article_rec.title: Good moods
article_rec.subtitle: outlook, affect and mood in dynemotion and the mind module

abstract.par: In this paper we describe two systems for autonomous characters intended to simulate the minds of characters in virtual game worlds. These systems, the Dynemotion People Engine (DPE) and the Mind Module (MM), are here presented with special focus placed on the design and implementation of the parts of the architecture that simulate what is colloquially called mood. The mood feature is presented to the user in both applications as a fine-grained matrix that summarizes the character's state of mind, typically a complex state. Thus in both systems the mood feature functions as a qualitative guide describing the affordances for the interaction with one's own avatar or another character at a given moment. This simplifies the design and balancing of game design in terms of authorial affordances and provides a more familiar context for user-character interactions.

fulltext.ft_body: Good Moods Outlook, Affect and Mood in Dynemotion and the Mind Module Mirjam Palosaari EladhariMichael Sellers Gotland University Online Alchemy Visby, Sweden Austin, USAmirjam.eladhari@hgo.se mike@onlinealchemy.com ABSTRACT In this paper we describe two systems for autonomous char­acters intended to simulate the minds of characters in virtual game worlds. These systems, the Dynemotion People En­gine (DPE) and the Mind Module (MM), are here presented with special focus placed on the design and implementation of the parts of the architecture that simulate what is collo­quially called mood. The mood feature is presented to the user in both applications as a .ne-grained matrix that sum­marizes the character s state of mind, typically a complex state. Thus in both systems the mood feature functions as a qualitative guide describing the a.ordances for the inter­action with one s own avatar or another character at a given moment. This simpli.es the design and balancing of game design in terms of authorial a.ordances and provides a more familiar context for user-character interactions. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.0 [Arti.cial Intelligence]: General cognitive simula­tion; I.2.1 [Arti.cial Intelligence]: Arti.cial Intelligence games Keywords mood, personality, trait, character, multiplayer, a.ect 1. INTRODUCTION While trait theory from personality psychology and a.ect theory have been used as inspiration for systems that give agents emotions and personality, there is no obvious the­ory in the .eld of psychology or cognitive science to lean on when it comes to modeling what we in daily speech call mood. In this paper we use the word mood in this every­day sense, to mean an overall state or quality of feeling at a particular time. Mood changes faster than personality, but typically more slowly than individual emotions. The mood of a person in real life is a complex state. It is temporary and highly contextual, but can linger even if the context Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. changes. It is also individual, i.e., the way mood changes and .uctuates depends on the individual s personality and internal psychology, not just the context of the moment. This paper began to take shape when the authors of this paper met for the .rst time. When comparing our systems ­the Dynemotion People Engine (DPE) and the Mind Module (MM), we found striking similarities though the systems had been developed without knowledge of each other: Both sys­tems are agent-based architectures for characters in multi­player games, and use the Five Factor Model (FFM) as a framework for the personality of the characters. While the emotional system of the MM is inspired by a.ect theory [17] and the OCC model [14] and the DPE uses an original model based on an underlying Maslovian system, neither of us had found applicable theories to draw upon for model­ing the summarizing state of mood, but both saw the need for such a feature. A summarizing display of a character s state of mind is useful both from an authorial perspective and from a user s perspective. In design readily understand­ing a character s mood is useful for understanding character motivations and interactions. From a user s point of view a representation of mood is necessary to have an accessible concentrated display of the current state of mind that other­wise might be too complex to understand in a multi-tasking game-world environment. In both DPE and MM mood is a state that can be seen as the tip of the iceberg of underlying emotions. A character s mood depends on their personality and on what he or she has experienced in its current context. Additionally, DPE and MM have similar solutions for dis­playing mood: both use the concept of a color coded matrix where the mood .uctuates along two axes that allow a high granularity of what the mood is, expanding beyond the binary notions of good and bad mood. In this paper we present Dynemotion and the Mind Module with a focus on the summarizing state of a character s mood. We compare these systems, present a small qualitative user study and discuss the systems from a technical and authorial point of view. 1.1 Related Work In psychology, trait theory has been developed to describe real life personality. Trait theory, pioneered by Allport in the 1930s [1], is one of several major branches of theories of personality, where the other branches roughly can be cate­gorized as type, psychoanalytic, behaviorist, cognitive, hu­manistic and biopsychological theories. From the trait the­ory, several di.erent personality assessment tests have been developed by psychologist, one of the most prominent being the Five Factor Model (FFM, also called Big Five ), which can be assessed for individuals using a questionnaire called the NEO PI-R [10]. Factor Trait Openness Imagination, Artistic Interests, Emotionality, Adventurousness, Intellect, Liberalism Continuousness Self-E.cacy, Orderliness, Dutifulness, Achievement-striving, Self-Discipline, Cautiousness Extraversion Friendliness, Gregariousness, Assertiveness, Activity-Level, Excitement-Seeking, Cheerfulness Agreeableness Trust, Morality, Altruism, Cooperation, Modesty, Sympathy Neuroticism Anxiety, Anger, Depression, Self-Continuousness, Immoderation, Vulnerability Table 1: Traits in NEO PI-R (also called OCEAN). Emotion modelling has during the past decades emerged as a separate .eld of study, where the theory presented by Ortony et al in 1988 proved to be an important landmark, now of­ten referred to as the OCC model [14]. The OCC model is purely theoretical, written in the .eld of psychology, but several applications in the .elds of AI and cognitive science have used it as an inspiration for frameworks for autonomous agents that simulate human emotion. Other work in the area of virtual characters that use both the FFM and the OCC as conceptual frameworks include work by Guoliang [5], Klesen [6], Kshirsagar[8], 2000) and El Jed [3], a virtual reality training environment tool for .re men. Guoliang s work include a factor for an agent s mood, where mood is briefer than a trait, but longer lasting than an emotion (this work also highlights the lack of uni.ed de.nitions of mood in the literature). An excellent discussion of the .eld of vir­tual characters with personality, emotions and mood can be found in the State of The Art Report Building Expression into Virtual Characters by Vinayagamoorthy [18]. In con­temporary games a few like The Sims 2 [16] have a bearing on this topic, where the characters have a mood represented as a diamond over the head of the character, which changes in colour depending on the mood. The mood in this case is a state that summarises how well a character s needs, such as hunger or social have been ful.lled. 2. DYNEMOTION The Dynemotion People Engine (DPE) is a system devel­ope by Online Alchemy, Inc. for creating agent-based AIs embodied in a virtual world context. The DPE is intended for use in games and simulations for training, therapeutic, and other uses. The AI aspects of DPE characters can also be applied to the player s avatar in a virtual world, provid­ing the player with additional information about and insight into their character and the world. 2.1 Basic Attributes DPE characters have personalities, desires, goals, and emo­tions. They observe and learn from the world around them, they are able to exchange opinions and experiences, and their memories a.ect their later goals, actions, relationships and personality. DPE agents have a personality typically based on the Five Factor Model (FFM). This creates a long­term baseline for the character s associations with their en­vironment. For example, a character with a high Neuroti­cism score would be more likely to experience greater anxiety given an observation of the same fearful object than would another character with a lower Neuroticism score. Person­ality in DPE characters is not immutable, but can change slowly over time based on their experiences. At the heart of the DPE is a set of quasi-Maslovian moti­vational desires that act as largely independent sub-agents. The type and number of these desires is variable, but they typically follow the outline of Maslow s hierarchy of needs [9] including physical, safety, social, skill, and contribution or self-actualization needs. Through observation of external conditions (including observed objects, people, and events with emotional associations) and internal states, and modi­.ed by the character s memories, associations, and personal­ity, these desires determine the character s goals and action choices. 2.2 Emotions Signi.cantly, each of the desires enables the mapping of sep­arate internally perceived emotional content. That is, each desire creates an emotional state-space, such that a charac­ter might feel hungry, hopeful, lonely, and proud all at the same time based on the states of di.erent internal desires. In broadly de.ning emotion, we follow an approach informed by the Schacter-Singer two factor theory [15], including all cognitively apprehended aspects of physiological or qualita­tive psychological states and processes. Some of these emotions appear and fade quickly, while oth­ers are much longer lasting (surprise vs. empathy, for ex­ample). This enables a much more nuanced and layered set of emotions that are tracked internally beyond just happy or sad. For example, happiness can correspond to var­ious combinations of pleasure, delight, amity, satisfaction, empathy, and joy (an incomplete set of inexact names for happy emotions moving up the Maslovian hierarchy from physical to peak experiences). These emotional distinctions are not taken from any existing model, but are derived from the applicable emotions for each desire. These distinctions are necessarily qualitative, but have met with comprehen­sion and acceptance in early user tests. 2.3 Mood Display While DPE characters, like humans, have a richly textured internal emotional landscape, it is not always possible (or desirable) to communicate the many layers of feeling at all times. When interacting with another person, a pinched look on their face may indicate a variety of conditions from indigestion to social rejection; we map a complex internal space to our faces, gestures, and speech. This mapping con­denses many conditions into a smaller state space which in turn aids in fast comprehension of overall qualitative emo­tional state -what we typically call someone s mood. To aid in comprehension of one agent s emotional state, or mood, by another agent or by a human user, we map the internal layered model to a two-dimensional space that is also color­coded to provide a qualitative, locational visual indication of the overall mood. Internally each desire s emotional state maps to this mood space, but the mood is typically displayed as an aggregate of all internal emotions. Figure 1: The Dynemotion Mood space and color This mood mapping has two axes: the x-axis is termed Out­look ; it is the overall positive or negative valence to how the individual is feeling -in broad terms from avoidance to at­traction, unhappy to happy, or generally bad to good. The y-axis is a depiction of expressed energy, and is thus called A.ect. In broad terms this varies from inert or in­sensate on the low end to very high-energy (surprised or excited) on the upper extreme. Combining these two axes together yields the two-dimensional mood space shown in Figure 1. Normalizing the two axes so that each covers the range [-1,1], we can describe the four extremes and other important points. High Outlook, high A.ect (1,1) is high­energy happiness; this corresponds to pleasurable or joyful moods, or other forms of active positive feeling. High Out­look, low A.ect (1,-1) equates to satiation or a peaceful, zen-like calm. Low Outlook and low A.ect (-1,-1) describes an unmotivated (low-energy) unhappiness, best exempli.ed by despair. Low Outlook, high A.ect (-1,1) can be seen as rage. The primary di.erence between these two negative poles is that in the latter the individual is ready to act, to lash out, while in the former the lack of energy indicates that no action is deemed possible or relevant. In between these points we have the ends of the axes: high A.ect (wired/excited); high Outlook (pleased); low A.ect (lethargic or insensate); and low Outlook (not merely un­happy but also encompassing extreme repulsion or fear re­actions). The color mapping applied to this quadrant system is based on a typical color wheel, but with some adjustments: the color becomes more saturated as values diverge from the center ((0,0) is emotionally neutral and thus gray), and the colors become darker with decreasing A.ect. This yields a bright red for anger, a light green for joy, a blue-green for peaceful calm, and a deep blue-violet for despair. In our early user testing, these color combinations have been readily recognizable as shorthand for mood when displayed on or around avatars. A group of characters with a red glow or red disks at their feet are quickly seen as being an angry mob, for example. Given the qualitative nature of the col­ors, as a character s mood changes, corresponding changes in their displayed color value is an understandable indicator of their emotional shifts. We have also experimented with assigning text-string indicators to di.erent locations in this quadrant space (up to 64 separate mood names in an 8-by-8 grid); this text appears to work well as an adjunct to the color and positional indication, but is not su.cient on its own to quickly communicate a character s mood. It is interesting to note that these four quadrants correspond to the four medieval humors thought at the time to govern an individual s internal emotional and physical balance: san­guine (high-energy happy); phlegmatic (low-energy happy); melancholy (low-energy unhappy); and choleric (high-energy unhappy). While this cannot be taken as anything more than an anecdotal correspondence, it highlights the fact that in devising systems to simulate or emulate emotions and moods, there is little more than personal experience and anecdote in the literature to base these on. The popular OCC model is itself an analytic approach to de.ning emo­tions by separating their referents -a paradoxically logi­cal approach to quantifying what are ultimately qualitative states. An important area for continuing research is in de­vising emotional systems that are progressively more recog­nizable, complete, and predictable from the point of view of multiple, cross-cultural studies with humans. 3. THE MIND MODULE The Mind Module (MM) is a semi-autonomous agent archi­tecture built to be used in a multiplayer environment as a part of the player s avatar. It can also be used with au­tonomous characters, but here we focus on its application to player characters. The MM models the avatar s personal­ity as a collection of traits inspired by the FFM, maintains dynamic emotion state as a function of interactions with ob­jects in the environment and trait values, and summarizes the avatar s current emotional state as an inner and outer mood. 3.1 Affect Nodes The current iteration of the MM consists of a weighted net­work of interconnected nodes of four types: traits, emotions, sentiments and moods as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2: A.ect Node Types Emotions can be regarded as brief and focused (ie. directed at an intentional object) disposition, while sentiments can be distinguished as a permanent and focused disposition [12]. Similarly, mood can be regarded as a brief and global dis­position, while personality can be regarded as a permanent and global disposition. Hence emotion, mood, sentiment and personality are regions of a two-dimensional a.ect plane, with focus (focused to global) along one dimension and du­ration (brief to permanent) along the other as illustrated in Figure 3. A value of a node with a fast decay rate is non­zero for only a short period of time after the stimulus that causes the value of the node to change, and thus a.ects the value of other nodes in the network for only a short period of time. Figure 3: Two-dimensional a.ect plane 3.2 Personality and Emotions The personality of a character de.nes the nature and strength of the emotions a character feels in di.erent situations. The MM gives each avatar 30 trait nodes, inspired by the FFM, as shown in Table 1. The traits are grouped into .ve factors, with the value of a factor being a weighted linear combination of the values of the traits. The choice of the 13 emotions (listed in the Mood section below) used by the MM emotions is based on research into a.ects and a.ect theory by Tomkins [17], Ekman [2] and Nathansson [13]. Through a mapping of weightings between emotion nodes and trait nodes, the MM de.nes how much the value of an emotion node .uctuates for each avatar. For example, the emotion node Amusement is connected to four trait nodes with the following weightings: Cheerfulness: 1.1, Depres­sion: 0.9, Imagination: 1.2 and Emotionality: 1.1. Thus, stimuli that would lead to Amusement will lead to more Amusement the higher the trait values for Cheerfulness, Imagination, and Emotionality, and less Amusement the higher the trait value for Depression. Systematic informa­tion about e.ects of personality on emotion applicable for the MM is scarce. The current weightings between traits and emotion is experimental and is evaluated with the goal to create interesting game play experiences rather than sim­ulating a set of beliefs of about the workings of the human mind. 3.3 Mood The mood is a processed summary of current state of a char­acter s mind. The mood of a character is measured on two scales that are independent of each other, an inner (intro­vert) and an outer (expressive). Each scale ranges from -50 to 50; this corresponds to Depressed to Bliss on the inner scale, Angry to Exultant on the outer scale as shown in Fig­ure 4. The inner mood is the private sense of or harmony that can be present even if the character is in an environment where events lead to a parallel mood of annoyance. Reversely, a character in a gloomy mood can still be in a cheerful mood space if events in the context give that result. The nature of the outer mood is social, and as such tied to emotions that are typically not only directed towards another entity but also often expressed toward an entity, such as anger Figure 4: Mood matrix or amusement. The two scales for the mood nodes open up the possibility of more complex states of mind than a single binary axis of moods that cancel each other out. The weightings between the mood nodes and the emotion nodes are shown in table 2. Emotion Weight to Inner Mood Weight to Outer Mood Amusement +2 Interest -excitement +1.5 Enjoyment -Joy +2 +2 Relief +1.5 +1.5 Satisfaction +2 Surprise -Startle +1.5 Confusion -1.5 Distress -Anguish -2 -1.5 Fear -Terror -2 Anger -Rage -2 Shame -Humiliation -1.5 Sadness -2 Guilt -1.5 Table 2: How the mood scales are a.ected by emo­tions. The weightings in table 2 are those tested in the prototype described in this paper, and are subject to change. Just as with the mapping between traits and emotion there are few sources in psychology to draw upon for these details, and since the purpose of the implementation is to facilitate game play experiences rather than a true simulation of the human mind, the iterations of this aspect of the MM is tested and reiterated accordingly. The real-time, or current, mood of the character is depen­dent on the nature and strength of the emotions the char­acter has experienced the past hours. The strength of the emotions is di.erent for di.erent characters depending on their personality traits. The nature of the emotions di.ers depending on what sentiment nodes the characters have to­ward other entities in the context. Hence two characters going through a similar series of events potentially have dif­ferent emotional experiences and therefore end up in di.er­ent mood spaces. 3.4 Sentiments -Emotional attachments A player character can have emotions associated with game objects. For example, a character with arachnophobia would have the emotion Fear associated with objects of type Spi­der. Such associated emotions are called sentiments. These are represented in the MM via sentiment nodes that link emotion nodes to speci.c objects or object types. Thus, if the player s avatar has a sentiment of Fear towards Spiders, and a Spider comes within perceptual range, there will be an immediate change in the value of the Fear node; the exact value of the change will be a function of the strength of the sentiment as well as the values of the traits that modulate the value of Fear. The sentiment nodes of the MM allows several sentiments ie, of di.erent emotions, to be attached toward an other entity, thus creating a compound set of sentiment. Sen­timents can in a game world context be created several ways. The emergent sentiments origin from interactions with other entities in the world, thus creating emotional memories. The authored sentiment sets have certain pre-set combinations. For example infatuation is a combination of interest/excitement/amusement and joy toward another character. The authored sets of sentiments have a longer decay rate than the one s emerging from interaction. The MM thus provides the player with information about the avatars feelings toward other entities in the world. Prox­imity to objects or characters a.ect the emotions, and thus the mood of an avatar, functioning as information the player can use to form an agenda for game play. Thus, in compar­ison to DPE the MM relies more on the player s own goal formulation. 3.5 Case study: Affecting the mood of a char­acter using Affective Actions In order to explore how players would take to the use of mood in a social game play context we devised a test scenario in a paper prototype, see Figure 5. Figure 5: Guided paper prototype play test. A player is using an a.ective action 3.5.1 World of Minds The context for the test was World of Minds (WoM), a pro­totype game world where the personalities of the inhabitants are the base for the game mechanics. When interacting with other characters, the reactions depend upon the player char­acter s current mood and personality. The basic game play of WoM is simple: Players need to de­feat physical manifestations of negative mental states. In order to do so, they can cast spells on them, but the spells available are constrained by the avatar s personality, her cur­rent mood, and how far the avatar has progressed in learning new spells. Each avatar has mind energy (mana) and mind resistance (hit points). Each spell costs mind energy to use, and attacks reduce mind resistance. The experience of the character de.nes how large the possible pool of energy and resistanse is at a given moment. The regeneration rate of re­sistanse depends on the inner mood, while the regeneration rate of the energy depends on the outer mood, as shown in .gure 6. Figure 6: Fluctuations of Mind Energy and Mind Resistance A central feature in WoM is that players can a.ect each other s moods by using a.ective actions (AAs). AAs are actively chosen by the players, they are not e.ects of other social actions. If a player targets another avatar she can choose from a selection of AAs. For example the AA Com­fort can be used successfully on targets that have an active emotion node of Sadness, but only if the player s own avatar is not in the area of Furious on the mood matrix. If the AA Comfort is used successfully the values of the emotion nodes Sadness and Anguish of the target are diminished, which in turn a.ects the mood of the character. Sentiments for avatars in WoM are generally instantiated as a result of a player character s action or of a result a player s choice. In the current implementation sentiments are instantiated when an emotion node reaches a threshold value, in most cases set as 90% of its maximum. Figure 7 is an illustration of how an a.ective action or a spell causing amusement is interpreted by the MM. The values on the arrows between the nodes are weights. 3.5.2 Play-test Our approach for evaluating the game design via a paper prototype draws on User-Centered Design, where the user s experience is a main driver for design, as well as from rapid prototype and playtesting approaches that are becoming more common in game design [4]. During the playtests, the test leader walks individual players through a paper simu­ Figure 7: An example of how an amusing action is interpreted by the MM lation of several scenarios. Players are asked to think aloud while playing the game; additionally, the test leader stops the game at several points and conducts interviews. Our approach is described in detail in [7]. Ten players individually went through .ve game mastered scenarios where her avatar had a mind, represented by the character sheet as shown in Figure 8. During the .ve scenarios, the player was guided through using the main categories of actions in the game, includ­ing a.ective actions, navigation in a landscape of sentiment, and mind magic spells. Using the character sheet (Fig. 8), the test leader updated the state of mind of the avatar and NPCs, showing the player the e.ect of her actions in the game in terms of .uctuations in emotions, mood, mind en­ergy and mind resistance. In order to best capture player s problem-solving processes within the game, and to best un­derstand potential areas for confusion, the players were given minimal explanations about how and what to do. At any point, players could access a help system in order to ask any question. The twenty-two interview questions focused on the player s understanding of the relationship between values in the MM, e.ects of game actions, relationship be­tween personality and availability of actions such as spells, etc. For each playtest, the participant: 1. Filled in a short (less than ten questions) survey on demographic data and previous gaming experience. 2. Took the IPIP-NEO Personality test and emailed the results to the test leader. 3. Filled in a short survey about their experience taking the personality test and their opinions about the use of personality traits for avatar creation. 4. Participated in the playtest, which took between 1 and 1.5 hours. Each playtest session consisted of playing .ve scenarios, and answering questions in two inter­views, one in the middle, and one at the end of the playtest. Each session was videotaped. 5. Filled in two more short surveys, one focused on senti­ment objects, and the other on general impressions of the experience. We used the video analysis tool Transana to analyze the 15 hours of video of interviews and play sessions. We devel­oped a coding scheme for potentially relevant phenomena and states of mind; this provided us with the initial frame­work for searching for patterns and regularities, as advo­cated by Miles and Huberman [11]. 3.5.3 Players and affective actions The scenario that was most interesting for results regarding the mood feature were where the player met the character Teresa, who was played by the game master. Teresa had an identical character sheet but with values showing that she was depressed. She introduced the player to the use of Af­fective Actions (AAs) by saying that she was very sad, and asking for a hug . Seven of the players chose to hug Teresa, while three of them started the chain of AA s in the scenario with using Comfort . The AA comfort would diminish the emotions of sadness and anguish in the targeted character. No one chose the AA Look at target with dismay which would have created an increase in the nodes confusion and sadness. Some AA s were to be used in a reciprocal fashion, such as joke where the target could respond by either Laugh at joke , or Refuse to laugh at Joke . Using such an AA in­cluded a risk, since if the target chose (or had to) to refuse, the e.ect on the joker would be an increase in distress and sadness. Laughing on the other hand would give both the joker and the target in increase of amusement, plus an in­crease in the satisfaction node of the successful joker. How­ever, if the target of the AA Joke had her mood marker in the leftmost row in the mood matrix (4) it was not possible Figure 8: Mind Sheet used in playtest of WoM. to use the Laugh at Joke reciprocal AA. The players enjoyed monitoring the .uctuations of the mood in their own avatars and Teresa and experimenting with dif­ferent AAs. This scenario, one of .ve, was the most popu­lar one: the majority of the players pointed it out as their favorite part of playing the prototype. Several of the par­ticipants used the expression make sense when discussing the mood feature in relation to the a.ective actions in the interviews conducted in relation to the tests. 4. COMPARISON OF MOOD REPRESEN-TATION IN DPE AND MM The two scales of the mood matrices of DPE and MM are similar despite many di.erences in the details in the un­derlying systems. Both create a spatial representation with the extremes of anger, despair, exultation, and bliss, though each organizes the underlying axes di.erently. MM di.eren­tiates between inner and outer mood, while DPE puts both internal and social emotions in the same mood-space. A.ect in the DPE is valence-neutral; that is, it is part of positive and negative moods alike. This is somewhat analogous to the change between inner and outer mood in MM, but the analogy can easily become strained. One aspect of mod­eling emotions and moods that is clear in both cases, and which was pervasive in our discussions, is the lack of clear terminology for referring to qualitative emotion and mood states. This hinders literature comprehension, design, and comparison between models. 5. CONCLUSIONS We have presented two systems that simulate the minds of virtual characters where their moods are displayed as the aggregation of multiple underlying emotions. Unlike person­ality traits the mood depends on the context, just as emo­tions, but the mood lingers, bringing the emotional memory of recent experiences into the contexts, thus enriching an en­vironment where characters appear more plausible than in the virtual game worlds to date. Players may use this infor­mation about their own avatar and other characters in the game in order to interpret the internal state of that charac­ter, what kind of actions that can be performed, or interpret what interactions would be appropriate in a given context. Guided play tests show that despite issues of naming moods, users .nd their graphical and textual display useful in game play situations that use metaphors of social interaction. 6. REFERENCES [1] G. article_rec.title: Combining heuristic and landmark search for path planning

abstract.par: We propose a hybridization of heuristic search and the LPI algorithm. Our approach uses heuristic search to find paths to landmarks, and employs a small amount of landmark information to correct itself when the heuristic search deviates from the shortest path. The use of the heuristic allows lower memory usage than LPI, while the use of the landmarks permits the algorithm to operate effectively even with a poor heuristic. When the heuristic accuracy is very high, the algorithm tends towards greedy search; when the heuristic accuracy is low, the algorithm tends towards LPI. Experiments show that the memory usage of LPI can be reduced by more than half while preserving the accuracy of the solutions.

fulltext.ft_body: Combining Heuristic and Landmark Search for Path Planning Kevin Grant David Mould Dept. of Math and Computer ScienceSchool of Computer ScienceUniversity of LethbridgeCarleton UniversityLethbridge, AB, CanadaOttawa, ON, Canada kevin.grant2@uleth.ca mould@scs.carleton.ca ABSTRACT We propose a hybridization of heuristic search and the LPI algorithm. Our approach uses heuristic search to .nd paths to landmarks, and employs a small amount of landmark in­formation to correct itself when the heuristic search deviates from the shortest path. The use of the heuristic allows lower memoryusage than LPI,while the useof the landmarksper­mits the algorithm to operate e.ectively even with a poor heuristic. When the heuristic accuracy is very high, the algorithm tends towards greedy search; when the heuristic accuracy is low, the algorithm tends towards LPI. Experi­ments show that the memory usage of LPI can be reduced by more than half while preserving the accuracy of the so­lutions. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.1[Applications and Expert Systems]: Games General Terms Path planning, heuristics, precomputation, LPI 1. INTRODUCTION Finding least-cost paths through maps is a fundamental problem in computer science, and is of particular interest in computer games, with autonomous units planning their routes across the virtual landscape, and human-controlled units receiving high-level instructions (e.g., advance to this locationon themap )andbeingrequiredtoresolve thelow­level details themselves. Because of the importance of the path planning problem, many algorithms have been pro­posed to solve it. Two popular classes of path planners are heuristic search algorithms and precomputation algorithms. Heuristic search algorithms compute paths at run-time, us­ing a heuristic function to guide the search; the quality of the heuristic determines the time required to .nd a solu­tion. Heuristic search has a low-memory overhead (linear on graph size), and adapts well to a changing graph, since Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 nothing is pre-computed. However, it requires the existence of good heuristics, which are not always available. Further­more, game maps are often designed in such a way as to frustrate simple heuristics. Precomputation algorithms compute pathsbetweenpoints o.ine; at runtime, .nding pathsbecomes a simple greedy search. If memory allows, one can precompute and store all shortest paths between all points [3, 7]. Because of quadratic memory requirements, this is typically not pos­sible. The LPI algorithm (Landmark Path.nding between Intersections) [5] stores shortest path information for only a subset of the vertices in a graph. The paths found are an approximation to the actual shortest path; the approxima­tions are typically of a high quality. However, even though the memory cost for LPI is lower than storing all shortest paths, it are still considerably higher than heuristic search algorithms, as the size of each landmark is linear on the number of nodes in the graph. In this paper, we propose incorporating heuristic search into the LPI algorithm, to make use of the low memory ad­vantages of heuristic search and the runtime advantages of LPI.Conventionally, heuristic searchprovides an estimate of the distance remaining to the goal from a given node, which is then used to decide which node to expand in a search; this is the process usedby A*. In our case, we use a heuristic that does not do distance estimation; rather, given a node, the heuristic suggests which node is next on the path to­wards the goal. With such a heuristic, we can amend LPI to store landmark information only when the landmarks s path deviates from the path suggested by the heuristic when the heuristic and landmark agree, nothing needs to be stored. There are several bene.ts to this approach. First, the amount of storage required by the landmarks is reduced substantially in some cases, an order of magnitude reduc­tion is realized. Second, this allows LPI to take advantage of application-speci.c structure in graphs whenever it is avail­able, just as other heuristic-based search methods do (e.g., Euclidean distance in a planar graph). The algorithm be­haves nicely according to heuristic accuracy: with a perfect heuristic, the algorithm reverts to greedy depth-.rst search; with an inaccurate heuristic, the algorithm reverts to stan­dard LPI. Moreover, even if the heuristic is accurate in only part of the graph, the algorithm can make full use of the accurate portion of the heuristic information, storing land­mark information only where the heuristic is unhelpful. Note that the path planning methods presented here are targeted at weighted graphs. In such graphs, the weights of edges between nodes are non-uniform, representing di.- Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. culty (e.g., distance, time, hazards) of making the crossing between adjacent nodes. Weighted graphs are a generaliza­tion of the more common obstacle maps : graphs whose tran­sition edge weights are uniform, with obstacles that forbid access to certain locations. Weighted graphs o.er a richer representation than obstacle graphs, since the weights can be used to represent various concepts: the hazard of mov­ing through defended territory; exposure to detection in a stealth game; even aspects of a character s personality can be described by graph weights, by, for example, increasing (or decreasing) the weights for walking over muddy ground. The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 gives some background on the problem domain, as well as some rep­resentative path planning algorithms. Section 3 presents a simple variation on the original LPI algorithm that makes it independent of precomputed costs between vertices and landmarks. Section4 presents the incorporation of heuristic use into the landmarking algorithm. Section 5 considers the same algorithm when we allow landmarks to maintain sub­optimal paths. Finally, Section 6 discusses the results and suggests future work. 2. BACKGROUND We consider the task of .nding the shortest path between two vertices in the graph with n vertices and m edges; a request for a shortest path is called a query. We use S and G to refer to the start vertex and end vertex of our path, respectively, and the optimal distance between two nodes A and B is written d(A,B). As mentioned, the proposed algorithm is e.ectively a hy­brid of a search algorithm employing heuristics and the LPI algorithm. We discuss each in turn. 2.1 Search Heuristics In search algorithms, a heuristic is a function that esti­mates the cost from a current state to the goal state. Specif­ically, when searching for paths through graphs, the heuris­tic estimates the path cost between two vertices. Given a set of potential vertices to explore, a search algorithm uses heuristics to select which vertex to explore next. For exam­ple, greedy search [9] chooses the vertex with the smallest remaining value, while A* [6] chooses the vertex with the smallest accrued cost plus remaining cost. The heuristic accuracy directly a.ects the number of ver­tices explored in the graph when searching for a path. A perfect heuristic would allow a greedy hill-climbing search to traverse directly from start to goal. A poor heuristic gives no information to the search algorithm, and subse­quently results in blind searches that have the potential to explore much of the graph before .nding a path. Hence, path planning using search heuristics should only be done if the heuristic is accurate. As we will see, the proposed method makes this choice automatically. 2.2 LPI The LPI algorithm [5] uses landmarks for .nding paths between two vertices. A landmark L is a vertex that stores the shortest path from itself to all other vertices in the graph. Hence, the LPI algorithm requires solving the single-source shortest path (SSSP) problem for each landmark. The SSSP problem can be solved by Dijkstra s algorithm [2], which computes d(S,V) for every vertex V, as well as a previous vertex for each vertex in the graph relative to L, denoted pL(V)for vertex V. The previous vertex is the vertex that precedes V in the shortest path from V to L: the shortest path from any vertex V to L canbereconstructed simplyby following these previous pointers. Each landmark requires O(n)space to hold the shortest paths to n vertices. The LPI algorithm .nds a path between S and G as fol­lows: for a landmark L, we traverse the shortest path from S towards L, using the information at landmark L this is called the upswing from S to L. At the same time, we traverse the shortest path from G towards L, called the downswing from G to L. As we traverse the upswing, we label each visited vertex with its cost to S, which we main­tain as a running total. A similar labeling is performed for each vertex when traversing the downswing. The upswing and downswing eventually meet; thispoint is called the least common ancestor (LCA) of S and G relative to L. The up­swing and downswing terminate at their respective LCA. Whenan upswingandadownswingintersect(atpoint I), the path from S to I to G is considered asapossible path. The cost of this path is immediately available as the sum of the upswing and downswing labels. During its operation, LPI considers all possible intersections between upswings and downswings, remembering the intersection point with the lowest cost. The path running through this intersection of lowest cost can be reconstructed through a greedy hill­climbing search from the intersectionpoint. Note that there is guaranteed to be an intersection between an upswing and downswing, although in the worst case this intersection is found at the landmark vertex itself. Figure 1 shows an example of LPI in action. In these .gures, the landmarks are shown as circles, while the start and endpoints are shown as triangles. As the upswings and downswings are traversed (Figures 1(a) and 1(b)), all inter­sections between an upswing and downswing are recorded. When all swings havebeen traversed, the upswing and down­swing whose intersection is of lowest cost is used to recon­struct an approximate path in time linear on path length (Figure 1(c)). The primary advantage of LPI is its speed: following pre­computed paths is quite fast, and the labeling operation adds little overhead to this computation. In addition, the LPI algorithm was shown to produce paths of high quality typically within 1% of optimal. The primary disadvantage of LPI is its memory requirements. The O(n)storage used for each landmark is needed at runtime, and while the al­gorithm performs well with a small number of landmarks, larger graphs require more landmarks to maintain constant quality. Reducing the memory cost of LPI while maintaining its path quality is the primary objective of this paper. 2.3 Other Path Planning Algorithms The ALT class of algorithms [4] uses landmarks to guide its heuristics. Speci.cally, let V and G be two vertices in the graph, and L be a landmark. By the triangle inequality, |d(V,L)- d(L,G)| is a lower bound for the distance d(V,G). The largest lower bound over all landmarks is used as the heuristic value. In some sense, the ALT algorithm uses a procedure that is the opposite of the method we propose here: ALT uses landmarks to de.ne its heuristic, while we use heuristics to reduce the memory requirements of land­marks. One of the advantages of ALT is that it is an exact algorithm. However, ALT requires many more node expan­sions than LPI, while the path quality of LPI remains close (a) Upswings. (b) Downswings. (c) An upswing and downswing being combined to form a path. The path (shown as a solid line) is reconstructed from the point of intersection. The opti­mal path is shown as a dotted line. Figure 1: An example of how LPI .nds an approx­imate path. Landmarks are shown as circles, while the start and end vertex are shown by a . and ., respectively. to optimal [5]. Another class of algorithms that combines search with pre-computed structure is hierarchical search. The HTAP algorithm [8] creates a hierarchy of abstracted graphs of­.ine; runtime queries are handled by creating one query for each level of the hierarchy, and using the results of searching the low-resolution graphs to constrain subsequent higher­resolution searches. Because searchtakes place in a constant­width corridor at each level, HTAP s time complexity is lin­ear in the number of edges in the .nal path. HTAP uses O(n log n) space to store the hierarchy. However, the con­straint means that the optimal path may notbe found. Em­pirical comparison showed that LPI provided considerably higher quality paths than HTAP, while requiring roughly the same time and space cost [5]. 3. DISTANCE-FREE LANDMARKS LPI relies on locating the LCA of two vertices S and G for each landmark. It expands the upswing and downswing from S and G towards their respective landmark in parallel; by always moving from the vertex that is farthest from the landmark, we are assured that neither swing moves past theLCA.Thisprocess depends on the distance information at each landmark. However, our intent is to prune some landmark information in favour of heuristic search, and the heuristic will not store this distance information. Hence, it is important that the algorithm be able to function without it. We can traverse the shortest paths with only the previous pointers; no cost information is necessary. If we remove the restriction that we will not move past the LCA, and instead simply traverse until we reach the landmark, then the cost information from the SSSP algorithm is not used. Allowing traversal past the LCA results in unnecessary traversal for the upswing. However,a simple modi.cationof the algorithm can reduce the amount of unnecessary traver­sal considerably. Rather than choosing one subset of land­marks (of size k), and traversing from S and G towards these landmarks, we instead choose a set of k landmarks for S, and a di.erent set of k landmarks for G. The set of landmarks for S is those closest to G, and the set of land­marks for G is those closest to S. Even though we employ twice as many landmarks, we are now doing only one swing per landmark. When traversing an upswing, we need not traverse past the .rst found intersection point, as the tri­angle inequality (which holds between the shortest path be­tween points) guarantees that any intersections found along a swing past the .rst intersection point cannot be of lower cost. Aborting each swing upon reaching the .rst intersec­tion can greatly reduce the number of traversed vertices. With the modi.ed algorithm, there might notbe any in­tersections between the upswings and downswings. In this exceptional circumstance, we can construct a path by send­ing a downswing from G to G s closest landmark, which guarantees an intersection with the upswing from S to this landmark (if only at the landmark itself). We now need to be able to determine the closest land­marks to particular vertices. However, the number of land­marks used in each path query by the LPI algorithm is typ­ically small. Hence, we suggest storing, for each vertex, a .xed-size set of closest landmarks, independent of the num­ber of landmarks placed in the graph. 3.1 Evaluation To compare the modi.ed LPI algorithm against the origi­nal, we use the same terrains used to test the LPI algorithm. These include four 512× 512 images (Mandrill, Lena, Pep­pers, andTerrain), one simple maze (243×243), one complex maze (340 × 340), and two random terrains of size 243 × 243 and 729×729. We also use four 243×243 maps fromFreeciv, an open source strategy game [1]. In all graphs, each vertex is connected to its eight neighbours, and the cost of traversal between neighbouring vertices is proportional to the inten­sity of their corresponding pixels. Table 1 compares the accuracy of the original algorithm vs. the modi.ed algorithm,with8 landmarks placedin the graph and using the closest4landmarks for path generation. We chose to use 8 landmarks, as this value keeps the mem­ory cost low while still giving reasonable results in these 2D terrain maps. We make 5000 random queries, and show the accuracy of the paths relative to optimal. Each column of the table shows the percentage of queries that were within x% of optimal, where x% is the column header. As the table shows, no accuracy is lost; in fact, the accuracy is slightly improved. Table2 shows the di.erence in cost from the original algo­rithm to the modi.ed algorithm for the same tests. For this test, we divide the cost of computing using the new method by the cost of computing using the old method; computa­tional costwas quanti.edby numberof expandedverticesin the searchprocess. Each table entryshows thepercentage of values that fall below x, where x is the column header. The table shows that in these test cases, the modi.ed method Mandrill Lena Peppers Terrain Simple Maze Complex Maze Random-243 Random-729 Freeciv-1 Freeciv-2 Freeciv-3 Freeciv-4 73.6 76.3 86.2 75.4 85.2 83.4 70.1 55.9 58.3 57.6 56.5 58.9 85.9 88.3 92.0 85.1 87.8 91.3 87.3 84.9 85.7 86.2 86.2 85.3 Unmodi.ed 1% 5% 10% 92.0 92.9 94.4 90.8 90.1 94.4 93.3 93.3 93.7 93.8 93.9 92.8 76.3 79.7 87.6 76.4 85.4 86.5 74.2 58.6 62.0 61.7 58.9 62.9 1% 87.7 89.5 92.3 85.6 88.1 92.5 89.2 86.3 87.2 87.4 87.3 86.8 Modi.ed 5% 92.8 93.4 94.5 91.0 90.3 95.1 94.1 94.1 94.2 94.1 94.1 93.3 10% Table 1: Accuracy comparison between original and modi.ed algorithm. Numbers are thepercentage of queries within x% of optimal, where x% is the column header. 0.8 0.9 1.0 1.1 1.2 Mandrill 15.5 Lena 17.3 Peppers 19.5 Terrain 18.0 Simple Maze 41.0 Complex Maze 22.3 Random-243 13.8 Random-729 14.1 Freeciv-1 14.6 Freeciv-2 15.1 Freeciv-3 15.1 Freeciv-4 14.9 33.4 39.1 37.2 40.2 58.0 37.5 34.2 36.0 36.8 36.2 36.3 38.4 56.6 64.6 55.1 63.9 70.1 55.7 62.3 64.1 62.6 63.7 63.0 64.9 75.3 84.0 68.1 82.1 78.6 71.0 84.7 87.5 85.7 86.5 85.5 85.2 86.1 91.8 77.8 90.5 83.9 81.4 94.5 96.6 96.2 96.8 96.3 95.6 Table 2: Cost comparison between original and modi.ed algorithm. Numbers are thepercentage of queries whose ratio of visited vertices between the modi.ed and original algorithm are below the column label. is slightly less expensive than the original method: the pro­portion of paths requiring less than the cost of the original LPI algorithm was over 50% in all cases. For the remainder of this document, any reference to the LPI algorithm will refer to the modi.ed version of the algo­rithm. 4. HEURISTICS + LANDMARKING As mentioned, heuristic search works well when the dis­tance estimatesreturnedbythe estimate are accurate. When the heuristic quality ispoor, the search expands many more nodes. On the other hand, the LPI algorithm typically re­turns paths of high quality after expanding very few nodes, but requires a considerable amount of storage for each land­mark.Thekey contributionof thispaperisto combine these two ideas, in order to get the space advantages of heuristic search and the computational speed of LPI. Consider Figure 2. Figure 2(a) shows the landmark paths from three vertices (shown by triangles) to a landmark in the graph (shown by a circle). Figure 2(b) shows the paths followed by a greedy heuristic search (with no backtracking) from these same vertices toward the landmark, using an air­distance heuristic. Notice that several of the paths never (a) Landmark link be­tween B and C can be removed, since it corre­sponds to the heuristic link. However, landmark link between A and C must remain. Figure 3: An example of pruning landmark links. Landmark paths are dotted arrows; heuristic paths are solid arrows. Numbers on edges are edge costs, numbers on nodes are distances to the landmark. actually reach the goal (i.e., the algorithm is incomplete). However, while the heuristic does not guarantee us an opti­mal path to the landmark (or a path at all), it does spend some time traversing the optimal paths. The most impor­tant fact about these heuristic search paths is that they are never stored they are computed at runtime. Following landmark construction, it is trivial to check which previous pointers correspond to the vertex returned by the heuristic. When thisoccurs,we canremove thatpre­vious pointer from the landmark information. Figure 2(c) shows the result of this: only the previous pointer informa­tion for deviations from the heuristic search paths need to be stored (the dotted lines). To traverse the path from a vertex to the landmark, we follow the previous pointer if one exists. If it doesn t exist, then we know from the rules of construction that the heuristic will guide us correctly to the next vertex in the optimal path. This pruning is done separately for each landmark. We refer to landmarks that have been pruned in this fashion as partial landmarks. Note that the previous pointer does not necessarily need to correspond exactly to the next vertex returned by the heuristic. Rather, if the heuristic returns a neighbour whose cost to the landmark is the same as the cost to the landmark from the previous pointer, then this previous pointer can be pruned. Figure 3 shows an example. In Figure 3(a), Mandrill 0.69 Lena 0.63 Peppers 0.68 Terrain 0.63 Simple Maze 0.55 Complex Maze 0.65 Random-243 0.55 Random-729 0.55 Freeciv-1 0.41 Freeciv-2 0.42 Freeciv-3 0.41 Freeciv-4 0.41 Heuristic: Manhattan Landmarks: 4 8 0.68 0.64 0.68 0.64 0.50 0.65 0.55 0.55 0.41 0.42 0.42 0.41 0.68 0.64 0.68 0.64 0.55 0.66 0.55 0.55 0.41 0.42 0.42 0.41 16 0.37 0.34 0.27 0.31 0.41 0.11 0.30 0.29 0.39 0.39 0.38 0.38 4 0.39 0.35 0.31 0.27 0.38 0.10 0.31 0.29 0.40 0.40 0.38 0.37 Popular 8 0.42 0.36 0.30 0.29 0.41 0.12 0.32 0.31 0.41 0.41 0.40 0.39 16 Mandrill Lena Peppers Terrain Simple Maze Complex Maze Random-243 Random-729 Freeciv-1 Freeciv-2 Freeciv-3 Freeciv-4 Landmarks: Heuristic: 58.5 57.8 69.0 65.8 86.8 73.1 46.0 38.1 38.9 36.1 35.4 38.1 N 61.7 76.2 78.7 72.3 76.8 89.4 64.5 51.4 65.5 66.9 65.4 67.5 4 M 77.9 84.0 88.8 86.1 88.4 96.2 80.7 73.2 64.7 63.5 63.9 65.4 P 76.3 79.7 87.6 76.4 85.4 86.5 74.2 58.6 62.0 61.7 58.9 62.9 N 79.2 84.2 89.1 84.3 89.8 91.2 83.7 78.3 83.4 82.3 83.6 83.8 8 M 86.4 90.1 92.9 91.9 90.1 96.5 90.2 87.9 83.1 82.0 83.3 82.0 P Table 3: Memory comparison of full vs. partial land­marks. Each number is the ratio between memory cost of partial landmarks and full landmarks. Col­umn headers show heuristic and number of land­marks used. the landmark link between A and C cannot be removed, as this would cause traversal through node B, resulting in a greater cost than traversing directly from A to C. However, in Figure 3(b), the landmark link between A and C can be removed, as the heuristic path (through B) o.ers a path of the same cost. A simple algorithm for pruning the links of landmark L is as follows: for each vertex V, let N be the neighbour of V along the heuristic path. We prune the landmark path from V if the following equality holds: d(V,L)= d(V,N)+d(N,L) (1) The distances to the landmarkare storedbythe landmark, while d(V,N)is stored as an edge cost by the graph. Even though this potentially changes the paths traversed, it does not change the cost of the paths from vertex to landmark, allowing optimization in cases where more than one optimal path exists. 4.1 Evaluation We evaluate this hybrid technique using the same test graphs as used in the last section. We test using two heuris­tics. The .rst heuristic estimates the remaining distance to the targetby a modi.ed manhattan distance metric,which allows for diagonal movement, and assumes that any edge between two neighbouringvertices has the lowest possible cost. The second heuristic is not a heuristic in the traditional sense, as it doesn t make a distance estimate between two vertices. Rather, when selecting a neighbour of vertex V, it always selects the same neighbour regardless of destination, and the selectedvertexit selectsis the one thatis selectedby the most landmarks (determined in advance after landmark computation). We refer to these heuristics asManhattan and Popular, respectively. Popular often outperforms Manhat­tan, but requires O(n)storage, whereas Manhattan requires no memory beyond graph storage. Table 3 shows the memory reduction realized by pruning the landmarks. Each valuein thegraphis foundby dividing the memory cost of the partial landmarks by the memory cost of the full landmarks. The column headers indicate the number of landmarks used, and the heuristic used. The results show a considerable memory reduction in all cases. The Popular heuristic is able to reduce the memory require- Table 4: Accuracy comparison between full and par­tial landmarks, using as many landmarks, partial or full, as we can .t into available memory. Each value is the percentage of queries within 1% of optimal. For the heuristic column headers, N = No pruning, M = Manhattan, P = Popular. mentsof the landmarksby over 50%in allgraphs, andby an order of magnitude in the complex maze. Note that Popular requires enough extra space to store one landmark; this cost was not shown in the table, as it does not depend on the number of landmarks chosen. While this technique can be used as a simple memory re­duction technique, it also increases the number of landmarks that we can store for the same memory cost. That is, we can store many partial landmarks in the same space as fewer full landmarks. More landmarks improves the chances of .nd­ing the optimal path between two vertices, so the quality of the paths increases. We run two tests over each graph, assuming enough memory for4 and8 full landmarks in each test, respectively. In each test, we store as many landmarks, partial or full, as we can given the memory available. Table 4 shows the result of this test. The table shows, for each landmark count and heuristic, the number of queries that were within 1% of optimal. The results show that using the partial landmarks o.ers a substantial improvement in the accuracy of the tests, at no additional memory cost. Over 4 landmarks, the popu­larity heuristic was able to bring an additional 20% of the queries within 1% of optimal for 11 out of 12 of the terrains. A particularly striking result is comparing the partial land­marks using 4 landmarks worth of memory (4th column) vs. the full landmarks using 8 landmarks worth of memory (5th column). In this comparison, the accuracy of the queries is improved over all graphs, while using only half of the mem­ory. One of the most attractive features of this algorithm is that it correctly balances the amount of landmark informa­tion and heuristic information that it uses. Consider the con­stant memory model, where we continue to add landmarks until a predetermined memory bound is reached. When the accuracy of the heuristic is high, the landmarks will un­dergo substantial pruning. As a result, more of these sparse landmarks will be added, and the resulting path queries will resemble a standard greedy search. In the best case (a per­fect heuristic), landmarks would be pruned entirely, which would allow every vertex to be a landmark, and the algo­rithm reverts to standard greedy depth-.rst search (that al­ Figure 4: An example partial graph. The poten­tial exists for a loop to be created along the paths between vertices A and B. ways .nds the optimal path, with no backtracking). On the other hand, when the accuracy of the heuristic is low, then the landmarks would not undergo much pruning at all. In the worse case (a pathological heuristic that never guesses correctly), all landmark information would be stored, and the algorithm reverts to standard LPI. Hence, the algorithm allows us to take as much advantage of a heuristic as pos­sible, but also permits searching over graphs for which no good heuristics are available. 5. THRESHOLDING LANDMARK ACCU-RACY The LPI algorithm permits a memory accuracy tradeo. when computing shortest paths. Increasing the number of landmarks improves accuracy but increases memory require­ments, while decreasing the number of landmarks has the opposite e.ect. The techniques of the previous section re­duces the amount of memoryper landmark, which improves this tradeo.. However, in circumstances where memory is severely lim­ited, we may need to further reduce memory costs (at the expense of accuracy). We propose the following technique. Recall that when pruning the landmarkpointers, a previous pointer from a vertex was pruned if the heuristic returns a neighbour whose cost to the goal was equivalent to the cost from thepreviouspointer. Note thatwewould accept an al­ternate routing from the landmark paths if it did not add to the cost between a vertex and the corresponding landmark (Figure 3(b)). Suppose we relax the equivalence constraint of Equation 1. That is, we will accept the routing of the heuristic if it doesn t add to the length of the path to the landmark by more than the tolerance value. Given a toler­ance t (a percentage), we replace Equation 1 with: d(V,N)+d(N,L)<d(V,L)* (1+ t) (2) and leave the pruning algorithm intact. Returning to Fig­ure 3(a), recall that we did not prune the landmark path between A and C, as the heuristic route increases the cost from A to landmark from 103 to 105. If a tolerance of 2% is permitted, then the landmark path between A and C would be dropped. When dropping landmark pointers using this tolerance scheme, thepotential exists to create a loop. For instance, consider Figure 4. In this case, the heuristic path from ver­tex B leads to A, while the landmark path of A points to B. Since d(B,A) =2, d(A,L) = 102, and d(B,L) = 100, then if t = 4%, the landmark pointer will be dropped. This createsa loopbetweenvertices A and B, and any navigation Prune (L,t) 1. for each V . Furthermore, the proposed scheme also has the potential to increase the distancebetweenavertex and its correspond­ing landmarkby more than the limit imposedby t. Consider again Figure 3(a). With a tolerance of more than 2%, the link from A to C would be dropped, as explained previ­ously. However, if one of the vertices along the path from A to landmark L were to drop its landmark link and increase its distance to L, this would further increase A s distance to L, possibly by more than the allowed amount. To resolve the previous two issues, we propose processing the vertices in order of increasing hops from the landmark along their respective shortest path (that is, in the order of a BFSbeginning at the landmark). This way, for avertex V, any vertex between V and the landmark along the short­est path has alreadybeen processed. When V is processed, we .rst update its cost to the landmark with the cost of its previous pointer to the landmark, plus the edge cost be­tween itself and the previous pointer. This ensures that if its previous pointer cost was updated, then its cost is now current. The pruning then proceeds as before, according to Equation 2 (using the updated distances), but with the fol­lowing caveat: the landmark link may only be severed if the heuristic path returns a vertex that has already been pro­cessed. Finally, after each node is processed, its cost to the landmark is updated. We formalize this process as the algorithm in Figure 5. We assume that each landmark L stores d(V,L)and pL(V), for all V. Denote as pH (V,L)the next vertex from V along the heuristic path, and denote as (V,L) the cost of the d+ path from V to L after V hasbeen processed. Theboolean function pr(·)denoteswhether avertex hasbeen processed or not. In addition to eliminating the potential for loops, this al­gorithm ensures that no adjusted path from vertex to land­mark ever exceeds the tolerance amount, as stated by the following theorem. Theorem 1. The base case is trivial, as the cost from the landmark to itself is always 0, and the algorithm does not adjust this. For the inductive step, let V be a vertex, and let NH be V s neighbour along the heuristic path, and let NL be V s neighbour along the landmark path. There are two cases to consider: either V s landmarkpointer is pruned, or it is not. Consider the case when the pointer is not pruned. By the inductive hypothesis, d+(NL,L)/d(NL,L) = (1 + t). This means that d+(V,L)= d(V,NL)+d+(NL,L)= d(V,NL)+ d(NL,L)* (1 + t) = d(V,L)* (1 + t), so this case holds. Consider the case when the pointer is pruned. We know from the if statement that d(V,NH )+d+(NH ,L)<d(V,L)* (1 + t). Since the new cost of the path is given by the left side of this inequality, the inductive step holds for this case as well. As mentioned, the stated pruning algorithm does not nec­essarily .nd an optimal set of paths in terms of size or length, but it avoids a non-deterministic search over a very large search space, and seems to work well in practice, as we demonstrate in the following section. 5.1 Evaluation We evaluate our tolerance scheme using the same test data as theprevious sections. Table5 shows the memory require­ments of 4 landmarks over the di.erent test graphs for vary­ing tolerances. Each value in the table is the amount of memory required by the partial landmarks divided by the amount of memory required for 4 full landmarks. We make two observations about this data. First, allow­ing a tolerance when pruning o.ers a further reduction in memory over pruning with no tolerance in most of the graphs, we were able to reduce the memory requirements of the graphs to less than 25% of their original memory de­mands. Secondly, we see that the numbers level o. as the tolerancebecomes bigger, thatis,we cannotarbitrarilydrive the memory requirements to zero by increasing the toler­ance. This is easily understood by recalling that our heuris­tic search does not backtrack, and therefore some landmark pointers are necessary in order to ensure the completeness of the algorithm. Figure 6 plots the accuracy of the queries vs. the per­centage of queries that fall within this accuracy, for several di.erent tolerances over several graphs. Figure 6: Path accuracy vs. landmark count and tolerance. The x-axis of these graphs is path accu­racy, while the y-axis is the percentage of queries that fall within this accuracy. 2 landmarks 0% tolerance 3 landmarks -1% tolerance Mandrill 51.8 42.9 Lena 19.9 25.0 Peppers 36.5 43.6 Terrain 30.8 38.6 Simple Maze 7.0 48.8 Complex Maze 45.3 55.8 Random-243 10.7 24.3 Random-729 8.0 13.9 Freeciv-1 13.6 16.3 Freeciv-2 9.1 13.3 Freeciv-3 10.9 13.7 Freeciv-4 15.1 21.5 Table 6: Comparing landmark reduction vs. subop­timal pathing for memory reduction. Each value is the number of queries that were within 1% of opti­mal. representsa tolerance, and eachpoint on the linegraphs the percentage of queries (y-axis) that fall within the speci.ed accuracy (x-axis). The results show that as the tolerance increases, the path accuracy decreases, but by the expected amount: the number of queries within 1% of optimal with a tolerance of 1% is roughly the same as the number of queries within 5% of optimal with a tolerance of 5%. This tolerance scheme is particularly advantageous when the number of landmarks placed in the graph is very small. Whena largenumberof landmarksispresent,abetter mem­ory reduction technique would simply be to remove a land­mark. However, we have found in our experiments that there is a minimum number of landmarks that should be used dropping below this number has a profound e.ect on path accuracy. To demonstrate this, Table 6 compares the per­centage of paths that fall within 1% of optimal, using (a) two landmarks, and a tolerance of 0% and (b) three land­marks, and a tolerance of 1%. The results show that under these conditions, the suboptimal pathsprovideabetter ap­proximation than removing a landmark in all but one case. Of course, these results do not suggest that the suboptimal pathing technique should always be used as a replacement to landmark reduction. Rather, the results demonstrate a memory reduction technique when the number of landmarks is too small to reduce any further. 6. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK We present a hybridization of heuristic search and LPI. LPI precomputes paths from landmarks to points in the graph; our extension compares the precomputed results with the predictions of a heuristic and stores only the landmark information where the heuristic and the landmark directions disagree. With a good heuristic, the amount of stored in­formation can be quite low. The algorithm is thus able to exploit the low-memory requirements of heuristic search to reduce the memory cost of LPI considerably, while the use of the landmarks permits the algorithm to operate e.ectively even with a poor heuristic. Further memory reduction is possible by allowing suboptimal paths from vertices to their landmarks, at the cost of path accuracy. Experiments show that this method is able to considerably reduce the mem­ory requirements of the LPI algorithm, while the accuracy of the solutions is preserved. Owing to the reduced memory requirements, the extended algorithm is therefore more prac­tical for use in games than was the original LPI. Although LPI produces only approximately shortest paths, in games, where constraints on computational resources are often se­vere, an approximate path returned quickly can be more useful than an optimal path returned much later. Note that the extended LPI algorithm produces slightlybetter approx­imations than did the original LPI. There are several avenues of future work for this approach. The algorithm is able to exploit heuristics that give path in­formation rather than distance information, something that standard heuristic searches (e.g., greedy, A*) are unable to do. We wish to explore this idea further by coming up with new heuristics of this type, and evaluating the performance of the algorithm after incorporating these heuristics. Be­cause only path information is stored and not full distance information, this algorithm may be amenable to local repair in a dynamic graph; dynamic graphs, common in games, have not been thoroughly treated by existing precomputa­tion algorithms for path planning. We see investigation of dynamic graphs as an important and fruitful future research area for approximate path planning. We also intend to continue developing the suboptimal pathing technique of Section 5. In particular, we will evalu­ate di.erent search strategies for .nding the smallest set of landmarkpointers that maintainabound on path accuracy. 7. REFERENCES [1] Freeciv. www.freeciv.org. [2] E. W. article_rec.title: An emergent framework for realistic psychosocial behaviour in non player characters

abstract.par: This paper introduces a framework for emergent psychosocial behaviour in non player characters in video games. This framework uses concepts behind emergent gameplay to support the mechanics of designer-defined psychological and social concepts, undefined circumstances, and emergence. Based on this framework, a prototype system has been developed. This prototype has been evaluated for realistic emergent behaviour, and has been shown through experimentation to succeed in supporting emergent psychosocial behaviour. The work to date on the framework is encouraging and quite promising for continued work in this area in the future.
