fulltext.ft_body: Understanding Game Design for Affective Learning Claire Dormann and Robert Biddle Human Oriented Technology Laboratory Carleton University Ottawa, Canada cdormann@connect.carleton.ca ABSTRACT A.ective learning is an important aspect of education that can be supported through games. This paper focuses on how games can and do address a.ective learning, especially in light of the growing trend of educational and serious games aiming at changing behavior and attitudes. To sup­port a.ective learning though games, player emotions need to be recognized and interpreted, and an emotional experi­ence needs to be created that motivates players and deep­ens learning. Moreover, there is also a need to understand a.ective representations and mechanisms that games sup­port. The paper begins with a presentation of the di.erent perspectives on a.ective learning, and then takes a focus on the socio-emotional component of the a.ective domain. An a.ective walkthrough technique is then introduced to understand and analyze a.ective strategies in games. This technique is then applied to the game Ico, showing its a.ec­tive strategies and how these strategies can be leveraged for designing socio-emotional learning. The paper is concluded with an outline of an approach to designing games especially for a.ective learning, by identifying the key principles, creat­ing a repertory of a.ective learning game patterns, and using methods to contextualize gameplay and facilitate learning. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [Personal Computing]: Games General Terms Design Keywords game design, a.ective development 1. INTRODUCTION The potential for computer games in learning has long been heralded. There are countless games where educational Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. objectives are in the foreground, and learning is the explicit goal of the game. There are also games where the edu­cational objectives are more indirect. For example, Where in the world is Carmen Sandiego taught simple geography whilst users were playing a mystery game [5]. Since that, the use of computer games for education has also increased drastically in a variety of contexts, in schools, universities, workplaces, hospital, and so on. Many studies have shown that playing with computer games can enhance visual pro­cessing skills, including visual attention, and the ability to manipulate objects or mental images through space [32, 7]. Especially with more complex games, such as Civiliza­tion1, players also learn to take in information from many sources and make decisions quickly. They discover strate­gies for overcoming obstacles, and construct understanding of complex systems through experimentation in natural and unobtrusive ways. Educational researchers and game theo­rists have well documented how games can provide higher levels of continuing motivation, improve practical reasoning skills, and complex problem solving or cognitive develop­ment in scienti.c/technical aspects [24]. These perspectives, however, relate principally to the cognitive side of learning and development. There is a growing trend of educational games aiming at changing behavior and attitudes: persuasive games, games for health, games for change. These games address emo­tional, social, or cultural issues. Role-playing simulation games have long been recognized as an e.ective means to achieve cognitive and a.ective objectives, for example in the history classroom. Through such games, players em­pathy with the characters and their situation increases, and the students interest in the subject is also enhanced. Rev­olution2 is a role-play game (RPG) based on the American Revolution, which o.ered a cast of characters that have dif­ferent perspectives. The game thus allows di.erent socio­cultural experiences based on the choice of character, such as an upper class lawyer or an African house slave. Other games help players to manage di.cult emotions and stress. Remission is a .rst-person-shooter type game that helps teenagers going through cancer3 . A 3D undersea ex­ploration adventure enables players to virtually swim with sea turtles and tropical .sh, as they hunt for a hidden trea­sure; this game has been shown to distract children su.ering from acute pain or undergoing painful operations4 . 1http://www.civilization.com/ 2http://www.educationarcade.org 3http://www.re-mission.net 4http://www.socialimpactgames.com Gameplay absorbs players intensely and utterly; it en­genders a deep sense of engagement, to the extent that player feels immersed in the mediated environment [16]. The pleasure involved in mastering the game environment arises through individual subjectivity and personal construction of meaning during gameplay would sustain a.ective learn­ing [26]. Through gameplay, players are exploring the game world, trying out new options, dealing with dilemmas, or trying out new roles and perceiving emotions through char­acters and their actions. Characters can even be specially developed to support social learning through interaction, and to enhance emotional involvement. Games have a com­pelling nature which is widely acknowledged. A.ective learn­ing through game should thus draw players into the game world through interactions and explorations, emotional in­volvement, and the excitement of meeting cognitive chal­lenges [31]. Learning in this way unites cognition, emotion, and action in productive and powerful ways. The qualities of the emerging experience compels players to further en­gagement until completion. A.ective learning is therefore an important aspect of ed­ucation that can be addressed through games. We are inter­ested in understanding how games can and do support af­fective learning and the acquisition of a.ective competencies for training, leisure and life-long learning. To best support a.ective learning though games, we need to recognize and interpret the player emotions, and create emotional experi­ence that motivates players and deepens learning. Moreover, we need to understand a.ective representations and mecha­nisms that games support. In this paper, our .rst step is to analyze in detail these a.ective strategies. After presenting the di.erent perspec­tives on a.ective learning, we focus on the socio-emotional component of the a.ective domain. In order to understand and analyze e.ectively a.ective strategies that might help us to understand and design for a.ective learning, we then describe how we took a technique from user interface evalua­tion called the cognitive walkthrough , and we adapted it as an a.ective walkthrough for analyzing and tracking a.ective development. We choose the game Ico [28] as a case study, as we believed that it had a very strong a.ective components involving social awareness, collaboration, and responsibility. We apply the a.ective walkthrough to Ico, showing its af­fective strategies and how these strategies can be leveraged for designing socio-emotional learning. We then identify dis­tinctive principles of games for a.ective design, and outline how the a.ective walkthrough will help us to create a reper­tory of a.ective learning game patterns to help designers to craft and assess their games in term of a.ective learning. Finally, we discuss how using games for a.ective learning can be supported in the real world context. 2. AFFECTIVE LEARNING A.ective learning has been described in di.erent ways, which can sometime create confusion as to what issues are being considered. The most limited perspective entails look­ing at how a.ect can support the learning process, while others take a more integrated approach between a.ect, cog­nition and learning, while yet others focus on a.ective edu­cation or a.ective development. A.ective learning represents an internalization of positive attitudes toward course content, subject matter or the in­structor [25]. A.ective learning activities are directed at coping with feelings that arise during learning, and that im­pact positively or negatively the learning process [29]. The a.ective dimensions of learning contribute to a positive ed­ucational experience. Fun and enjoyment are well known to be e.ective in children s development, both supporting and deepening learning, as well as facilitating engagement and motivation [4]. However, Dirkx [8] suggests that the role of emotions is much more than a motivational concern, and that the a.ec­tive dimension provides the foundation on which rest the practical, conceptual and imaginative modes of learning. Emotional experiences lend us the ability to better com­prehend and regulate our activities, to understand our mo­tivations, and how to ful.ll our needs [23]. Emotion plays an important role in decision-making, planning and action. Emotion s role in stimulating thought should be taken into consideration, as well as the in.uence of thought on af­fect. A.ective learning demands the integration of cogni­tive, emotional and aesthetic dimensions, all of them which are of interest in the learning process [14]. A.ective learning also involves the case where the learning concerns the a.ective domain. Ellis and Fouts [9] de.ned the a.ective domain as the area of education that focuses on the attitudinal/emotional development of students (p. 9). Krathwohl et al. [17] describe a.ective learning objectives as those which emphasize a feeling tone, an emotion, or a degree of acceptance or rejection (p. 7). A.ective reactions include feelings of con.dence, self-e.cacy, attitudes, prefer­ences, and dispositions which may be viewed as a speci.c type of learning outcome [13]. Martin and Reigeluth [19] identify six dimensions for a.ective learning: emotional, so­cial, aesthetic, moral, spiritual and motivational. Emotional development consists of understanding your own and others feelings and a.ective evaluations, learning to manage those feelings, and wanting to do so. Social development involves building codes of behavior and rationales for following them, including developing pro-social attitudes, often in relation to caring, justice and equality. Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) relates closely to the social-emotional development of Martin and Reigeluth, although it also involves some ele­ments of moral development. It is described [21] as: Self-awareness: identi.cation and recognition of one s own emotions, recognition of strengths in one s self and others, a sense of self-e.cacy, and self-con.dence. Self-management: impulse control, stress management, persistence, goal setting, and motivation. Social awareness: empathy, respect for others, and the ability to see di.erent perspectives of the same issue. Relationship skills: cooperation, willingness to seek and provide help, and communication. Responsible decision making: evaluation and re.ection and personal and ethical responsibility. Social and Emotional Learning has been mostly developed in programs and activities for teenagers; especially around prevention (e.g. alcohol abuse), health education or social skill enhancement5 . However, more interest in programs for adults is appearing in the context of life-long learning and 5For examples, see http://www.casel.org/. new literacy. For example, this would include programs to support adults engaged in self-directed learning using so­cial networks, and peer support groups for developing emo­tional competencies (e.g. for caring for older adults). In our paper, we address a.ective learning focusing on socio­emotional learning. 3. THE AFFECTIVE WALKTHROUGH The subject of a.ective learning was introduced above, and the goal now is to better understand how a.ective learn­ing can be supported in games. This section introduces a method to study a.ective learning in games, and then presents a case study where the method is applied to the game Ico. In order to study a.ective learning in games, we wished to adopt a method of inspecting the game and gameplay based on recognized principles, and allowing repeated observation and analysis. We therefore adapted a technique from user interface evaluation called the cognitive walkthough [30]. This method is normally utilized for assessing the usability of a software: assessing how easy the software is to use by intended users for some set of goals. However, its theoreti­cal foundation is the idea is that learning by exploration will facilitate skill acquisition. This leads to a distinctive char­acteristic of the cognitive walkthrough, as the creators make clear, the plan is: focus on just one attribute of usability, ease of learning . Applying the cognitive walkthrough in­volves an iterative process that resembles Norman s human action cycle , where the user in turn forms goals, executes some action, evaluates the e.ects of the action, and then re­peats [20]. In the cognitive walkthrough, the reviewer pro­ceeds in this way, and at the appropriate points, asks these questions [30]: 1. Will the user try to achieve the right e.ect? 2. Will the user notice that the correct action is available? 3. Will the user associate the correct action with the ef­fect trying to be achieved? 4. If the correct action is performed, will the user see that progress is being made toward solution of the task? The emphasis on exploration and learning is very suitable for our needs, so we have adapted the cognitive walkthrough to study a.ective learning, and refer to our adaptation as the a.ective walkthough . In adapting the walkthrough method and the 4 questions above, we do not change the cycle nor the questions completely, because a.ective learn­ing is not isolated from cognitive learning, but the two natu­rally occur together. In games especially, the nature of goals and play typically involves both a.ective and cognitive ele­ments. In role play games, for example, and other games de­picting worlds with interacting characters, a.ect is naturally involved as a way of organising, explaining, and motivating gameplay. The ludic economy of the game might involve non-a.ective metrics, such as money, possessions, or land, but even these are typically framed with an a.ective agenda; some games create metrics that directly address a.ect, such as happiness or friendship. For our a.ective walkthrough, therefore, we add and emphasise the a.ective learning ele­ments involved in the cycle of forming goals, taking action, and evaluating results. The procedure of the a.ective walkthrough is the same as that of a cognitive walkthrough. We follow the cycle, and so form goals, execute actions, evaluate the e.ects, and repeat. However, in forming goals, we consider a.ective issues; in executing actions we attempt to achieve the goals that re­late to a.ective issues; in evaluating we consider whether we have made relevant progress. And, perhaps most impor­tantly, we then re.ect on that interaction and re-form our goals. That iterative step of goal reformation is critical for learning, and in the original cognitive walkthrough supports an increase in understanding how the software works so de­veloping the user s mental model of the software. In the a.ective walkthrough the step allows for an a.ective les­son , whereby the user may gain understanding of the way that a.ective aspects of the game play out: this can lead to a.ective learning. As we have discussed in the sections above, a.ective learn­ing is a broad area and includes several kinds of issues. While it might make sense to consider all these kinds of issues in an a.ective walkthrough, we might also decide to focus on fewer kinds. In our work so far, we have concen­trated on socio-emotional learning. So in the walkthrough cycle, we focus on elements that relate to these issues. We take care to consider our emotions, those of ourself, of our avatar, and of other characters; the relationships depicted between characters, and the aesthetic issues that relate to these issues. We therefore ask: What might the player, their avatar, or other charac­ters, experience emotionally? What relationships are depicted or might emerge be­tween characters? What e.ect will the setting have on the player, their avatar, or other characters? The overall question for interpretation is: how would the a.ective experiences above in.uence the experience and goals in gameplay? To illustrate the process, and to demonstrate how a.ective learning can be supported by a game, we now show a sam­ple sequence of an a.ective walkthrough. In the items be­low, we describe the main gameplay and our notes on a.ect. As with a cognitive walkthrough, these notes emphasize the immediate experience during the walkthrough. Our more comprehensive interpretation of the a.ective lessons follows in the next major section of the paper. In this example, the notes and interpretation are our own, and thus re.ect our own feelings and our personal background in psychol­ogy, communications, and education. The same technique could be applied with more evaluators and a di.erent range of expertise. The method would remain one of inspection, however, and future work is necessary to establish links be­tween the in-game experience and a.ective learning resulting from gameplay. Ico was created for the Sony PlayStation 2, and was de­signed by Fumito Ueda [28]. We chose Ico because reviews highlighted the emotive character of the interactions6 . The game involves the player guiding the actions of a small boy, Ico, in an escape from a castle, and his interactions with Yorda, a girl he meets. The player guides Ico via a hand­held controller, and the results are depicted on screen, both directly, and in resulting cut-scenes. In our descriptions be­low, the use of the term we refers to the player, guiding 6http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/adventure/ico/ Ico. Unusually for this kind of game, the screen shows no abstract information in the form of numbers or meters: only the virtual world. We begin our walkthrough with two preview scenes, then continue with interactive play until the .rst save point. The .rst preview scene is shown when the game disk loads on the PlayStation; the second is shown when the player begins the game. Preview 1 Part 1 Action: Men on horseback carry a boy, (the game case notes name him, Ico, aged 12), with horns through a forest to a castle. A.ect: The forest is lush and pleasant with birdsong, but the men seem stern and resigned to their harsh duty. The boy s hands are bound, but he is brightly dressed and looks around with curios­ity. The castle is shown in an elevated position in bright sunshine. Preface 1 Part 2 Action: Scenes of the castle are shown, with the boy shown running through rooms and between build­ings, jumping and climbing ropes, sometimes a girl is also seen. A.ect: Wistful music plays, suggesting detachment. The scenes vary and change rapidly in a dream­like fashion. The movement of the boy suggests vigour and resourcefulness: hope. The girl is pale and ethereal, but noble in bearing, and Ico is sometimes shown posing as a heroic statue, sug­gesting a valour. Preview 2 Action: The men take the boy in a boat to a sub­terranean entrance, through caves and through a vault-like doorway. They enter a mausoleum; they put him inside a sarcophagus and leave. Af­ter the men leave, an earthquake shakes the castle causing the sarcophagus to fall and break, freeing Ico. A.ect: The entry to the castle suggests strength and cold, a formidable but apparently empty fortress: the emptiness making it more frightening. As they seal him in the sarcophagus, the men seem remorseful, and ask for him not to be angry, say­ing: this is for the good of the village. Room 1 Action: We explore the room and .nd no exits; we .nd a lever, pull it; it opens a door which we exit. A.ect: The preview suggests we are lucky to be alive and should escape; the room is grey and the wind noise suggests cold; no one seems alive in any other sarcophagus. Ico s bright clothing suggests hope; his movements suggests a child-like inde­fatigability and enthusiasm. Room 2 Action: The room has no doors, but does have a chain hanging from the ceiling and high open windows; we climb the chain, jump to a window, and exit. A.ect: The room is slightly warmer in colour from glowing torches, suggesting hope; we .nd we can climb the chain, giving us con.dence in our agility, and suggesting escape may indeed be possible. Room 3 Scene 1 Action: The room has a sealed door and two lad­ders: one ladder leads only to a shelf; the other to a spiral staircase ascending high to a dome; we climb the staircase and .nd a large cage with a girl (Yorda) inside; we .nd a lever, pull it; the cage is lowered to the ground and we follow. A.ect: The room is very tall, and bright light and movement is perceivable high up, which seems hopeful. When we ascend, we notice breaks in the staircase and windows, suggesting abandon­ment; see the cage with a shock: it is grey steel with spikes; a second shock is the girl inside, very pale, frail, tired, and dressed in white rags; Ico s experience in the sarcophagus suggests a.nity; he promises: I will get you down. Room 3 Scene 2 Action: The cage is suspended just out of reach; we climb the ladder to the shelf and jump on it, causing the cage to fall and break open; Yorda emerges, but a black creature, appears and carries her away and descends into a black pit; we take her by the hand and pull her away; she opens the main door to the room, and we exit together to the outside where they .nd the .rst save-point. A.ect: Yorda appears frail and move in a hesitant other-worldly way; she speaks an incomprehensi­ble language but seems interested in Ico (.gure 1); the black creature, a spectre, has glowing angry eyes, and moves in a jerky threatening manner; Yorda does not resist the spectre, but is willing to accept Ico s help in escaping the black pit (see .gure 2); she opens the main door with a spark of lightening suggesting magical power; Ico is awed and asks How did you do that? , but he must lead the way through, while she follows, suggest­ing trust and reliance on Ico. They climb to a door, and outside to welcome sunshine and a seat for two: Ico sits and Yorda joins him, suggesting a mutual commitment: this is the save point. 4. ANALYSING AFFECTIVE LEARNING In this section, we traverse our a.ective walkthrough to identify the a.ective lessons and the di.erent a.ective learn­ing modes involved. In particular, we discuss the game mechanisms and representations (e.g. actions, settings, char­acter designs, and so on) and how they supports a.ective mediation, and identify challenges to users expectations. We do not o.er a critique of Ico per se, but initiate re.ec­tion on existing a.ective strategies, and how they might be used and improved to sustain a.ective learning in serious games. Figure 1: Ico leads Yorda away from danger. Figure 2: Yorda moves to touch Ico, before being grabbed away by the spectre. 4.1 Emotional development During the gameplay, players will observe emotional prac­tices of the chracters, are led to recognize feelings regarding dilemmas, and are exposed to ways of resolving emotionally di.cult situations. This interplay comprises opportunities for a.ective learning, although caution remains necessary about the e.ect on the player. In particular, future work is necessary to explore whether there is transfer from the gameworld to player attitudes and behaviour beyond the gameworld, or whether the player learns only in the context of advancement within the ludic framework. The feelings that players initially get are partly triggered by the storyline (i.e. the preview), where they will learn about Ico and his fate. As described for room 1, the emo­tional aesthetics in this game are quite strong, through the setting (the space suggesting the castle size, the sarcophagi, and so on) and the character design. Ico appears as an active twelve year old, while Yorda appears as a frail girl of about .fteen. Visual appeal causes empathy, so similarly we re­act sympathetically to the boyish Ico and the fragile Yorda. When game characters are likable, players can decide to go to great lengths to rescue them, and to help them work out their problems. Moreover, players are quite inclined to learn skills that will help their characters. The crucial emotional point of the game is in room 3, when Ico has set the girl free from the cage, and defends her from attack: this sets the pattern for a large part of the game. The cage clearly cast Yorda as a victim, and her fragility implies her helplessness. Ico is puzzled and clearly identi.es the girl has a co-victim: he explains his fate and asks if hers was the same. One very poignant moment is when Ico is .rst holding the girl s hand. It adds a tactile and a multi-sensory dimension to the game that implies a relationship of trust, security and caring [6]. A.ective tension arises when the black spectres attempts to kidnap Yorda, requiring attention and action. Later on, an emotional dilemma occurs when Ico has to let go of Yorda and let the spectres grab her, with the risk that entails, in order to move boxes and trigger an escape route; of course he must rescue her at the last minute, but this requires interesting a.ective decision making. Surprisingly, the characters expressions of emotions are almost non-existent, they do not speci.cally express emo­tional reactions or interpersonal emotions. Only in the cage room, and much later on in the game when the girl trips, does Ico show concern. Yorda is dragged around in a very mechanical way without any reaction, she at time seems more a living key than a victim to be rescued. Based on our knowledge of heroic fantasy, we expected more empathy between Ico and Yorda, and the lack of emotional reactions diminishes the empathy that we felt toward the two charac­ters. Emotion research suggests that in ethically and chal­lenging situations (in which Ico .nds himself), one might need to take and the share emotion experiences vicariously to learn how to feel [15]. This engagement is often de.ned as empathy with the characters emotions and predicaments. Thus for a.ective learning, and in the representation of car­ing, the character emotions and reactions need to be made believable, so as to allow the players to become vicariously involved in the emotional dilemmas. By becoming engrossed in their character, a player s empathy with their avatar in­creases, also enhancing their vicarious experience of emo­tion, and their e.ectiveness in making value judgments [18]. 4.2 Social Development The acquisition and understanding of social skills for rela­tionships and collaborative work is an important dimension of a.ective learning. It relates to the identi.cation of use­ful social behavior, an awareness of social practices and the development of interpersonal skills. While part of gameplay is constructed through spatial navigation, the other is supported by the relation between the two characters, Ico and Yorda. Ico shows a concern for Yorda, and promises to set her free. Altruist help is an inter­esting component in the development of socially responsible action, and this social construction in the game was very innovative and interesting. After rescuing Yorda, Ico has to keep her with him helping her to overcome obstacles and stay free. Despite Yorda being older than Ico, this is a typ­ical relation of an older sibling caring for a younger one. A powerful pedagogical device for a.ective learning consists in letting stronger students teach more vulnerable and depen­dent one (e.g. imagine if Ico could simply show Yorda what to do). Another interesting feature of this game for a.ective learning is that, despite not understanding each other, Ico and Yorda still can act together and cooperate to escape, suggesting that some di.erences can be overcome. Caring, as a lived process of empathy and active solidar­ity, was also well instantiated in Ico. Caring is a crucial feature in resolving some types of a.ective learning prob­lems which involve conceptual and emotive understanding, positive attitudes, respect for others; and the willingness and skills to act to protect and enhance these feelings, val­ues and rights[10]. Most game development has a focus on attempting to create more graphics realism and better mo­tion representations. We therefore admire Ico, and advocate that, at least within certain game genres, adding a socio­emotional realism which is often sadly missing: we believe it would be crucial for a.ective learning. Embedding social practices such as greeting rituals, socio-cultural rules be­tween characters (e.g. respecting distance), as well as social models (e.g. models of a.nity) would sustain socialization, enculturation and social development. In addition to their socializing dimension, the capacity of games to symbolically generate roles makes them e.ective transmitters of society s values and attitudes. 4.3 Socio-Emotional Learning As we have just discussed, games o.er potential for af­fective learning, and Ico o.ers some interesting mechanisms and representations for socio-emotional learning. The player has, as in most games, a sense of self-e.cacy, and con.dence as they learn to solve spatial puzzles. Quite a few game ele­ments suggest social awareness and relationship skills (through caring and cooperation) that support responsible decision making (resolving emotional dilemmas). Moreover, the in­tegration of cognitive and a.ective strategies, solving spatial puzzles versus caring for the girl and destroying the curse, create a kind of tension in the game that enables the player to continue until resolution. Games, in opposition to other modes of electronic learning, are very good at persuading and encouraging players to complete the game, through for example the illusion of winability or prestige. Simulation games can integrate cognitive and a.ective learning, and help to address areas that are not tackled in traditional studies. Typically, learning relates mostly to cognitive do­mains over the importance of the a.ective competencies such as compassion, empathy, advocacy, commitment, optimism, respect, and self-con.dence. In particular, we believe that RPGs o.er special opportunities to craft social awareness and responsible decision making by giving the player the possibilities to explore di.erent perspectives through role­playing di.erent characters (e.g. both the bully and victim). Through games, we can build codes of behavior and ratio­nales for following them, including pro-social attitudes such as caring, and equality to .ght prejudice. 5. DISCUSSION We have introduced a.ective learning, and shown how it can be identi.ed and supported in existing computer games. We now turn to the broader issues of designing games to support a.ective learning. 5.1 The Role of Design The sections above show that there is some support for a.ective learning even in mass-market commercial games: in the case of Ico, we might even suggest that this support was involved in the critical and commercial success of game. However, we believe the critical next steps are to identify how games can be designed and created especially to sup­port a.ective learning, and to study the transfer of learning from gameplay to the world beyond. With this knowledge we could create games for use in educational contexts, and serious games for wider dissemination. Especially in the realm of serious games, there is already evidence of the need to better understand a.ective design. This is even true, for example, in some serious games that are speci.cally designed to change attitudes and promote ac­tion, such as Food Force7, and Darfur is Dying8 . Both these games are successful and designed with skill and care, and we o.er the following comments not as criticism, but rather to highlight alternative design possibilities. Food Force is a game by the United Nations World Food Programme, and their web site makes it clear that the goal is to educate about hunger. However, the gameplay does not actually in­volve or depict anyone su.ering from hunger. Instead, the gameplay emphasises logistical issues that emphasizes the skill and dedication required in famine relief. If there is any a.ective learning supported, it concerns social devel­opment among relief team members, rather than emotional or moral development relating to world hunger. Darfur is Dying also relates largely to hunger and health, but in the complex political military context of Darfur, western Sudan. The gameplay does depict and involve the victims, but the game is oddly cold from an a.ective point of view, despite the integration of calls to action within the game, where the player is encouraged to contact appropriate organizations. The initial mini-game about fetching water while under gun­.re includes sobering text messages about the dismal real­ity, but the participants on both sides are shown as smiling comical participants. The mini-game of village management is presented in a more abstract way involving an isometric map, where individuals and their health or emotions are not discernible at all: changes to water, food, health, and even attack are shown again simply as text messages. In considering game design for a.ective learning, we must remember that there is much relevant background relating to other media. For example, there is a long background in stories and images that use a.ect for better understand­ing of issues. More recently a language has emerged in .lm and television that has quickly become familiar: long shots, close-ups, soft focus, perspective, and so on: are all used to support a.ect and a.ective learning. Gameplay, however, introduces some novel capabilities that require our attention. For example, game engines involving logic and mathematics constrain action and outcomes, and therefore support cer­tain generated patterns of possibility. In discussing the topic of persuasion in games, Bogost draws attention to the role of this in design, calling it procedural rhetoric [3]. Moreover, the player interaction itself involves and indeed requires the player becoming responsible for making choices within the game. Aarseth calls this the ergodic aspect of gameplay [1], and emphasises the impact of engagement, work, and commitment on the player. These distinctive characteris­tics of games suggest there is much to be done in exploring design for a.ective learning. 5.2 Design Patterns One approach to assisting the design of games for a.ec­tive development would be to focus on elements in existing 7http://www.food-force.com/ 8http://www.darfurisdying.com/ games. In our walkthrough and interpretation of Ico, for ex­ample, we saw a number of recurring game design elements that supported a.ective learning. These design elements may also prove useful in other games. For this reason, we can document their nature and then explore them in di.er­ent contexts. This approach to design follows the example of Alexander in identifying and documenting design pat­terns , originally for the architecture of buildings and towns [2]. Alexander explains: As an element in the world, each pattern is a relationship between a certain context, a certain system of forces which occurs repeatedly in that context, and a certain spatial con.guration which allows these forces to resolve themselves. This approach has been successfully applied to software [12] and user interface [27] design. The idea is that the pattern documentation comprises the these elements: solution, problem, context, and frequently various forces involves, the consequences of using the pattern, as well as known examples of the pattern being used. Documenting all the patterns for game design for a.ective learning would take us beyond the scope of this paper, but we can give an example from Ico, and using the form that has become ac­cepted for software design patterns, for example a pattern for A.ective Gesture might be documented as follows: Problem: In the real world, it is sometimes necessary to cross barriers of personal space in order to help peo­ple who are unable to help themselves. Taking such steps must be done with great care, and has a distinct emotional impact on both people. Forces: The play actions in games are limited by the means of interaction, typically a keyboard, mouse, or hand­held game controller; the on-screen action is limited in detail by computational constraints. Moreover, ac­tions in games are typically avoided by players if they do not have any consequences in progressing the state of the game; alternatively they are automated and sim­ply become assumed by the player. Solution: Require the player the perform an action that mimics the real world action, and causes it to be dis­played in the game world, and keep it necessary as part of the gameplay. Example: In Ico, the boy wishes to help Yorda escape, yet she is frail, hesitant, and disoriented. In the real world, the appropriate action would be o.er one s hand, and lead her away from danger. To mimic this action, the player may use the game controller s right shoulder button, which is an action similar to actually taking someone s hand. Moreover, the gameplay sometimes requires letting go in order perform tasks that must be done alone, and Yorda s hand must therefore be taken again afterward. The overall e.ect is strikingly similar to helping a small child in the real world, requiring constant care and attention. 5.3 Contextualized Play While considering how a.ective learning strategies could work and be implemented in a game, we also have to con­sider the wider context of the game, and especially the need for debrie.ng and post-game experience. Educational and serious games are not usually designed in a vacuum, and they can be part of a curriculum or a training session. For example, one game might be to developed to foster socio­cultural skills that will be needed in a international setting; another example might be a game to address recurrent socio­emotional problems occurring in secondary schools. It is especially crucial to consider what happen after the game. The post-play analysis of events that occur in the game itself is an essential didactic practice that will sup­port a.ective learning [13]. It has been shown that discus­sions after gameplay allows students to formally integrate the events and issues that surround them in the game. Al­lowing players time to re.ect on their emotions, decisions and choices they made all helps them to analyze the situ­ation and put everything in perspective [22]. To stimulate even deeper re.ection, students can be asked, for example, to keep a journal of their game activities. This helps forge a fundamental link between game experience and learning, and also allows connections to be made between the game world and the real world. We can also relate the experience in gameplay to broader issues in the real world. For example, we could discuss Ico within a socio-emotional curriculum about caring (e.g. for a sick relative, the environment, and so on). We could ask students about the emotions provoked by the game, and how they might relate their experience to other situations, and even invite them to sketch appropriate gameplay. Frasca [11] makes a similar argument in the context of using The Sims for social problems, such as a living with an alcoholic mother. He points out that players, based on their personal experience, might want to adjust or re.ne some of the game representations or actions that they feel are not quite right. We thus might ask learner-players to develop alternative scenarios as skits, and then perform live role-play about issues that have arisen during gameplay. To deepen their experience, other activities can be also be initi­ated based on the gameplay. We can, for example, embrace the power of creativity, imagination and willingness of game players to become authors as demonstrated by the strength of participatory culture, (e.g. machinima, mod games, fan .ction). Students should be encouraged to further develop their ideas and understanding. We believe that even while we support a.ective learning within a game, further knowl­edge, and attitudes will be best reached in conjunction with a wider educational and societal context. 6. CONCLUSIONS This paper has addressed how computer games can sup­port a.ective learning. The paper began with an outline of what is meant by the term, and focused speci.cally on socio-emotional learning. The a.ective walkthrough was then introduced, a method for identifying a.ective learning during gameplay, and it was shown how the Sony PlaySta­tion game Ico supports a.ective learning. Some initial ob­servations from a walkthrough were presented, and a.ective lessons from deeper interpretation were suggested. Finally, a discussion was o.ered on how games could be speci.cally designed and used to support a.ective learning in the con­text of the real world. There is much work to be done in this area. In particular, the a.ective walkthrough can be used to study more games that already involve some a.ective learning, to identify and document recurring design patterns that emerge. These pat­terns then need to be studied to determine whether a.ective learning really does occur, and whether it transfers beyond the gameworld. If so, novel games could then be developed to use these patterns, and formative studies could be con­ducted to re.ne their design and assess their success, both in traditional educational contexts, and also in broader public gameplay through serious games. Computer games support all kinds of informal learning, and they support collaborative learning as designers and players converge. Serious games are now beginning to be­come a form of public interactive rhetoric. Better under­standing is needed about the ways in which a.ective learn­ing can be supported in order to use and develop a critical understanding of the a.ective nature of computer games. 7. article_rec.title: Collaboration in serious game development
article_rec.subtitle: a case study

abstract.par: This paper presents an ethnographic study of the development practices at a small but successful company that develops serious games for industry training. We concentrated on the day-to-day collaboration of the studio team responsible for the game content and software, and used qualitative research methods, including field observations, contextual interviews and conversation analysis. This paper reports our findings, emphasizing a holistic perspective encompassing social and technical factors influencing collaboration in serious game development. In particular, we report on how co-location and a positive social environment work together with the technical tools and infrastructure to provide an environment that facilitates full participation of professionals with differing disciplinary perspectives, and contributes to iterative development and refinement of the game.
