fulltext.ft_body: Urban Traf.c Simulation for Games A General Approach for Simulation of Urban Actors Michael Kutz University of Applied Sciences Bonn-Rhein-Sieg Department of Computer Science Grantham-Allee 20 53757 Sankt Augustin, Germany michael.kutz@fh-bonn-rhein-sieg.de ABSTRACT Many modern computer games take place in urban environ­ments. One important fact about such environments is that there are plenty of other people around who might react to whatever the user does. For example in the FIVIS project a bicycle simulator is developed that will serve (beside other applications) as an instrument for tra.c education which strongly requires other tra.c participants reacting to the users actions (see http://www.fivis.eu and [7]). This contribution describes our current work on a general approach for an interactive agent system for urban environ­ments. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.6.8 [Simulation and Modeling]: Types of Simulation Gaming, Visual; I.2.1 [Arti.cial Intelligence]: Applica­tions and Expert Systems Games, Cartography General Terms Algorithms, Human Factors Keywords Urban tra.c simulation, interactive simulation, microscopic tra.c simulation, agent-based simulation 1. INTRODUCTION The objective of the project is to create a module for urban virtual environments that gives the user a realistic impres­sion of urban tra.c. To do so typical participants of urban tra.c such as pedestrians, cars, trucks etc. need to be simulated in a way that their behavior makes a realistic im­pression to the user. Realistic behavior especially includes reacting to the actions of other participants and of course to those of the user. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. Prof. Dr. Rainer Herpers University of Applied Sciences Bonn-Rhein-Sieg Department of Computer Science Grantham-Allee 20 53757 Sankt Augustin, Germany rainer.herpers@fh-bonn-rhein-sieg.de 1.1 Motivation The FIVIS 1 project aims to create a comprehensive bi­ cycle simulation system consisting of two main components: a 6 degrees of freedom hydraulic platform with a bicycle mounted on top and equipped with several actuators and sensors (see [7]) and a three wall immersive virtual environ­ ment (see [2, 3]) which covers the visual .eld of the user sitting on the bicycle (see Figure 1). One of the applications for the bicycle simulation system developed in the FIVIS project is tra.c education of school students in a safe environment. For this application it is necessary to simulate realistic tra.c situations. Figure 1: Setup of the FIVIS bicycle simulator virtual environment. Another motivation is the application of the system in computer games. Players like to do whatever comes to their mind and some computer games already give them the op­portunity to do so. However, often non-player characters in such games can act confusingly unrealistic. For example, they keep using .xed traveling paths or they simply disap­pear after the user loses sight for a moment. The simulator described in this contribution will make it possible to avoid such irritating phenomena using a system of intelligent soft­ware agents. 1 FIVIS stands for the German project title F ahrrad­simulator in der I mmersiven V isualisierungsumgebung I mmersion Square translated bicycle simulator in the immersive visualization environment Immersion Square 1.2 State of the art Existing tra.c simulation models (e.g. [5, 8, 4]) are used today to predict daily tra.c situations and to optimize traf­.c networks, tra.c lights cycles or evacuation plans. Espe­cially the microscopic tra.c simulation (MTS) which sim­ulates tra.c as a set of individual agents is a good source of know-how as described in the following section. The FIVIS tra.c simulator has on the one hand some additional requirements to those of MTS systems but on the other hand it may also relax some, as described in the following subsection. 1.3 Requirements Compared to existing agent based tra.c simulation mod­els, a model created for games or a simulator has a di.erent scope. Since the objective is to give a realistic impression to the user, it is not necessary to calculate the behavior of every tra.c participant all the time, as done by MTS systems. For participants who are not in the user s .eld of view it is suf­.cient to know where they might appear in it. However for those participants who are in the users sight, a very precise calculation is required to meet the users expectations. Another important di.erence is the visualisation: MTS systems often o.er a two-dimensional bird s eye view of the scene but in virtual environments a detailed three-dimensional .rst person s perspective is necessary. For the FIVIS project, like in most games, both processes the tra.c simulation and the three-dimensional visualisation need to run on one machine. To have a .owing visualisation, the tra.c simu­lation has to calculate the behavior of all agents in sight of the user at the very least, 25 times per second, while leav­ing enough computational resources for the visualisation. So the simulator has to be much faster than most MTS systems with .xed time steps of about one second. 2. SIMULATION MODEL Since the simulation requires individualism of each tra.c participant, an agent-based approach appears best since it allows the modeling of each participant with his own behav­ior parameters. See [6, pp. 31] for further information. The logic of the tra.c simulator is divided into four lay­ers ordered by their required type of information. Higher layers get by with less dynamic information layer 3 uses only static information while layer 1 only uses dynamic in­formation. Layer 0 is special since it has impact on all other layers. Layer 3: Navigation The topmost layer s logic addresses the task of navigation through a tra.c network. In­cluding the choice of a target and the calculation of a good route to it. The implementation requires only knowledge about the overall structure of the tra.c net­work. Layer 2: Tra.c rules The tra.c rules layer adds consid­eration of rules such as right of way, lane changing, parking, etc. In contrast to the navigation layer it is necessary to be aware of other agents that for instance may have the right of way. Layer 1: Re.ex behavior In this layer behaviors of traf­.c participants which are not described in tra.c rules are implemented. For example a car might slow down as it approaches a red tra.c light even if it is still far away or if a pedestrian steps on the street with­out looking; a close-by car will perform an emergency break or try to dodge the obstacle. Layer 0: Individualization The last layer takes individ­ual parameters and characteristics of the participants into account. For instance varying of speed and track. This is just natural and should leave a lot better im­pression on the user since the participants will not move like put on rails. As described in section 1.3 there is no need to calculate the detailed behavior of tra.c participants who are currently not visible to the user. So these agents are only considered for the rather simple calculations of level 3 and disregarded in the more complex ones of the levels below. The more detailed information about an agent is needed, the deeper the calculation needs to be. 2.1 Representation of traf.c networks A simple logical representation for tra.c networks is a directed graph. The nodes of the graph represent branches and targets, while the edges represent direct connections. This representation is already su.cient for the route calcu­lation of layer 3 (see section 2). There is no need for prior knowledge of the road geometry to determine if it leads to a certain place. However, to calculate a good route which is as short as possible the true length of the edge is a valuable information. To make such calculations possible some additional information about the road is stored with the edge. Di.erent types of tra.c participants may be restricted to certain parts of the tra.c network. For example cars are not allowed to use sidewalks or bicycle paths while bicy­clists may use both roads and bicycle paths. The kind attribute of edges allows agents to check whether they may use an edge or not in a very fast and simple manner using binary disjunction: if the agent s and the edge s kind codes conjunction s result is non zero, the agent may use the edge (see Figure 2 for an example). Roads have the kind code 31 = 011111 so they may be used by cars 1 = 000001 or buses 2 = 000010 or trucks 4 = 000100 or motorcycles 8 = 001000 or bicycles 16 = 010000. But not by pedestrians 32 = 100000. Figure 2: Example for evaluating kind attributes of edges and agents with binary conjunction. While layer 3 gets by with the simple structure of the net­work, for layer 2, some more information is required: The agents need to know about lanes, tra.c signs, zebra cross­ings, tra.c lights etc. This information is packed into lane objects. An edge has at least one lane if it has more, agents may switch between them. Lanes also carry the geometric description of a road which is needed if agents want to cal­culate their exact position and direction. In Figure 3 an example for a tra.c network with the described data is given. The red dots represent branches Figure 3: Example of a tra.c network derived from a Google Maps satellite image showing a part of the city of Siegburg, Germany. while the blue dots targets (here only parking spaces). The black arrows are edges and the green polylines represent their lanes. For a better overview the example shows only some roads, ignoring sidewalks and zebra crossings which would be a network for pedestrians. The geometry of the lanes is described by a sequence of coordinates de.ning the polyline visible in the example .g­ure. Each coordinate is accompanied by a value de.ning the width of the road. Since it is almost always possible to use additional space apart from the road s borders which are de.ned by road marks, there are two more values de.ning this additional space to the left and to the right. Agents are allowed to use the space for double-lane change, passing maneuvers, or other exceptional cases. For pedestrians this tolerance may also include the whole street beside the side­walk so they can switch sides by running across the street. Tra.c signs, zebra crossings, tra.c lights etc. are stored as simple markers in the lane objects since there may be di.erent rules for di.erent lanes of the same road. The in­terpretation of the signs is done completely by the agents. This allows behaviors like ignoring or temper based inter­pretations of tra.c signs similar to real tra.c participant s behavior. 2.2 Traf.c participant agents All tra.c participants are represented by instances of the same class Agent . The class provides the functionality the agent needs to interpret the tra.c graph described in 2.1. One of these is choosing a target node which is appropri­ate for the agent and which is not too close to the current position. An agent switching from one parking space right to the next does not meet the users expectations, so agents always choose a target which is at least around one corner. Furthermore agents calculate a good (not necessarily an optimal) route using an A * algorithm (see [6, pp. 96]) and a schedule allowing to predict their arrival at any node on this route. This way it is possible to determine which agents are in the user s .eld of view and which are not. Several other methods of the common agent class are used to update the tra.c participants state for instance its current speed, acceleration or orientation. As explained in section 2.1 di.erent kinds of tra.c par­ ticipants are separated by the kind attribute. Certainly the kind attribute as a simple label is not enough to sep­arate driving behaviors of bicycles and trucks. The features needed for this are held in two separate components of the class explained in sections 2.2.1 and 2.2.2. These compo­nents in.uence the results of almost all common methods. 2.2.1 Mechanical features Mechanical features like weight, dimensions or maximum engine power are grouped by a component named Mechan­ical . It provides some methods calculating more abstract parameters needed to determine the agents behavior. For instance one method calculates the maximum possible ac­celeration. Another delivers the maximum speed that may be reached taking the current steering and the resulting cen­trifugal forces into account. In FIVIS the calculation of the features is forwarded to a physics engine, also used by the visualisation. Currently this is the PhysX engine by NVIDIA (see http://www. nvidia.com/object/nvidia_physx.html). 2.2.2 Human character The character of tra.c participants has a strong impact on their behavior. For instance, some people like to run across the street, while others will always prefer a zebra crossing or a pedestrian light even if it s ahead on the road. Some car drivers may keep a wide security distance, while others almost touch the bumper of the next one. These im­pacts of the human factor are addressed by a human com­ponent of the agents. A way to describe the human character commonly used by psychologists is the Big Five personality traits model (see [1]). These traits are Openness, Conscientiousness, Ex­traversion, Agreeableness and Neuroticism. Like most per­sonality tests the human component stores a score between -2 and +2 for each of them. In a future study we will research the impact of these fac­tors on the behavior in tra.c by a questionnaire. The results of this study will be used to calculate behavioral parameters such as the preferred speed, in dependence to factors like speed limits and curve radius, or the preferred gap to the tra.c participant ahead. 3. PRELIMINARY AND FUTURE WORK The tra.c network representing parts of the model (de­scribed in section 2.1) are already implemented in Python and a suitable XML .le format has been created. Agents are already capable of navigating through the traf­.c network on their own, including choosing an appropriate target node and calculation of a route with arrival time pre­dictions (described in section 2.2). However they do not regard their Human and Mechanical components which will be the next step in development. A preliminary visualisation has been built to examine the agents behavior while they are under development. Figure 4 shows its output for the network shown in Figure 3. The black arrows, red and blue dots have the same meaning as in Figure 3 while the gray faces are derived from the lanes geometrical description of the lane objects. Figure 4: Output of the preliminary visualisation for the tra.c network shown in Figure 3. This simple visualisation will be replaced with the .nal FIVIS simulation software developed in parallel. Figure 5 shows three screenshots showing a model of the city of Sieg­burg created during the project. The distortions of the top­most and the bottom image equalize the angles between the projection screens as used in FIVIS (see Figure 1). 4. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS The authors gratefully acknowledge the .nancial support of the BMBF-FH3 program Angewandte Forschung an Hoch­schulen im Verbund mit der Wirtschaft ; project FIVIS grant: 1736A05. Figure 5: Screenshot of a current version of the FIVIS simulation software, showing a virtual bi­ cycle in a sample city environment. 5. REFERENCES [1] L. R. Goldberg. article_rec.title: Scripted smarts in an intelligent virtual environment
article_rec.subtitle: behaviour definition using a simple entity annotation language

abstract.par: We present a Simple Entity Annotation Language (SEAL) for the definition of believably intelligent game character behaviour. The SEAL system provides mechanisms that allow entity behaviour definition through the creation of an annotated world. Thus, by combining rule-based systems with affordance theory, this C-like scripting language provides a unified approach to the definition of virtual entities as well as the "smart" objects that the entities can interact with in the virtual game world within one behaviour definition language for virtual entities.

fulltext.ft_body: Scripted Smarts in an Intelligent Virtual Environment Behaviour De.nition Using a Simple Entity Annotation Language EikeFalk Anderson Faculty of Engineering and Computing Coventry University eikea@siggraph.org ABSTRACT We present a Simple Entity Annotation Language (SEAL) for the de.nitionofbelievablyintelligent gamecharacterbe­haviour. The SEAL system provides mechanisms that allow entity behaviour de.nition through the creation of an anno­tated world. Thus, by combining rule-based systems with a.ordance theory, this C-like scripting language provides a uni.ed approach to the de.nition of virtual entities as well as the smart objects that the entities can interact with in the virtual game world within one behaviour de.nition language for virtual entities. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.1[ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE]: Applications and Expert Systems Games ;D.3.2[PROGRAMMING LAN-GUAGES]: LanguageClassi.cations Specialized applica­tion languages GeneralTerms Behaviour De.nition (Programming) Language Keywords Smart Terrain, Game AI 1. INTRODUCTION A recent trend in computer games is to make them exten­sible by allowing users to modify them to their needs, one of the main areas for doing sobeing the de.nition of game AI. Many new games achieve this through the use of more or less complex scripting systems that allow the game AI to be de.ned or extended. A type of scripting language which is domain speci.c to the creation of Non Player Charac­ter (NPC)intelligence is the Behaviour De.nition Language (BDL)[2]. Another emerging trend is the use of annotated environ­ments( SmartTerrain ) to simplify the simulation of intelli­gent gamecharacterbehaviour. If the virtualworldinwhich Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copyotherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. such an NPC exists holds all the information necessary for the NPC to interact with it, the NPC can be less complex which allows for the rapid development of game scenarios [5]. This use of annotated objects [7] to make up the vir­tual gameworldgreatly bene.ts the developmentprocess and also makes the NPC s AI highly extensible. In this paper we present a game-genre independent be­haviour de.nition language, exposing di.erent methods of behaviour de.nition, including the de.nition of virtual enti­ties as well as elements of their environment that they can interact with, through a uni.ed software interface for be­haviour de.nition. As a BDL coupled with the concept of Smart Terrain , our Simple Entity Annotation Language (SEAL) [3] presents what we believe to be a promising com­bination of NPCbehaviour de.nition techniques. 2. RELATEDWORK In computer game development, scripting languages are used within the games themselves (by embedding them in the games or game engines) or in the tools used for game development usually in situations where the use of an im­plementation language would be inappropriate [4]. Some developers use existing generic scripting systems or permutations of these systems to add scripting facilities to their games. Others employ proprietary purpose-built scripting languages that are dedicated to a single game or game engine. Robert Huebner s case study of how scripting support was implemented in the game Jedi Knight: Dark Forces detailsthedevelopmentprocessof suchaproprietary language for use by the designers of the game [11]. Whereas onlya fewyears ago the majorityof scripting so­lutions used in computer games were proprietary languages, the trend has now shifted towards the use of generic scripting solutionsofwhich somehavebeen designed explicitly for use in computer games. Thisbecomes evidentinarecent survey of scripting languages in computer games [9] which focuses on the languages Lua, Python, AngelScript and GameMon­key Script, all of which are embeddable languages that have been used in commercial games. This does not, however, mean that the development of proprietary scripting solu­tions should be avoided at all costs, as Wilcox notes that despite the e.ort and development overhead involved in the creation of a new scripting system you are not reinventing the wheel. You are creating a way to concisely express your thoughts in a new language [18]. There are some dedicated AI scripting systems that have been used in a number of games and animation systems. In most cases the scripting languages used by these systems havebeen highly specialised for speci.c genres of computer games or kinds ofbehaviour generatedbythe systems. More generic AI scripting systems for the de.nition of intelligent virtual entities use what we call behaviour de.nition lan­guages. 2.1 Behaviour De.nition Languages We de.ne the termbehaviour de.nition language tobea programming language used for the de.nition of game char­acter behaviour, often found in the form of programs run­ning on a virtual machine which interfaces with the charac­ter controls within a game engine. Thus the task of BDLs is to facilitate the application oriented creation of believable virtual entities that inhabit game worlds. While behaviour de.nition languages are domain speci.c to the creation of NPC intelligence, they are often more than just a Domain-Speci.c Language (DSL) [17] for game AI. Many behaviour de.nition languages maintain the .exibility of traditional programming languageswhile at the same time o.eringpow­erful AI functions and operators. 2.2 Entity Annotationfor NPC Behaviour De.nition The mechanism for creating annotated worlds that we re­fer to using the term Annotated Entities provides an in­direct approach to the creation of believable intelligent en­tities. Such intelligent entities that inhabit a virtual world do not have the knowledge that would enable them to inter­act with other objects of the world that canbe interacted with, but these objects themselves have the knowledge as to how other virtual entities can interact with them. These objects broadcast information about themselves (including the instructions on how to use them) to NPCs in their vicin­ity, which can then use this information for interaction with those objects, making the objects smart . NPCs only pas­sively interact with objects, meaning that e.ectively the ob­jects interact with themselves through the mediation of the entities that appear to use them. It ispossible to provide ex­tensive domain knowledge to NPCs by annotating not only objects but also the environment itself, literally using Smart Terrain , and passing information to the NPCs about the virtual world in which they exist. The idea of annotated environments is based on the theory of a.ordance (or a.ordance theory) [5] that was developed in the .elds of psychology and visual perception. A.or­dance theory states that the makeup and shape of objects contains suggestions about their usage. A.ordance itself is an abstract concept, the implementation of which is greatly simpli.ed by annotations that work like labels containing instructions which provide an explicit interpretation of af­fordances. Annotations have provenpopular for the animation of vir­tual actors in computer animation, facilitating animation selection [13], i.e. the choice of appropriate animation se­quences that .t the environment. Other uses of annotations include the storage of tactical information in the environ­ment for war games and military simulations [6]. Probably the most common form of annotations found in computer games a.ects behaviour selection, often in com­bination with animation selection [15]. Here the annotated objects actually have embedded instructions that are exe­cutedby the NPCs that attempt to use these objects. The interaction protocol employed to facilitate the com­munication between an NPC and a smart object needs to enable the object to advertise its features to the NPCs and then allowthe NPCstorequestfromtheobjectrelevant instructions (annotations) on its usage [14]. This communi­cationbetween annotated object and NPC can be achieved using techniques related to messaging [10]. 3. ASIMPLE ENTITY ANNOTATION LAN-GUAGE Our Simple EntityAnnotation Language (SEAL) is a new procedural scripting language for the de.nition ofbehaviour for virtual entities in computer games and the annotation of objects for use by these virtual entities. 3.1 The Syntax of SEAL The syntax and semantics of SEAL inherit much from the C [12] family of programming languages and as such, SEAL program source code largely resembles programs written in C/C++. SEAL does not support object orientation, making the structure of SEAL programs more closely resemble the programming language C than C++ [16]. A SEAL program is meant to encode a complete virtual entity and as such each program needs to declare itself as an entity in which the NPC s program is encapsulated. The identi.er used to name the entity is then used to mark the SEALprogram s entrypointfromwhich executionwill com­mence. We believe that this provides a more consistent ap­proach to de.ning the program entry point than found in C/C++ which use a function called main , as here there is no need to use reserved identi.ers. Apart from this, the syntax of SEAL is very similar to the syntax of the C/C++ programming languages. 3.1.1 A Data Type for Finite State Machines Finite State Machines (FSMs) provide a tried and tested mechanism whichhas proved suitable for manykinds of com­puter game AI which makes them by far the most used AI technology in modern computer games [1] as they allow for the simple de.nitionof deterministicbehaviour. For this the SEALspeci.cation provides a state datatype that allows the de.nition of state machines which can alsobe used to express the structure of hierarchical state machines [8], i.e. each state can also be a complete state machine. The state structure members can be of di.erent types: 1. A reference to an instance of another state machine structure (referenced through its identi.er). 2. An action (see below), i.e. a function in the host ap­plication. 3. A SEAL function (similar to a method in a class). 4. A labelled SEAL expression, addressable through its label. Independent of their actual types, these structure members will always be treated as states by the FSM. 3.1.2 Triggers and Event Based Programming in SEAL The language speci.cation includes an event data type to allow NPC programs to react to named events. The dec­laration of the event requires the de.nition of a SEAL in­struction list, i.e. an event handler that will be triggered once an event occurs. The current speci.cation of the language introduces a trigger operator for spawning events from within NPC pro­grams. Events that have been triggered in this way are spawned globally throughout the run-time environment un­less they are addressed directly towards a speci.c entity. 3.1.3 Mechanisms for Accessing the Host Applica­tion from SEAL NPC programs can be enabled to directly call functions that are de.ned within the run-time environment s host ap­plication. These functions within the host application are used to provide the virtual entities actual functionality, i.e. abilities for interaction with the virtual world. The neces­sary function bindings are created by using the SEAL data type action , which maps SEAL actions to these functions in the host application. Actions that execute functions in the host application are not the only mechanism by which NPC programs can in­teract with their host. Data in the host application can be bound to scalar variables in NPC programs by using the volatile variable attribute. 3.2 Entity Annotation with SEAL All of the entities in the game world, i.e. NPCs as well as inanimate objects that canbe interacted with, are de.ned as scripts. These are SEAL programs that are executed by a virtual machine (the system s run-time environment) which interfaces with the game engine that hosts the virtual world. The use of the SEAL system provides annotations of objects with an identical representation to that of knowl­edge encoded within an NPC s rules, i.e. within the same type of program and using the same scripting language. In SEAL the environment itself can be annotated using intan­gible objects, i.e. objects that are invisible and cannot be directly interacted with but which are located within the virtual world and thus accessible to NPCs. The system s interaction protocol needs to allow objects to advertise their capabilities, followedbyNPCs then initiating contactwith objects that they intend to use and the objects .nally providing access to the desired features by exposing the relevant procedures to the NPCs for execution. SEAL s interaction protocol for annotated entities is im­plemented through a combination of system events in the run-time environment and a set of data type quali.ers that arepartofthe languagespeci.cation, aswellas several stan­dard functions of the language. An annotated object is re­quired to advertise all of the functions that it provides for the use by other entities that share its virtual environment. In SEAL this is achieved through the use of the global type quali.er at the de.nition of functions, which then marks these functions as exported for use by other entities. NPCs are noti.ed about objects that export functions through a system event that the host application must de­.ne in the run-time environment through API calls. The event is triggered as soon as an annotated entity broadcasts its availability to the NPC. Once an NPC hasbeen noti.edof theavailabilityof anno­tated objects, it can then retrieve references to the object s exported functions that it requires to use by invoking the SEAL standard function getGlobal . 4. A SEAL EXAMPLE PROGRAM To demonstrate the usage of SEAL we can look at a typical scenario found in many computer games that includes the useofanobjectin the virtualworldby an NPC,fromwhich theworkingsof the system shouldbecome apparent. This scenario is a combat simulation where an NPC has been assigned a base defence role. The defences of this base include turret-like gun emplacements that are implemented as annotated entities and which can be manned by NPCs. The approachof an enemyis signalled to the NPC through an event enemy detected , for whichthe NPC has to provide an event handler. Assuming that the runtime-system event notifying NPCs about unmanned emplacements is named unused and associated with the noti.cation condition that the NPC ispositioned next to the gun-turret, the structure of a program describing a defender NPC could look as fol­lows in SEAL: entity defender { scalar manGun; scalar turret; scalar gunAvailable = 0; event unused { manGun = getGlobal("use"); if(manGun!=NULL) { turret=getEntity(manGun); gunAvailable = 1; trigger lock @ turret; } }; state fsm { patrolling() , NULL; defending() , patrolling(); fsm() , NULL; }; event enemy_detected { setstate fsm::defending; }; fsm::patrolling() { while(1) { /* execute patrolling behaviour */ ... } } fsm::defending { if(gunAvailable) /* if gun-turret available */ { manGun(); /* man gun turret */ trigger unlock @ turret; gunAvailable = 0; ... } else { /* execute default defence behaviour */ ... } } fsm::fsm() { setstate patrolling; } defender() { setstate fsm; } }; The above program shows the sections of the NPC be­haviour de.nition that are relevant to the use of annotated gun emplacement entities. If the enemy detected event is triggered, the defender NPC is set to execute the defending state. If an available gun emplacement has been found be­forehand, i.e. if the manGun variable hasbeen successfully mapped to the gun-turret s use function, the NPC will call the exported manGun function to use the gun emplace­ment. In this example, the script de.ning the gun-turret exports its use function for usebyother entities,which includes the declaration of an action .re that maps the function to .re the turret s gun and allows it to be .red from within the exported function, as shown below: entity turret { event lock { setSilent(); }; /* stop advertising */ event unlock { setBroadcast(); }; /* advertise */ ... global void use() { action .re(); /* action to .re the gun */ ... .re(); ... } ... turret() {} }; 5. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION Our Simple EntityAnnotation Language provides a frame­work for the de.nition of the behaviour of virtual entities and the annotation of objects in the virtual world. Our current system prototype provides a working mecha­nism and interaction protocol that allows entities to be an­notated and other entities to utilise these annotations (ex­ported functions). However, the speci.cation of SEAL does not include contingencies for synchronisation problems that may arise if several virtual machine processes attempt to simultaneously access the same annotated entity. The languages speci.cation also does not consider situ­ations in which an exported function attempts to change data in its parent process s memory(whilebeing executed from a di.erent process), which could seriously disrupt the working of the system if this occurred in combination with several processes accessing the exported function, as men­tioned above. Asolution to thesepotential problems could take the form of additional safety features thatwouldhavetobe builtinto the system s virtual machine, modi.cations to the language speci.cation ora combination thereof. This issue willhave to be addressed by future implementations of the system. 6. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The development of the BDL described in this paper was originally proposed as a list of desirable language features in a short paper published in the proceedings of zfxCON05 Conference [3]. The work presented here, describing the language, forms part of my PhD thesis, so .rst and foremost I would like to thank my supervisor, Prof. Peter Comninos for his help, encouragement and guidance. I also need to thank my friends and colleagues at the National Centre for Computer Animation (NCCA). 7. REFERENCES [1] E. F. Anderson. Playing Smart -Arti.cial Intelligence in Computer Games. fulltext.ft_body: Synthesizing Neural Networks for Learning in Games Robert G. Price, Scott D. Goodwin Centre for Interactive Digital Entertainment Research School of Computer Science, University of Windsor Windsor, Ontario, Canada +1 519 253-3000 x3774 {price9,sgoodwin}@uwindsor.ca ABSTRACT Many games have started to employ learning techniques to make them more realistic or interesting. Usually though, this learning is done before the game ships, and it cannot compensate for any exploits a character discovers. One reason for this is that game publishers do not want to risk having the non-player characters making odd decisions in games that learn. In this paper we propose an approach that can be used to quickly jump-start the learning process in a game that uses a neural network to learn. We create different environments that might occur in a game, analyse them and come up with a starting point that allows the agents to quickly be able to accomplish their goals, which in our case is navigating through a random board. Categories and Subject Descriptors F.1.1 [Theory of Computation]: Computation By Abstract Devices Self-modifying machines (e.g., neural networks). General Terms Algorithms, Design, Experimentation, Theory. Keywords rtNEAT, neural networks, learning, games. 1. INTRODUCTION Artificial neural networks generally fall into one of two categories: those that create a model by memorizing part of the data they learn from, and those that create a model by building an abstract representation of it. The first group is suitable for in­game learning since they are usually fast and efficient. The second group has been used in games, but not for in game learning, since they take a long time to learn. Instead they learned during a game s development and the model is queried after the game s release [1]. The purpose of this research is to determine if it is possible to combine neural networks from agents trained in different tasks to be able to solve new problems faster. This would allow a game to train agents to navigate different types of boards, analyse the layout of new random boards, and Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. then combine the neural networks from the trained agents in such a way that they will learn the task of navigating the new board faster than by using either of the other pre-trained agents. One challenge for AI is to create intelligent agents that can change their behaviour based on interactions with the environment. Video games can provide complex artificial environments, and with millions of people spending time playing them, machine learning can make video games more interesting. NERO (NeuroEvolving Robotic Operatives) is a game built on rtNEAT (Real-time NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies), where a player trains a team of virtual robots for combat against other players' teams. NERO is available for download at nerogame.org, and is still an active research project of the Neural Networks Group of the Department of Computer Science at the University of Texas at Austin [3]. NERO was used for our experiments since it provided a simple way to train agents with a learning algorithm on different boards, and view the neural networks created through the training. Traditional reinforcement learning (RL) techniques learn to predict the long-term reward for taking actions in different states by exploring the state space and keeping track of the results. In video games, there are several common demands that make them more difficult. These include: (from [6]) 1 A large state/action space. Since games usually have several different types of objects and characters and many different possible actions, the state/action space that RL must explore is extremely high dimensional. ... Action selection may thus incur a very large cost on the game engine, reducing the amount of computation available for the game itself. 2. Diverse behaviors. Agents learning simultaneously in a simulated world should not all converge to the same behavior: A homogeneous population would make the game boring. ... Without explicitly maintaining diversity, such an outcome is likely. 3. Consistent individual behaviors. RL depends on occasionally taking a random action in order to explore new behaviors. While this strategy works well in offline learning, players do not want to constantly see the same individual agent periodically making inexplicable and idiosyncratic moves relative to its usual policy. 4. Fast adaptation and sophisticated behaviors. Because players do not want to wait hours for agents to adapt, it may be necessary to use a simple representation that can be learned quickly. However, a simple representation would limit the ability to learn sophisticated behaviors. Thus there is a trade-off between learning simple behaviors quickly and learning sophisticated behaviors more slowly, neither of which is desirable. 5. Memory of past states. If agents remember past events, they can react more convincingly to the present situation. However, such memory requires keeping track of more than the current state, ruling out traditional Markovian methods. Neuroevolution (NE) (the artificial evolution of neural networks using an evolutionary algorithm), is an alternative RL technique that meets each of these demands naturally: (1) NE works well in high dimensional spaces. (2) Diverse populations can be explicitly maintained through speciation. (3) The behavior of an individual during its lifetime does not change because it always chooses actions from the same network. (4) A representation of the solution can be evolved, allowing simple practical behaviors to be discovered quickly in the beginning and complexified later. (5) Recurrent neural networks can be evolved that implement and utilize effective memory structures [6]. NERO uses NEAT, which evolves neural networks for reinforcement learning tasks using an evolutionary algorithm. NEAT starts with a simple artificial network and adds complexity only if it helps solve a problem. NEAT combines the usual search for the appropriate network weights with complexification of the network structure, allowing the behaviour of evolved neural networks to become increasingly sophisticated over generations. Real-time NEAT (rtNEAT) is able to complexify neural networks as the game is being played, making it possible for agents to evolve increasingly sophisticated behaviours in real time [6]. In NERO, the agents have a lifetime that is imposed on them. At the end of their lifetime, they are evaluated, and the least fit agents are immediately discarded and replaced by breeding two high­fitness agents. Mutations in NEAT can change both connection weights and network structures. The Real-Time NEAT algorithm (rtNEAT) evolves a small population in real time, rather than using the traditional notion of generations [6], [7]. Each brain controls an individual agent in the simulation. When the brain s evaluation time is up, its fitness is compared with other agents. Low scoring brains will be replaced with newer brains, which will be given a chance to compete in the environment. The rtNEAT algorithm first appeared in the NERO video game, in which simulated robots learn in real-time, responding to player interaction [3]. 2. EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE Keeping a game fun for the players so they continue to use the game is important for games with learning algorithms. Learning algorithms that are used in a game should not take too long to learn complex behaviours, or have several agents change their behaviour radically at the same time. The authors wanted to see if it would be possible to accelerate the learning process by starting the agents a neural network that would likely be useful for their task. The following steps were used to carry out our experiments. For the first step, two different groups of agents were trained to navigate through one of two separate types of game boards, described below. Once the agents were trained, a random board was created. This new board was analysed, and a new group of agents was created by combining the neural networks of the original agents. The newly-created neural network s weights were proportional to how similar the new board was to the training board. It was shown in [2] that an artificial neural network trained on a single, isolated very difficult task is unlikely to learn it well. In our experiments, a group of agents was trained to find their way through progressively harder mazes. An example of one of the mazes is shown in Figure 1. The agents that were presented the problem in stages learned their task much faster than the group that had to learn it all at once. Figure 1: A maze that the agents learned to navigate. The agents were given similar mazes of increasing difficultly to navigate once they could reliably find their way through one maze, a few more walls would be added and the process was repeated until the agents could navigate a fairly complex board. After the agents learned how to navigate a simple maze in this fashion, they were given other simple mazes to learn. The commonality among all of these simple mazes was the fact that whenever an agent encountered a wall, it would be able to reach the goal if it ran along the wall in the direction that was closer to the goal. A different group of agents learned how to navigate a complex mazes, in a manner that was similar to the simple mazes. The commonality among all of the complex mazes was that an agent would need to occasionally move in a direction that took it farther from the goal in order to eventually reach it. A "follow-a-wall" approach would be successful to make it to the goal. In both training cases, 30 agents were used on each board. The training was determined to be successful once 5 of the agents were simultaneously close to the flag. Once success was determined, the training was allowed to run for an additional 5 generations, to let the successful genes get passed to future generations. Once the different groups of agents were trained, new boards were generated. These boards had varying degrees of elements from the simple mazes and the complex mazes. Three groups of agents would be timed on finding their way through these new mazes: the agents trained on the simple mazes, the agents trained on the complex mazes, and the agents that were controlled by the new neural network created from both of the other agents. These new networks had weights that reflected the amount of features the new board had in common with the simple or complex mazes. 3. RESULTS It was noticed that in many instances the agents controlled by the newly created neural networks performed as well as or slightly better than either of the other groups, but in some instances it performed poorly. If the type of maze was very similar to one of the types of mazes that the agents were trained on (for example on a maze that was simple and mostly open), then the agents that started with the combined neural network performed about as well as the agent trained on that type of maze (the agents trained on simple mazes in this example). This was expected since when the two networks were combined, the weighting of network from the agents that trained on that type of maze would be very similar to the newly created network. 4. ANALYSIS In the cases where the agents that performed poorly, it appeared that it was due to noise from other concepts learned from the training. For example, the agents navigated the maze fairly well, but they also learned other concepts that hindered their progress, like following other agents. In some cases, one agent would pick the wrong path when navigating a maze and other agents nearby would all follow along the wrong path. When another group of agents were approaching the same spot later, if the first agent picked the right branch in the path, the others would all follow. This leads us to believe that if only the concepts needed to succeed in the task are used from the training nodes, it is more likely that better performance will be realized when those networks are combined to form a starting network in the new task. This might make it more difficult to come up with training cases, since an agent that learns a task may learn several concepts in the process, and it might not be necessarily easy to determine which concepts lead to the success. This could possibly be accomplished in a step after training, where the network gets simplified in several different ways re-evaluated to see if it still performs well, and only the smallest network that performs well is used. 5. FUTURE WORK Parts of this experiment seem promising, but to be useful in the game industry, more emphasis will be needed on the training the agents properly at the start. Any noise that might exist in a trained neural network could be moved into the newly synthesized neural network, causing some of the unrealistic, erratic behaviours that game publishers want to keep out of games. If the neural networks used contain only the connections needed to perform the task, networks that are created by combining them will be more likely to succeed at the task quickly, giving the appearance of intelligent behaviour. 6. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The first author is supported by a Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada Postgraduate Scholarship (NSERC PGS D). The second author is supported by NSERC Discovery Grant 122131-04. 7. REFERENCES [1] Baekkelund, Christian. A Brief Comparison of Machine Learning Methods, AI Game Programming Wisdom 3. Steve Rabin, ed., pp. 617-631, 2006. [2] Caruana, Rich. Multitask Learning, Machine Learning Vol. 28, pp. 41-75, 1997. [3] Nero 2.0 Official Site: http://nerogame.org/ viewed July 9, 2008. [4] Stanley, Kenneth O., Bobby D. Bryant, Igor Karpov, Risto Miikkulainen. Real-Time Evolution of Neural Networks in the NERO Video Game, Proceedings of the Twenty-First National Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Menlo Park, CA: AAAI Press, pp. 1671-1674, 2006. [5] Stanley, Kenneth O., Bobby D. Bryant, and Risto Miikkulainen. Evolving Neural Network Agents in the NERO Video Game, Proceedings of the IEEE 2005 Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Games. Piscataway, NJ: IEEE, pp. 182-189, 2005. [6] Stanley, Kenneth O., Bobby D. Bryant, and Risto Miikkulainen. Real-time Neuroevolution in the NERO Video Game, IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation, Vol. 9, number 6, pp 653-668, 2005. [7] Stanley, Kenneth O., and Risto Miikkulainen. Evolving Neural Networks through Augmenting Topologies, Evolutionary Computation, Vol. 10, No. 2, pp. 99-127, 2002.

article_rec.title: How to embed a game engineering course into a computer science curriculum

abstract.par: In recent years computer games have grown to the size of multimillion dollar projects that are driven by a creative vision of game design and include a vast spectrum of different fields of application. Due to these characteristics, a software engineering approach on game development is absolutely critical for project success nowadays. This consequently renders software engineering an integral part of any forward-looking game development curriculum. The paper at hand covers a kind of game engineering course that has been integrated into an existing computer science curriculum. In this paper, the course's concept and setting are discussed and the lessons learned are presented.

fulltext.ft_body: How to Embed a Game Engineering Course into a Computer Science Curriculum Daniel Volk Institute for Software Technology Universitaet der Bundeswehr Muenchen 85577 Neubiberg, Germany daniel.volk@unibw.de ABSTRACT In recent years computer games have grown to the size of multi­million dollar projects that are driven by a creative vision of game design and include a vast spectrum of different fields of application. Due to these characteristics, a software engineering approach on game development is absolutely critical for project success nowadays. This consequently renders software engineering an integral part of any forward-looking game development curriculum. The paper at hand covers a kind of game engineering course that has been integrated into an existing computer science curriculum. In this paper, the course s concept and setting are discussed and the lessons learned are presented. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.3.2 [Computers and Education]: Computer and Information Science Education Computer science education, Curriculum. Keywords Game Development Education, Computer Science Education, Curriculum, Game Engineering, Software Engineering 1. INTRODUCTION Nowadays, typical AAA game projects are developed within a two to three year timeframe by a huge interdisciplinary team and, as a result, consume several million USD per title. In addition to these remarkable project parameters, also pure game-related characteristics add even more complexity to these projects. Accordingly, the potential difficulties of game development (GD) can be traced to issues of both external and internal origin. The former are rather standard software engineering (SE) aspects as, e.g., the time-boxedness of the projects and their significant duration. The latter are raised as well by the creative nature of game projects (e.g., the typical focus on non-functional requirements [2]), as also by a wide range of used technologies. In summary, this means quite a challenge for an adequate GD education, but simultaneously also renders GD an interesting use case for SE courses per se [14]. This especially holds true when the great motivational factor of computer games is considered, Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. too, which often leads to a great benefit for the course s outcome [12]. However, an overly distinct emphasis on single SE aspects without transferring the course concept into the corresponding domain remains to be somewhat artificial and does not fully unfold the potential benefit in an educational scenario. Regarding this, the course at hand not just needed to be an extension of existing SE teaching (whereat the learning effects should be achieved by using a domain-specific SE approach), but also had to resemble an authentic GD setting to be able to build a believable context for its execution. 2. PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS For shaping out the course s concept the IGDA (International Game Developer Association) curriculum [8] and the actual computer science (CS) curriculum defined the starting point. The IGDA Curriculum Framework Within the mentioned framework, those areas of concern that appeared to match the envisioned concept best were listed as Game Programming and Game Production. Here, the first section focuses on traditional CS topics as, e.g., programming techniques and algorithmic design, the second section includes a mix of standard SE and project management (PM) aspects. Up to this point, the contents for the game engineering course were pretty conventional yet. This fact also showed in a first evaluation of corresponding literature around the course s core theme of SE and PM (see, e.g., [3] or [6]), which clearly tended to contain slightly adjusted standard knowledge, rather than game-only aspects. But, since the secondary goal also implied capturing the soul of game development , to be able to deliver an authentic setting, the question arose, which further topics to add to the agenda. At this, the additional stuff had to be chosen carefully to avoid unnecessary overhead for the course. However, these circumstances seemed somewhat similar to the question of how to set up a fresh GD curriculum per se. Regarding this, the corresponding literature [11] recommended using the Game Design-first approach. The existing CS Curriculum Within the current CS curriculum the game engineering course was planned to be the secluding course, which could draw upon (and should continue) the contents of two direct predecessors, which are outlined in the following: Programming Project (4th trimester) The aim of the programming project is to practice those aspects of a prior introduction to object-oriented programming (OOP) (including the paradigm, concepts and simple SE topics) that couldn t be realized by the help of associated exercises. It focuses on the organization of team work, a firsthand experience of object-oriented analysis, design and programming (OOA/D/P), simplified versions of development artifacts and the use of professional development tools. Introduction to SE (6th trimester) While the OOP course already introduced some essentials, this lecture gives a much more profound insight into the area of SE. It contains a detailed discussion of single development artifacts, gives an introduction into quality assurance and planning methodology and covers more sophisticated development processes. Hence, it obviously made sense to realize the game engineering course in terms of a direct evolution of the prior programming project, inheriting its modus operandi, but changing its focus regarding to the 6th trimester SE introduction. The Course Concept As a result of the prior stocktaking, the game engineering course was planned to be built around a game design nucleus, use common programming and SE techniques and mimic a typical game production setting. Since the game design and game production part were just included to a degree, necessary to sustain an authentic setting, potential overhead was minimized and a narrow focus for the course was provided. To be more specific: the course participants should be given a basic introduction into the area of game design, which would allow them to create a coherent game design document. In addition, the course should be structured, using current game development practice, whereby typical development roles should be taken over by students and faculty staff. Derived from the game development setting, the development process needed to follow evolutionary methodology, using prototype-oriented and code-centric development techniques. Anyhow, to guarantee a controlled course of development, the additional risk of the chosen process should be alleviated by the help of as well refactoring and redesigning techniques, as also the use of design pattern. Besides the already known OOA/D/P-cycle, the course should include a planning phase, focusing on cost and risk assessment. 3. EXECUTION Since the game engineering project was the last practical course in the curriculum, it was rather realized in form of a real project that presumed a high level of self-reliance on the side of the participating students. To be able to generate this kind of autonomy, it was necessary to make it their project, which assured a certain level of involvement [5], but also meant giving up some control. In this sense, the students were allowed to form their own teams and to realize their own game ideas. Also the way of doing things in terms of the prior learned OOA/D/P-cycle was left to the students to a certain degree. Supervision was handled in a flexible way (e.g., in terms of presentation appointments) and the course was given the prior mentioned game production setting both aspects clearly supported the intended game project feeling . Solely, the restriction to 2D games was mandatory, to avoid extensive time investments in the area of content production (a fact that is often underestimated [10]). The Personnel 20 students took part in the game engineering course whereat the resulting 4 project teams ranged from 3 to 6 members each. To fulfill the requirement of an authentic setting, the development roles of the former programming project had been adapted to a typical GD scenario. The student teams took over at least 3 important roles: that of developer producer, that of lead designer and that of lead engineer (also responsible for quality assurance). The faculty advisor was designated to take over the role of publisher producer. In addition, the role of a game consultant (a student tutor) had been included, to compensate issues regarding the game framework. The Technology Selecting the right technology for the course was not exactly an easy task since Java was made out by the curriculum and also not every type of game framework was compatible to the course concept. Complete game engines were to high-level, due to their too strong focus on the domain of game design and their too steep learning curve; libraries like LWJGL or JOGL also seemed to be impractical, because their low level of development would have moved the focus of the course towards single technical aspects. After evaluating the remaining small selection of mid-level candidates, Slick (http://slick.cokeandcode.com/) a selection of game libraries that is based on LWJGL was chosen. Since Slick is not an educational framework, it lacked extensive documentation. To alleviate this problem, a student tutor, who created a tutorial for the framework and was available to the project teams in his special role as game consultant, participated in the course. For version control and as the development environment, the already known tools SVN and Rational Systems Developer were used respectively. Organizational Issues The course had been temporally divided into 3 main parts: the pre-production (4 weeks), production (8 weeks) and post­production (2-3 days) phases, known from conventional GD. The first one included a concept (3x 1 week) and a planning phase (1 week); the second one mainly consisted of typical prototyping iterations (2x 4 weeks), but mainly ignored the less SE-centric full production phase due to its focus on content. To amplify the setting (on the PM level), an introductory lecture (covering the games market and industry) was given before pre-production and both a high concept pitch presentation and a marketing-centric end presentation were scheduled as starting point and endpoint respectively. To support the game development scenario on the engineering level, instructions on game design, suitable planning methods and adapted SE topics (+ the chosen game framework) were given before the actual sub-phases. The game engineering course was organized (on the PM level) by the help of a course homepage that included a hot news section, all organizational artifacts and a Google calendar for scheduling. The single game projects were documented (on the SE level) by the help of project homepages that included a current state section (change logs, presentation protocols and task lists) and a process section (all phase artifacts). Besides their homepages, every project team had to give weekly presentations (ca. 60-90minutes), which had the intention to pass the actual state of development and to discuss issues regarding the current phase. The latter part had no default form and effectively ranged from evaluating the game design in terms of story boards to doing code reviews of the actual implementation. In addition, all course participants received a weekly project newsletter containing helpful information. The Process Pre-Production Phase Since the time, necessary for a full-fledged game design lecture, was not available during the course, the game design introduction needed to concentrate on the basics. The rest had to be based on an iterative input during the concept phase. In this manner, the weekly presentations during this first phase were mostly used to discuss single aspects of the corresponding game scripts, which rendered the actual presentations more a kind of design workshops. This approach was nourished by the conviction that the students were already domain experts in the area of computer games. In fact, all of the participants were strong gamers and had a solid knowledge of game design aspects. The primary problem was just their lacking ability to articulate single aspects of game design and to write down the design in a structured way. The chosen pattern approach [4] provided a solution to this problem (using [1] as the fundament). In effect, this raised the demand for an easy-to-read textbook, which included as well a comprehensive introduction to the single aspects of game design, as also a consideration of typical genres, to close the gap towards the pattern discussion. After evaluating a bunch of possible candidates, [13] proved to be a suitable choice. The course started with a high concept presentation in the first week, whereby the teams initially presented three different game ideas. This avoided a premature decision for a possibly impractical game idea. After that, the concept got refined to a full-fledged game script in the following two weeks, using the presentations primarily to discuss the game documentation in terms of structure, typical patterns or comparable games. In general, we understood the game script as a living document that was never completed during development, but would be continued in later phases and changed on demand. The design documentation itself typically contained the initial game idea and its features as a core, game mechanics and the emerging gameplay (e.g., in form of value tables, calculation sheets, tech trees, or 60sec-of-gameplay descriptions), the setting and its narrative elements (e.g., in form of prose description, but also initial sketches and storyboarding elements), as also descriptions of the resulting game world and its interactivity (e.g., in form of first GUI or level/ map drafts). In the subsequent planning phase, first content and technical requirements were extracted from the prior user-centric features of the design script and were prioritized in terms of the game design. Since cost estimation was also understood as a clearly iterative procedure that just ends with project completion, this aspect was paid regard to by using an empirical form of estimation. This was done by the help of a relative estimation method (using a planning poker to alleviate the lacking experience of the course participants). In addition, also a simple form of risk assessment was done. After the requirements had been evaluated in the described way, vertical prototypes were defined by the help of two milestones for the production phase. The Process Production Phase Since the OOA/D/P-cycle already had been trained in the prior programming course, the teams were not given too many defaults for this phase, which corresponded to the intended higher level of autonomy. While the phase was intended to contain two pure technical prototyping iterations at first, the easier-than-thought content production (see section 4) allowed the second iteration to drift towards full production to a certain degree. However, the focus remained to be a technical one and was based on two essential starting points that mainly happened in parallel: on the one hand, lots of prototyping was done to try out the technical possibilities of the given framework and single aspects of gameplay. This kind of prototyping involved the creation of small throw-away prototypes that not necessarily had a high level of software quality and therefore weren t included in the final game software in their original form. On the other hand, the raw requirements, which had been extracted while the planning phase, have been refined to a domain model by the help of different analysis methods. Besides using the UML-compatible model­driven approach in form of broad context and 60sec-of­gameplay use cases or state charts (e.g., to clarify quest structure), also analysis by the help of less formal GUI-centric storyboarding and CRC card sessions was done. Together with requirements extraction in the pre-production phase, this part caused most friction within the process, due to the yet unfamiliar GD domain (see section 4). After a short intermezzo of planning refinement, both parts of this first step were then brought together within an object-oriented design. As well the domain models were transferred to the level of detail necessary for design (e.g., in form of class, activity and sequence diagrams), as also framework­knowledge (gained by the throw-away prototypes) was included in the model. Those two opposing termini were then merged by the help of an evolutionary prototype that covered the vertical slice of the corresponding milestone. Since the prototyping was done in an evolutionary manner, it was also necessary to include a continuous reworking, which was done in form of refactoring and applying design pattern [7]. In this way, the main prototype iterated step-by-step towards the final game, which also allowed trying out (and adapting) the envisioned game design on the fly. The Process Post-Production Phase To reflect completed projects and to learn from your own mistakes is one of the most important aspects of the engineering discipline. Due to that, an evaluation phase is an integral part of all of our engineering courses. In this case, the evaluation was done in form of Postmortems within the post-production phase. 4. POSTMORTEM (+) The Passion Factor The original idea, to handle the game engineering course more in form of real projects completely worked out. With the students having a reasonable degree of freedom while development and the projects resembling real game productions at a believable level of authenticity, most of the participating students were real passionate about their game. Personally, I have rarely experienced such a level of commitment to a course, which caused the students to bring in enormous time investments, other faculty staff were quite jealous of. The most important instrument for fostering this scenario was to mirror the students commitment by flexibility in handling, confidence in their abilities and personal involvement into the course. In this way, the modus of the course changed from control to direction and I partially felt more like a real producer than a course advisor. (+) Mission Accomplished With commitment being the driving factor of the game engineering course, implementing the course contents was more a kind of side effect, when compared to conventional courses. All project teams really lived their process (in general, I rarely get mailed project documentation at Sunday evening) to be able to get better results in return. Also, all game design scripts stated a clear vision of the game and playing their development roles was a matter of course for most students. In this context, I would argue that the clear and narrow focus of the learning targets was quite helpful here. (+) We had no Problems with that Content Although the course concept lacked a multidisciplinary approach, the part of content production that was necessary to allow a realistic gameplay experience appeared to be no problem to the project teams. On the one hand, this is clearly traceable to the focus on the prototyping part of the production phase, of course, which meant that simple mockups were actually sufficient to show the functioning of the technical aspects. On the other hand, the development teams were quite creative and provided more than plain mockups: the assets used ranged from simple 3D models (created with Blender) to SouthPark-style avatars (created by the help of free web-based tools) to semi-professional background music and illustrations from the role-playing community. Although this kind of content production was not originally intended, the restriction to 2D content obviously helped the teams not to overreach and is suggested for similar projects. (-) No Arties Far and Wide Despite the fact that the development teams had no problems creating the necessary content, the course concept would have gained greatly by a multidisciplinary approach. Computer game development is simply not a single-subject thing, but involves a wide range of disciplines. This typically raises issues of different terminology and ways of thinking and possibly adds challenges concerning distributed teams. But in any case, it enriches collaboration because of necessary discussions and compromises, which is a precious experience [5][9]. Therefore, I would classify this aspect (that has been intentionally neglected in this first iteration, because of complexity concerns) as the biggest drawback yet, which needs to be improved in future iterations of the course. (-) Those Reqs are No(n/t)-Functional As mentioned before, the transition between pre-production and production, as well as the analysis part within the prototyping iterations was not completely unproblematic. All of the project teams had a hard time, extracting technical requirements from the features within the game design script and formalizing those in terms of known object-oriented analysis techniques. While even current literature seems to pretty much lack any standardized method yet (see, e.g., the quite different approaches in [2] and [4]), the complexity of this aspect also had been underestimated in the concept yet. (-) Lost in Features / Feel the Crunch The students heavy commitment to the game engineering course also had its downside. Since the teams strongly identified with their projects, they also considerably tended towards overambitious planning. Although, this problem already became partially visible in the planning phase, the project teams were quite reluctant to cut out features, but subconsciously distorted their project plans instead. This implicated a run for features and a noticeable crunch time at the end of the course and resulted in the fact that none of projects was really completed (although, a first gameplay experience was tangible in every project). To mitigate this problem, the projects possibly need to be restricted externally in future. 5. CONCLUSION Being bound to a conventional CS curriculum for the game engineering course seemed to be quite a handicap at first, but as the course proved, an authentic setting that fosters commitment and makes students passionate of what they do is also possible within the frame of such a curriculum. At this, no extensive game­specific lectures were necessary to create a believable GD setting - instead, an introduction to game design showed to be the key to the game engineering course. In contrast, an already sound basic knowledge in the area of programming and SE seems to be necessary for this kind of course. This knowledge base was provided by the former lectures and a programming project as a direct predecessor. Without that experience, the course participants doubtlessly would have get bogged down in details and lost the sight for their game design. All in all, I would call the game engineering course a great success, whereby small adjustments in terms of the mentioned minor issues and the planned major enhancement of an interdisciplinary approach surely will make the course even better. 6.
