fulltext.ft_body: What You Can't See Is What You Don't Get: Paradigms of Game World Visualization Jaroslav velch Charles University in Prague Smetanovo nábre í 6 Praha 1, 101 00 +420 773988425 jsvelch@gmail.com ABSTRACT This paper tries to analyze the modes of visual representation in digital games and introduces the idea of illusionism, a rhetorical position in a game text that asserts that there is nothing more to the fictional game world than a player can see. This is contrasted by illustrationism, an approach that lays bare the fact that the game world is not shown in its entirety. Based on this distinction, I present ways of partial and multi-modal representation of game worlds that have been and can be used to bypass the urge for unconditional illusionism. The article also makes point about the power of written or spoken language as a code underutilized in contemporary digital games. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [Personal Computing]: General games. General Terms Design, Theory. Keywords illusion, illustration, graphics, realism, representation, game world, game design. 1.ILLUSION VERSUS ILLUSTRATION In the history of digital games, we have seen a wide array of methods used to convey the images of the game world. We saw the jumble of ASCII characters in Nethack, the surreal sidescrolling world of Mario, interactive fiction and illustrated adventures by Infocom, painterly backgrounds of the original Monkey Island, straight faux-3D corridors of the Wolfenstein bunkers, big pre-rendered chunks of fantasy land in Planescape: Torment, shifting perspectives of Star Trail and immersive 3D worlds of the likes of Oblivion. The differences between the visuals of these games involve not only quality, perspective and level of detail, but also the modality of representation of the game world. By modality we mean a way of correspondence between the fictional game world and its representation. This term is more commonly used in relation to real world [Kress and Van Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 08, November 3 5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. Leeuwen 1996], but we will try and extend the examination of modality to fictional worlds. In this paper, we cannot provide a theory of the ontology of a game world1. Our version of modality cannot therefore be based on comparing our perception of the fictional world to its representation because we can perceive the fictional world only through the representation but on the discursive strategy used in the game. We will focus on the visual representation, but we believe a similar approach could be applied to procedural representation (i.e. game mechanics as a signifying system). Some games tend to take a rhetorical position of identifying the (audio)visual representation of the game world with the game world itself, asserting that there is nothing more to the world than there is to be seen in the game nothing is left out of the representation. We can call this tendency illusionism. Illusionist games do not signal in any way that the fictional world should be richer than its representation. It is self-contained; we do not have to be concerned whether a fictional world exists independently of the game and what it really looks like. A player can bring with him a certain assumption of how such a world should work and look like, based on his experience with the world he lives in and a degree of similarity between these two worlds. The clash of the assumptions with the representation may breach the illusion, but not the fact that the game is illusionist. The other approach to visual representation might be dubbed illustrationism. In illustrationist games, we get signals that the representation is just a part or a version of what the actual fictional world is supposed to look like. The visuals are mere illustrations and the game admits that it does not show the player everything. One of the best examples of this approach is that of early illustrated text adventure games. In these, graphics served to the same purpose as illustrations in printed books do. They were hints for the player's imagination most of the world description was presented in the form of written text. This approach was, at the time, arguably better for conveying images of more complex worlds and more complex actions, because not all of them had to be seen; great part of them could be described using a different code written language which is much less demanding of both processing power and storage space. In other words, in this visualization paradigm, the world comes first and the graphics try to catch up . The original roguelike games like Nethack are even beyond illustrationism: in these, the ASCII characters are not representations of the game world characters in an iconic way 1 For a discussion of fictional worlds from an analytical philosophy/narrative theory point of view, see Dole el [1998]. they are simply indices, placeholders. They just show the spatial whereabouts of objects in a fantasy world we can only imagine. As I use it in this paper, the idea of illusionism is inspired by the Czech translation theoretician Jirí Levý's concept of illusionist translation, which is a translation that pretends not to be a translation, but a first-hand text, thus concealing modality markers , such as translator's notes and in-text explanations. We want to distinguish illusionism from the more content-based concept of realism. Illusionism, rather, points to an overall strategy of audiovisual representation. As it is a strategy, and not an inherent feature of the game as a finished product, it can be prominent, but it might not used exclusively games usually use both illusion and illustration. To sum up the methodological stance taken in this paper, we do not attempt to explain how a vision of a game world is constructed by the player. We are interested in the clues she is given. And although either of these rhetorical positions is formed during the production process, we are not investigating the production mechanisms, at least not in a great detail. Therefore, we might point out that both Super Mario Bros. [Nintendo 1984] and Quake [id Software 1996] are based on an illusionist strategy. In the diegetic part of their interface, they portray a self-contained fictional world, presumably as it is. The players can see all the information that is needed to make sense of the world. These games might look unrealistic, but they act as if their worlds were in fact defined by the limitations of the graphics. We have no clues telling us that the world of Mario might actually be three-dimensional, we do not tend to ask why there are no living humans in Quake. We do not have much space to imagine there being toilets in the world of Oblivion, although we might find their absence puzzling. These worlds are depicted as complete. On the other hand, we can easily imagine there being toilets in illustrated adventure games like Hobbit. Further expansions of game worlds may change this new versions of Mario might revisit the original world, adding visual detail, and shift the original game into being just a version rather than the defining version of the world. 2. ILLUSION MADE REAL In literature and film, each description or shot is suited to a certain narrative moment in terms of both form and content. A place in their fictional world need not exist before it is first introduced, which is usually when a character sets foot in there. In order to allow freedom of exploration, digital games however face a problem that non-interactive media do not: the game world has to exist objectively (as data) independently of the player s actions. Games are therefore usually spatial stories [Jenkins 2004] and that makes world-building a cornerstone of game design. The building has to be done more rigorously than in other media, with real-time visualisation and gameplay salience in mind. The major visual paradigm in contemporary digital games tends to be both realistic and illusionist. According to Kress and Van Leeuwen's social theory of the real , a realism is a set of shared assumptions about what is the right way of representing reality [1996]. They point out that the dominant standard of the day is photorealism. Digital games have their own visual realisms, but the features of the dominant one (evidenced in games like Crysis [Crytek 2008] or Bioshock [2K Interactive 2007]) do include illusionism and photorealism they show it all as it is and show it in all detail a human eye/camera can see . That means more data and more to visualize. In this paradigm, we have grown to expect that the world is represented on a consistent level of detail. A typical contemporary 3D game like The Witcher [CD Projekt 2007] tends to map the whole game world in a unified manner. Promotional and box art set aside, the visual information we get about the game world is based on a single, cohesive underlying structure. Cutscenes, conversations, and views from all possible angles are all rendered from a model of the world that is homogeneous and uses more or less a single, objective geometry2. Jesper Juul quotes a criticism by Frank Lantz: I think there is a widespread and largely unexamined belief in this community that computer games are evolving towards an infinitely detailed and utterly seamless simulation. That this is their destiny. [Juul 2007]. Quite often, illusionism falls into a trap. Not only are there many instances of clashes between the visuals and the game world it also limits the creativity in terms of game worlds. Let us take a look at an example of a clash that can break down the suspension of disbelief. In The Witcher, most of the narrative is revealed in dialogues with NPCs. The chemist in the alchemy workshop welcomes you while mixing substances to make an explosive, and asks you (or, the player character) to hold your breath, so that you do not interfere with the experiment. But while describing the delicate operation he was performing, his model is standing around with bare hands, seemingly engaged in a casual conversation. These two conflicting pieces of information raise an uncomfortable question: Why can't I see it if it obviously is happening in the reality of the game world ? This inconsistency in part stems from the fact that the game's graphics are in general very detailed (and realistic ), but in some parts altogether missing, which can in turn be explained by the separate production of dialog and animation. One suggestion of how to fix this inconsistency would be obviously to add the missing animation. Another one would be to leave the event out of the game, therefore limiting the game world to what may be visualized. I would like to bring up yet one more suggestion: the inconsistency can be resolved on a higher level abstraction3. It has been done many times before: the whole conversation could be represented without the animation itself, in a separate interface, and the incident could be described by a third-person narrator, saving money and labor. This is not to say that it is the best solution for this particular case, only to show one of the cases in which compromising visual illusionism might improve consistency and therefore suspend the disbelief. 3.A PIECE OF YOUR WORLD Many digital games tend to build on pre-existing or elaborately envisioned game worlds. The complexity of the worlds makes it tremendously difficult for the developers to represent the game world visually on a constant level of detail. We can envision two ways of dealing with this. The first one expects us to turn to the nature of metaphor. Metaphorical representation abstracts from what it represents and highlights certain features of a concept while leaving others in the background [Lakoff and Johnson 1980; Mukarovský 1978]. This is the process by which many of the game mechanics metaphors are constructed: some of the features have to be left out in order to 2 Until the release of Echochrome [Sony 2008], it was, for example, very rare to see a subjective kind of rendering that could capture the geometries of M. C. Escher s drawings. 3 This option is implied in Jesper Juul s discussion of levels of abstraction in regards to rules and fiction [Juul 2007]. fit a certain kind of human experience into a rule system. That is what can be done with game worlds too. Some parts of them can be left out or abstracted upon, because they are not important sites of gameplay. This leaves certain parts of the game world underspecified, which is a phenomenon investigated in literary theory by Roman Ingarden [1973]. Given the fact that much of their background graphics were hand­painted from a fixed point of view, early 1990's adventure games tended to concentrate action to specific, procedurally salient4 locations, while using specific devices to maintain the notion that the game world is bigger. Let us look at zooming out first. It is one of the filmic devices used to give an overview of a larger chunk of a fictional world and film has a long tradition of making people think that they saw what they actually did not. In The Secret Of Monkey Island [Lucasfilm 1990], for example, it would be unfeasible (and pointless) to draw the graphics of the whole game world on the same level of detail as the main locations have. That's where the bird-eye-view maps come in, on which the main character is represented by nothing more than a microscopic dot. When the "moving around" part is foregrounded and the "interaction with close surroundings" part is backgrounded in the gameplay, a change of perspective ensues. The game thus presents the player with two views of the world that are not based on the same underlying data. They should be cohesive but they do not form a continuum. Of course this means imposing a fixed perspective on the player, but we might argue that the change in gameplay does the same in terms of procedural representation. Another device could be called the synecdoche effect. A synecdoche is a representation of a whole by its part [Mikics 2007]. It came to be used with adventure games quite prominently. To give a fairly recent example, in the Abe Lincoln Must Die part of the Sam & Max episodic series, the title characters are able to enter the White House but the only room they can get into is the Oval Office. As they enter the White House, after a cut, they appear directly in this room. The Oval Office stands for the whole White House and it is the place the action is localized in. There need not be any explanations for that, as it has grown to be a cognition-based convention, not only in games, but all media. The resulting spatial inconsistency is allowed due to the fact the gameplay is localized to certain spots in the game world and there have to be no common laws of physics valid across the boundaries of the game locales. The rest of the White House is hinted at and the players are welcome to fill it in with their own knowledge or imagination. 4.MULTI-MODAL REPRESENTATION Of course, this disjointed spaciality is just one of the approaches to space to be used in digital games. Actual hands-on exploration of continuous spaces is focus of the games like Oblivion [Bethesda 2006] that advertise their seamlessness. They, naturally, foreground the spatiality and therefore cannot use the content reduction devices described above. No wonder that RPGs tend to be games with longest development cycles [Linda Currie, personal communication]. In the more space-conscious games of the yesteryear, spatiality is preserved at the expense of visual detail. The lack of visual information is then compensated by using multi-modal 4 Under procedural saliency, we understand a concentration of possible actions meaningful in the game, for example, a space with many objects to interact with. representation, or in other words, by augmentation with written language. Whereas language may be considered less evocative than visuals, it is an incredibly powerful medium, capable of not only compensating for missing visuals, but bringing in unique information as well, especially when used non-diegetically. Wizardry VII: Crusaders Of The Dark Savant [Sir-Tech 1992], a classic RPG game, uses a lot of written language by the virtue of being a fantasy role-playing simulation . The diegetic part of the game world display is only a basic rendering of the game map from the first-person point of view, made out of floor and wall tiles. It is rather a representation of the player's position in "the map" of the world in the indexical sense: it provides the structural backbone of the spatial experience. The fictional gameworld is distinguished and described in further detail in the third-person, non-diegetic "dungeon master" narrative: This way, a huge game and a detailed game world could be built with relatively low resources. Using non-diegetic third person narrative, you can even get a notion of what the environments smell like. This it not to say this illustrationist approach was common to all CRPGs of that time Lands Of Lore [Westwood Studios 1993], for example, went on to visualize as much as it could. In the next generation of Western CRPGs, there seemed to be diegetic turn resulting in a tendency to concentrate the writing into the dialogs. The late 1990's Infinity Engine games such as Baldur's Gate [Bioware 1998] and Planescape: Torment [Black Isle 1999] offered a pre-rendered environment in a fixed-angle top-down view. This constant zoom-out gave a good overview of the general situation, but left a lot of space for the player's imagination to fill in on the looks and gestures of the characters, as it could not capture minute details5. Planescape: Torment, widely considered to be one of the pinnacles of digital game storytelling, is a true multi-modal piece of medium, a very text­heavy RPG. The designers abused the Infinity Engine dialog box to include not only dialogs, but also memories, thoughts, object interaction and environment description. The world and the narrative are bursting out of the engine, because they were not designed according to its limitations. As we can see, this tension does not always have to result in a subpar game. In the illustrationist manner, the game world itself, in a 5 The relationship between abstraction and imagination is convincingly presented in Scott McClouds s Understanding Comics [McCloud 1993], which inspired the abstraction of language in The Sims [Maxis 2000], as Will Wright explains in [Perlin 2004]. way, existed prior to the game, as it is a licensed product. This rather odd game world often betrays similarities with human experience and is more easily imagined that visualized. The possibilities of written language were recently utilized in a part of the Reality 2.0 episode of the Sam & Max [Telltale 2007] series. At a certain point of the story, the game loses graphics, turns into an interactive fiction mode and at this point, the game protagonists can perform actions such as pick up respect for living things . Although used primarily for comic purposes (and succeeding), it is a very powerful demonstration of the power of written language in digital games. But overall, written text has disappeared from commercial games on most platforms excluding handhelds. It might be caused by the prevalence of the what-you-see-is-what-you-get kind of illusionism. But interestingly enough, we always see things we do not get. HUDs, guiding arrows and item highlights are quite common in contemporary games. Some of themshare the diegetic space of the interface and compromise the illusionism of the game as well it poses an intriguing question whether they construct a world in which items shimmer or whether they are pure gameplay signifiers, laid over the diegetic representation and independent of the game world, which is only up to players to resolve. Non­diegetic gameplay information and UI seems not to be at odds with illusionism, maybe because it is conventionally used to assist the gameplay, whereas usage of third-person narrative (and written language in general) is not. This resembles opinions of certain film theorists and critics who consider use of voice-over to mark an insufficient utilization of the medium [Henderson 1983]. 5. CONCLUSIONS Digital games have evolved into a predominantly (audio)visual medium. At the same time, they tend to be played out in the space of a fictional game world. The ever-evolving display technologies make it extremely time-consuming and expensive to construct game worlds that can be consistently visually represented in the state-of-the-art quality and a consistent level of detail. I have presented several ways that might help one profess unbound imagination and creativity in designing game worlds, unlimited by time or technology constraints. An argument was made that the tricks described above are perfectly natural and legitimate, are being used in other media and align with the nature of abstraction and metaphor, and that illusionism is just one possible way of world-to-visuals correspondence. All of these tricks have been used before the aim of this article is to remind, not to reveal, to think beyond the current visual paradigms and, maybe, turn T. S. Eliot's streets that follow like a tedious argument / of insidious intent [1936] into a possible game world. 6.REFERENCES [1] 2K Games. 2007. Bioshock (PC). [2] Bethesda Softworks. 2006. article_rec.title: A semantic model for reactive entities to support collaborative game design

abstract.par: Commercial games for learning purposes have been widely used with relative success. However, very often game content hardly fits to the curriculum content, players lack direct communication, and the focus is only on learning by playing. In this paper we argue that a more interesting approach for learning is to involve players in the design process of the game in a way in which the rules governing the game, the participating virtual entities and the design of the game environment are defined and created by the players themselves. In this respect, keeping in mind that learning environments need to be spaces for discussion, experimentation and reflection, we discuss in this paper one of the many issues that have to be addressed to provide tools for learners to create in a collaborative way their own games. Particularly, we discuss how reactive entities that respond to events that are defined during the creation process can be modeled in a collaborative way. We propose a conceptual model for supporting such a tool for the creation of interactive and reactive environments.

fulltext.ft_body: A Semantic Model for Reactive Entities to Support Collaborative Game Design Alejandro Catalá Javier Jaen Polytechnic University of Valencia Polytechnic University of Valencia Camino de Vera s/n Camino de Vera s/n 46022 Valencia 46022 Valencia +34963877007 +34963877007 alcabo@fiv.upv.es fjaen@dsic.upv.es ABSTRACT Commercial games for learning purposes have been widely used with relative success. However, very often game content hardly fits to the curriculum content, players lack direct communication, and the focus is only on learning by playing. In this paper we argue that a more interesting approach for learning is to involve players in the design process of the game in a way in which the rules governing the game, the participating virtual entities and the design of the game environment are defined and created by the players themselves. In this respect, keeping in mind that learning environments need to be spaces for discussion, experimentation and reflection, we discuss in this paper one of the many issues that have to be addressed to provide tools for learners to create in a collaborative way their own games. Particularly, we discuss how reactive entities that respond to events that are defined during the creation process can be modeled in a collaborative way. We propose a conceptual model for supporting such a tool for the creation of interactive and reactive environments. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.6.5 [Simulation and Modeling]: Model Development. K.3.1 [Computers and Education]: Computer uses in Education Collaborative Learning, Computer-managed instruction. General Terms Design, Experimentation, Human Factors. Keywords Serious Games Design, Education, Learning, Semantic Events. 1. ITRODUCTIO Games may either be played casually or seriously. When played casually people look for having fun or just having a good time. This has been the most common primary objective and motivation for playing games. However, the concept of Serious Games is strongly emerging in recent years. A game being played seriously is not being played primarily for amusement but instead for Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. training, learning, education, etc. They try to benefit from the power of fun provided by regular games in order to engage users in the activities that must be performed, to convey new knowledge or develop new specific skills. Although many different learning styles or theories have been traditionally used in games in the past, it seems clear that several flavours of constructivism have widely influenced game design over the years and the subsequent social and psychological studies. The basic idea of constructivism is learning by doing since individuals require to act in order to know as a consequence of knowledge not being a mere copy of reality but an internalization of the idea transformed when understood. Therefore essential aspects to reinforce and guide the learning processes are the experimental practice and the reflection on such a practice. McFarlane et. al reported on the educational use of games at school[6]. Authors made an experimental evaluation of commercial video games at school settings according to an evaluation framework which they developed. They divided into three categories the learning type supported by games. The first category is characterized by learning as a result of tasks stimulated by the content of the games; the second one consits of knowledge developed through the content of the game, although in general content does not fit to curriculum content very well; the third one is about learning which develops skills as a result of playing the game. Some of these skills are essential to the context of the autonomous learner such as problem solving, sequencing, deductive reasoning and memorization, and others arise as a consequence of working in groups on tasks such as peer tutoring, co-operation and collaboration, co-learning, negotiating skills and group decision. Gros in [3] also discusses the use of video games as educational material in such a way that teachers create learning environments that permit the possibility of dealing with a complex system which is multidimensional, multimedia and interactive. The inclusion of the game in the classroom allows the entire group of students to work cooperatively and in discussion groups that should provide space for analysis and critical reflection of the medium itself. They focus on similar issues such as the ones reported in [6], and use a four-staged methodology composed of: experimentation, reflection, activity, and discussion. In the stage of experimentation students are asked to take notes of the decisions and results while playing. In the reflection, at the end of the sessions the results and strategies are compared among participants. In the stage of activity, specific curricular activities are designed for the game, and in the stage of discussion the reflection on the actual process of learning and the joint discussion related to the proposed activities are performed. The most extended conclusion is that games are effective teaching and training devices because they are highly motivating and may communicate very efficiently the concepts and facts of many subjects. However some difficulties are also found. In general, commercial video games are used in these studies resulting in game content hardly fitting to the curriculum content and without any chance to be modified because software is sold as is. The gaming activity must be strictly planned to accommodate the limited available time and to focus on the part of the game that best fits for the purpose of the gaming session. Evaluated games are often for two players, and in spite of availability of online communications for the multiplayer ones, there is a lack of direct communication and so the discussion and reflection is postponed to the end of the session. Additionally, the exercises proposed are not related to the game itself but with ordinary tasks of practice with the exception that in this time they are based on the content of the game. An obvious alternative would be to design specific video games that fit to curriculum content, but it is very expensive and not feasible. Similarly, ordinary educational software could be a solution but this usually falls into a clearly instruction based design, leaving out the natural good features of game design. In our opinion, future gaming platforms supporting learning activities should provide pre-set scenarios easily editable by teachers to adapt them to the curriculum content, and a space for experimentation, discussion and reflection for both teachers and learners. Therefore, future research on serious games for learning should not be focused on producing games whose content fits to all possible educational topics and learning styles but instead on giving teachers and learners the tools to produce themselves games that provide best fitting, paying attention to overcome the problems that were stated above. In fact, this is not a revolutionary idea because Abt in the late 60 s already though of considering the process of building a game as an important activity for learning. In [1] he remarked that the first phase of game learning, the design and preparation stage, may be divided into two kinds of activities: a relatively passive preparation for active game, and the actual design of the game to be played . The former is more common and implies learning the background of the material to be simulated in the game, its rules, roles, concepts, etc. The latter is probably a more rewarding way of game preparation. The game designer is actually inventing a simulation model of the process to be played. In the course of doing so, the student must identify the significant variables involved, the relationships among them, and the dynamics of the interaction. To do this successfully it requires understanding the process to be simulated. Therefore involving the students in this process expands their knowledge, learning not just factual content but also the processes and interactions involved. A direct consequence from Abt s work is that the focus is not on what can be learned by playing games but what is learned by playing to build games, and at last playing them. Consequently, a first step towards supporting these future learning environments is to meet, to a large extent, the pedagogical principles on games in a clear way and, accordingly, to give a tool that, on the one hand, allows teachers to design basic learning scenarios according to curriculum objectives and skills in which they are interested and, on the other hand, both teachers and learners have the ability to collaboratively build common playing worlds consisting of interactive entities supporting actions and being able to exhibit reactive behavior. Because a reactive and event based conception is a general framework that people easily understand in terms of action-reaction and cause-effect relationships, such a tool would provide a suitable space for experimenting, reflecting, and discussing in both game creation and playing processes. We are particularly interested in exploring the possibilities offered by augmented tabletop surfaces as a suitable platform to support this type of learning which we begin to explore in this paper. The goal of this paper is to propose a new conceptual model to facilitate such a tool supporting the creation of interactive and reactive environments as well as the generic event subsystem that makes possible their execution. In the remaining of the paper, we present the basic model for authoring reactive entities and events in the ecosystem, and finally, we present some conclusions and the main direction for our future work. 2. A MODEL FOR AUTHORIG REACTIVE EVET BASED ETITIES 2.1 Basic Reactive Entities As many other matters concerning scholar education, the teacher is responsible for making up consistent learning scenarios that meet the concepts to be communicated and the skills to be developed. After that, the teacher has to present to the students the basic environment and the tasks they must address through the definition of some actors acting within such a scenario. To some extent, the fact of taking an approach focused on reactive entities and the idea of considering the design stage as an important and a more rewarding stage for learning already give some directions on what kind of learning activities may take place. A reactive environment, so called ecosystem, is the place where several entities inhabit, interacting with each other, and performing their actions in order to achieve their objectives. The teacher tells the students what tasks they have to accomplish and each of them is responsible for designing a specific entity in the ecosystem. These entities are special in the sense of being first­order citizens because they represent the embodiment of the role that students must assume and the entities allow them to manipulate the environment too. Ordinary entities, or at least more modest ones, such as objects, props, or those which are not under the responsibility of students are important since they are needed to build sensible scenarios and because they may also present reactive behaviour. Figure 1 shows a part of our model as a UML class diagram for authoring reactive entities that captures these requirements and the most relevant attributes and methods. The class EntityType supports the definition of reactive entities and it is the most important class of this part. Each EntityType consists of a set of properties, a set of actions, and at last, a set of reactive rules that effectively express the necessary behaviour to define the reaction that entities must exhibit. To differentiate ordinary from actor entity definitions we specialize this concept in the class ActorType. Figure 1. UML class diagram for entity type definitions Properties are like qualities or attributes that entities have. They have a name and a type, which can either be an entity type or a primitive data type. For this reason, and since we are modeling types, we also provide the class PrimitiveType to support the non­entity basic predefined types, and the class MetaType that generalizes both sort of types. Actions can be understood as the active behaviour that entities may exhibit. So, an action is like an operation that the entity can perform. The class action has a name and an ordered set of parameters. Moreover, a parameter is characterized by a type from the ones being defined. Beyond the action definition, we need to provide a mechanism that allows the specification of what it actually does, and for this purpose a range of different specification languages such a graphical or scripting languages or just a custom third-party library that provides the implementation could be adopted. We abstract this requirement in our model with the class ActionImplementor. Actions can be invoked in three different ways: from another action, from a rule, or, even by participants through their actor entities. It must be pointed out that the latter allows participants to manipulate entities under their responsibility at the moment of playing. Rules cover the reactive behaviour that entities may exhibit. At the moment, we have considered the use of rules similar to Event­Condition-Action (ECA) rules. A BehaviourRule is composed of an antecedent and a consequent. The antecedent is a general condition that includes a description of an event and conditions over its parameters. The consequent is a description of an invocation of an action. By adopting a reactive environment and the introduction of the design stage as another important activity besides just playing, some of the Gee s principles [2] are inherently present, especially those related to the categorized as Empowered learners and Understanding , whereas the occurrence of other principles depends on how teachers design the activities, scenarios and tasks to be performed. The teacher, by assigning to the students the responsibility of creating reactive entities, defining their properties, actions, and rules, forces them to study the curriculum contents related to the proposed scenario in order to perform well. Moreover, in this manner, the Co-design principle is addressed since students are also designing the interactivity and the reactions which will guide the evolution of the ecosystem. Similarly, the Identity principle is covered twofold. Students have to learn the role of the entity by designing it and by playing its role too. Entities can be seen as single components that can only be fully realized as a part of a more complex system where everything adopts a meaning, as the System thinking principle describe. In our case, the complex system is the ecosystem, and this is, at the same time, correlated to some actual reality that the teacher has decided to involve in the scenario. In this sense, the prepared scenario is a simplified model of the reality, and when playing, the consequences are simulated at a low risk, supporting in this way Gee s Fish tanks and Sandboxes principles. 2.2 Events and Reactions Until now we have not talked in detail about rules and events. We proceed to describe the part of our model related to events and the behaviour rules in this subsection (see Figure 2). Events are an essential part of a reactive system because they convey the relevant changes in the state of entities. In particular, events are raised by actions when executed. In our model, the class EventType allows the definition of event types, and an event type has a name and an ordered set of parameters. As said above, a behaviour rule is composed of an antecedent and a consequent. Particularly, the antecedent is what we have called an event pattern. An event pattern is a flexible construction used to specify generic event occurrences. An event pattern has an event type and an ordered set of arguments. The event type limits the possible actual arguments to comply with its parameter definition, i.e., the type of each argument and its valid position in the list of arguments. An argument, or actual parameter, is either an instantiated parameter or a variable. An instantiated parameter has a reference to an entity or a value of a primitive type. A variable is like a wild card that takes value at the moment of matching an event occurrence to the event pattern. Additionally, we can express conditions over arguments. On the other hand, the consequent is an action pattern. An action pattern is similar to an event pattern, but it is about an action to be taken in case the antecedent is satisfied by an event occurrence. The variables involved in the consequent have to appear in the event pattern of the antecedent so that the values taken by the variables on the antecedent are propagated to the corresponding consequent variables. Different people perceive reality in a different way, and consequently people think and learn in a different way too. Individuals, as well as entities, have a subjective point of view, and, as a result, they internalize observed concepts in terms of other previously experienced ones. This leads to everyone to build its knowledge meshes according to own experiences and thoughts, as the Meaning as action image principle states. This means that we need to support a subjective definition of events happening in the ecosystem and the possibility for defining them in terms of other events for which we already know their exact meaning. We also consider this in our model by allowing the definition of equivalent relationships among event types. The class EntityType has a set of mappings between event types. The class EventTypeMapping establishes two event types as equivalent, and the class ParameterMapping refines the conversion among their parameters. The establishment of this kind of relationships is very important because participants can customize the perception of their entities. For example, two different entities could realize in a different manner what a positive event is, and they could express such a subjective perception by defining their own equivalent relationships in terms of other self-defined internal Figure 2. UML class diagram for events and behaviour rules events. To easily handle this feature in execution, a generic semantic event subsystem has been developed but its explanation is out of scope of this paper. 3. COCLUSIO AD FUTURE WORK We have performed some exploration on serious games for learning, as well as some exploration on game design s principles and on studies on using games at school. Taking into account their most important conclusions, especially the one considering the design of a game as a more rewarding stage for learning rather than just playing games, and the fact that behaviour s descriptions in terms of cause-effect and action-reaction are commonly understood, we have presented in this paper a part of a conceptual model for supporting the authoring of reactive ecosystems. An important issue that our model supports is the possibility of defining a subjective perception of events happening in the ecosystem. This paper is our starting point for our future research in this area. It involves the construction of a comprehensive tool for teachers to support collaboratively the construction and the playing of reactive ecosystems at school. In particular, we are thinking of using augmented tabletops as a suitable destination platform. An augmented tabletop is a technology consisting of a table providing a multi-touch surface that acts as a display at the same time, and optionally supporting several physical artifacts that enrich the interaction. This technology was originally conceived to support co-located collaboration in computer based environments through natural interaction with hands or other physical gadgets. Some work has been done in the field of games [4, 5] as well as in learning [7, 8]. However, they are not oriented to overcome the educational issues commented in the introduction but rather they support specific applications to solve very concrete problems. In addition, they just consist of playing the game whereas our approach is trying to go beyond this with a new philosophy, i.e., to include the process of building the game as an important task for learning, trying to consider such a platform as an appropriate tool and place for discussion, experimentation, and reflection at two levels, design and play. 4. abstract.par: This paper provides a conceptual framework that explains how people's engagement with games is changing as a result of new types of interfaces, hardware, and games. Neo-immersive games move gaming out of the box and into the real world by creating engaging new interfaces and controllers, while at the same time creating games well suited to the casual user. It expands what it means to "play the game" or "be in the game." This subtle shift of perspective allows us to explain the success of recent game titles such as Guitar Hero and the Wii platform.

fulltext.ft_body: Neo-Immersion: Awareness and Engagement in Gameplay Jennifer Whitson Chris Eaket Hypertext and Hypermedia LabHypertext and Hypermedia Lab Carleton UniversityCarleton University Ottawa, Ontario, Canada Ottawa, Ontario, Canada jwhitson@connect.carleton.ca chris.eaket@gmail.com Minh Quang TranNatalie King Human Oriented Technology LabHypertext and Hypermedia LabCarleton UniversityCarleton UniversityOttawa, Ontario, Canada Ottawa, Ontario, Canada mqtran@connect.carleton.ca nking4@connect.carleton.ca Brian Greenspan Hypertext and Hypermedia Lab Carleton University Ottawa, Ontario, Canada brian_greenspan@carleton.ca ABSTRACT This paper provides a conceptual framework that explains how people s engagement with games is changing as a result of new types of interfaces, hardware, and games. Neo immersive games move gaming out of the box and into the real world by creating engaging new interfaces and controllers, while at the same time creating games well suited to the casual user. It expands what it means to play the game or be in the game. This subtle shift of perspective allows us to explain the success of recent game titles such as Guitar Hero and the Wii platform. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [General] Games General Terms Design, Theory. Keywords Immersion, Video Games, Awareness. 1. INTRODUCTION Neo-immersive gaming is a theory of game design based on the claim that immersive gameplay is a function of bringing the game world to the user, rather than bringing the user into the game world. This subtle shift of perspective on 'immersive gaming' allows us to explain the success of recent game titles such as Guitar Hero and the Wii platform, and provides a rationale for future game design. As gaming becomes less of a solitary activity and a more social activity adopted by a broader demographic [1], the tenets of what makes a good game have been shifting. While technological advancements bring the ideal of total immersive gaming into reach, there are indicators that perhaps this total immersion is not what many gamers actually want. Neo­immersion is not a subset or genre of games, but a set of design goals for making immersive games. Neo-immersion occurs in traditional videogames, but increasingly works to describe games Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. using advanced haptic interfaces (i.e., those applying tactile sensation and control to interaction with computer applications). It represents a new trend with a growing influence on future game design. A major trend in immersive gaming has been towards photo­realistic graphics and creation of worlds in box [2]. The games that pushed the boundaries of game hardware and software were the First Person Shooters (FPSs), such as Doom, Quake and Unreal. The increase in the graphical realism of FPS games in particular promised users a meticulously rendered and realistic game world in which to lose themselves for hours on end, and the first-person perspective became a dominant mode of interacting in game worlds. Accordingly, it came as a bit of a surprise that one of the most highly sought games consoles over the last two holiday seasons was not the HD-Ready Playstation 3 or the XBOX 360, but rather the relatively humble, inexpensive and playfully named Nintendo Wii. The Wii emphasized the interface rather than eye-candy as the defining feature of user engagement and enjoyment. 2. CONVENTIONAL IMMERSION In this section, we introduce the term immersion and discuss its history and links with conventional video games. Immersion depends primarily on surrounding and integrating the user in a fully realized environment. The immersive medium can take the form of trompe-l'oeil paintings, IMAX movies, or virtual reality, as long as the effect is the creation of a spatial setting with the potential for narrative action [3]. In short, immersion takes the nineteenth-century concept of the willing suspension of disbelief to its natural conclusion: a separation from the real world and the replacement of that world with a highly realistic simulation. Familiar forms of analog media, such as novels or movies, have naturalized the ideal of a totally immersive interface to the point that the book or projector now falls below the user s attention level, and rarely interferes with the immersive experience. With digital media, however, the immersive experience often competes with the exigency of interactivity, which demands that the user attend to an interface that controls the virtual world, but is not part of it [4]. As Bolter and Grusin note, immersion thus paradoxically depends on technologies of mediation whose purpose is to disappear [5]; it relies on the twin myths of the invisible interface [6] and the erasure of representation via the creation of a perfect representation. The ideal immersive environment is characterized by three phenomena: loss of self-awareness, loss of social awareness, and loss of game awareness. To achieve the immersive ideal, games aim to replace the user s current reality with an alternative reality by situating the user in a virtual body located in an alternate time and space. Immersive games invite users to forget about the here and now and accept the reality of the game as their own. 2.1 Loss of Self-Awareness Game designers rely on a variety of tools and tricks to help users get into the game. One of the ways designers achieve this effect is by presenting the user with an alternate self while ensuring that the game avoids reminders of his or her real self. This strategy occurs in games that provide the user with a fully realized avatar. The avatar represents a complete self with a lifelike body, a personal history, a personality, and even future goals. For example, Mario, the Italian plumber, is a feisty avatar on a quest to save a princess. Another design trick is to avoid offering opportunities that users might take to reflect on their actions. To do so, the game needs to continually engage the player. Gameplay must never remind the users of the real world; perhaps more importantly, the users must not encounter any interruptions or pauses that might allow time for self-reflection. One of the worst offenders of this rule is the loading screen, which is why some games include a no loading times feature. For example, it is possible to play Dungeon Siege for thirty-five hours straight from start to finish without once pausing for a loading screen. Where it is not technically feasible to avoid the loading screen, it is used as an opportunity to further develop the story, or provide the user with helpful tips. As the intermediate layer between game and user, the interface can be used to strengthen user connection to the game. The interface helps to maintain the illusion of the game, enticing the user to play and providing the only entrance to the game world. For example, the on-screen interface of Eve Online is presented as the dashboard of a spaceship. Complex and fantastical, the interface is crucial for creating the fantasy that the user is a spaceship commander. 2.2 Loss of Social-Awareness Conventional immersive games are commonly meant to be played solo, thus leading to the stereotype of the anti-social gamer. Immersive games require users to concentrate on the game in order to achieve a feeling of blissful affinity. Users need to be alone to explore the game and involve themselves in the plot. The physical presence of others can remind users that they are surrounded by the real world, thus disrupting the one-on-one connection with the game. To block out others and achieve a more secluded atmosphere where they can concentrate, some users close the door and turn off the phone, or don headphones to play certain multiplayer games. Games that encourage physical isolation also tend to discourage treating gameplay as a spectacle: sitting on a couch watching your friend press buttons on the console generates very little excitement. By eliminating any trace of a real person from the game, game designers help users avoid situations that may remind them of the real world. An example of this tendency is Unreal Tournament TV, a popular mod for Unreal Tournament that allows spectators to observe matches on the video screen without seeing the players. In neo-immersive games such as Dance Dance Revolution (DDR), however, the spectator requires full view of the player because half the fun is watching the real person [7]. Even in multiplayer games, users are encouraged to role-play. Friends may even put aside their real-world relationships and forge new ones in the game. In-game relationships and social status may have little correlation to one s real-world persona, and can be a site for experimentation with and exploration of identity, activities that contribute to immersion. 2.3 Loss of Game-Awareness The goal of immersive games is to replace the user s real world with an alternate one. The game world will frequently advertise itself as make-believe in order to lure the user into the world through the promise of escape; however, to keep the user engaged, the game must in the long run stop portraying itself as a game and convince the user that what he or she is experiencing is real. This trend towards ultra-realism can be observed in many aspects of game design, including intricate narratives, geographies, and fully developed species and cultures. Designers strive to anticipate all aspects of their imaginary worlds, from the basics to the details, in order to make them appear as realistic as possible. They know that a coherent story in the perfect context will hold the attention of users. In effect, designers concentrate on world building, creating fully realized, minutely detailed, and geographically expansive game spaces for users to explore, inhabit, and conquer. Another way to trap the user inside the imaginary world is through self-contained, tightly bound narratives that do not link to stories in other games or contain explicit references to the real world. This feature of immersive games contrasts with serious games that connect to stories of actual oppression, and compel their users to act in the real world. 3. NEO-IMMERSION The pillars of neo-immersive games are in many ways the inverse of the characteristics of conventionally immersive games described in the previous section. We identify three fundamental qualities that constitute the foundation for neo-immersive gaming: awareness of self, awareness of others, and awareness of the game. As neo-immersion is a trait, not a discrete and bounded category of games, not all of the following examples will exhibit each and every quality of neo-immersion. We conceptualize the shift from conventional games to neo-immersive games as occurring on a continuum. 3.1 Awareness of Self Neo-immersive games achieve an increased awareness of the physical self by foregrounding the importance of the game interface and controllers while allowing the story to recede into the background. Most games now use conventional handheld controllers or keyboard and mouse. However, there has recently been a shift towards interface-driven games with increased gestural interfaces and where novel peripherals are the main draw to the game. The most apparent example of this shift can be found in Nintendo s Wii and the WiiSports gamepack, but it can also be seen in multi-platform releases such as DDR and Guitar Hero. The Wii prioritizes haptics by having the user s movements in the actual world affect the avatars movements in the virtual game world. This correspondence is achieved through gyroscopes and infrared sensors built into the remote. Conventional RPGs and FPSs tend to foreground the body of the avatar, which the user must learn to control through keyboard or joystick commands through which only part of the user s body (the eye or hand) is mapped onto the entire avatar. By contrast, neo-immersive games engage and foreground more of the user s body, from the frenetic punching in Wii Boxing to the delicate flicks of the wrist necessary to putt in Wii Golf. No backstory or game narrative is needed to contextualize or situate the game experience other than simple directions on how the player can translate her bodily actions to her avatar. Other neo-immersive games that are not only for the Wii platform include Rock Band, Guitar Hero and Sing Star, which prioritize the user s physical body, but are also focused on other senses and skill sets such as listening, coordination, fine motor skills, and even singing ability. 3.2 Awareness of Others The second pillar of neo-immersive gaming is an increased awareness of others. With this increased awareness console gaming shifts from a solitary experience to an intensely social one. Many games such as Rock Band and DDR are multiplayer spectacles geared for attracting and entertaining an audience. Whether channeling one s inner rock god or dancing up a storm in DDR, one is usually performing for an audience of one s peers, whether consciously or not [7]. In a sense, this development is a logical import from other media, such as reality television or Facebook, where the performance of identity is central. Neo­immersive games foreground the audience-participant hand-offs that were already inherent in gaming, refocusing them to create a conscious awareness of performing for one s fellow gamers. Other games, such as the MarioParty and the Rayman Raving Rabbids franchises, are marketed explicitly as party games, casual mini-games to be played in a group setting. The awareness of others is enhanced when players have to coordinate with each other to achieve a goal, either in-person (as with Rock Band players attempting to syncopate their rhythms) or mediated (such as when World of WarCraft [WoW] players communicate using VOIP, message boards, and IM to coordinate and strategize raids or plan the logistics of day-to-day guild operations). An awareness of others is also achieved by allowing out-of-character behaviour that either steps outside of the role-playing context of the game or abandons it altogether. Although originally intended for role-play, MMOPRGs also are a site for significant out-of-character behaviour. For example, in WoW players regularly communicate with each other using real names instead of character names and discuss real issues, making it quite easy for one to wander into a conversation between two orc warriors talking about baking crème brûlée. Another example of the increased awareness of others can be seen in the history of protests and demonstrations in online games, in which social awareness translates into social action. Collective action is relatively common, and there are many accounts of rallied users pressuring companies to address certain issues, including the mythic recounting of the naked avatars that over-ran the castle of Richard Garriott, creator of Ultima Online, in 1997 [8]. Although often humorous in the retelling, these protests are taken quite seriously by game companies. For example, even the rumour of a protest in EverQuest in response to the diminished powers of the warrior class resulted in pre-emptive changes by the company to appease players and avert a possible strike [9]. Another widely known account details how Blizzard Entertainment, creator of WoW, banned GLBT-friendly guilds, which ultimately resulted in 1,000 employees attending sensitivity training [10]. These examples demonstrate that while the industry drives some aspects of neo-immersive gaming, others emerge from the fan base, and are still emerging in ways that cannot be fully predicted. 3.3 Awareness of the Game The social awareness of neo-immersive games is closely tied to the awareness of the game itself. This awareness is largely centered around testing and breaking the boundaries of the magic circle. The concept of the magic circle, first introduced by Johan Huizinga in Homo Ludens [11], stipulates that play is separated from real life: The arena, the card table, the magic circle . . . all are in form and function play-grounds, i.e. forbidden spots, isolated, hedged round, hallowed, within which special rules obtain. All are temporary worlds within the ordinary world, dedicated to the performance of an act apart [11]. Games create a separate, temporary space within the ordinary world within which special rules apply. Yet, many contemporary scholars do not accept that play is separate from and contrary to everyday life [12], [13]. Recent work on the metagaming aspect of games such as WoW [14] demonstrates how players continuously enter and exit the magic circle during gameplay. This phenomenon occurs when, for instance, a user has WoW running in one window and a game guide up in another, while holding a VOIP conversation. This interruption disrupts the magic circle, but it also makes it richer by linking it to a constellation of other sites and services such as discussion boards, walk-throughs, fan-sites, and mods. In fact, it seems that many neo-immersive games are created to facilitate ruptures in the magic circle. For example, short sessions and mini-games can be easily interrupted and paused, allowing the user to control the temporal pace of the game (rather than being carried along with it, unable to stop until they find a suitable save location or finish the level). In addition, the introduction of intuitive interfaces and controllers requiring little prior knowledge of how to play help to tap into the large casual gamer audience. 4. NEO-IMMERSIVE GAMEPLAY The social aspect of neo-immersive games stems equally from a desire to change the user market and contexts of gameplay. As gaming appeals to a broader demographic, game designers are paying increasing attention to popular concerns over the allegedly negative social and health effects of excessive gaming. The emphasis on the physical body in the Wii marketing campaign corresponds with tensions felt by people who are increasingly stationary and spend long, motionless hours sitting at their computers at work or school. The Wii is marketed as a method of activating the uncoordinated, atrophied body, capitalizing on the tensions around children and the obesity epidemic [15]. While neo-immersive games are busy promoting fit bodies, they are also expanding the market share beyond the traditional demographic of adolescent males [16]. The Wii marketing campaign, at least, suggests a desire to expand beyond the 18-35 crowd, reflecting both larger demographic trends (i.e. a growing senior population) and the aging of the first generation of gamers. In his discussion of aging and virtual reality, Featherstone [17] anticipates that virtual reality technologies will re-empower the elderly through digital disguise, allowing them to adopt new modes of digital self-representation, virtual mobility, and sensory exploration that transcend the aging or infirm body, fragmenting and blurring its boundaries. Contrary to this prediction, the Wii occupies a middle ground, emphasizing that the elderly can be active once more in their own, real bodies. The Wiimote thus becomes a kind of enabling or prosthetic technology that enhances the physical body, rather than transcending it through out-of-body experiences. Far from the relatively safe sphere of virtual activity, neo-immersive games emphasize a degree of physical risk that might hold greater appeal for an aging boomer generation, even as they remain circumscribed within the safety of the home. Moreover, unlike virtual reality, neo-immersion emphasizes the wholeness of the embodied gaming experience, which demands more of the user s body than hand-eye coordination. Even the Wii advertisements tend to portray gamers standing from head to foot, standing before the screen in a totally embodied engagement. Far from leaving the body behind, the Wii promises to rejuvenate the out-of-shape and infirm. Part of the challenge and pleasure of these games occurs when users adapt to the gaming environment through repeated gameplay and see the effects of their growing ability to confront new challenges in that environment, thereby achieving agent-environment fit [18]. In the case of WiiFit, the situation is reversed: our pleasure comes not from how we masterfully effect the environment though iterative gameplay, but rather how that environment affects us by toning and disciplining our bodies. Neo-immersive games also have a greater respect for a user s social context and needs. Conventional immersive games demand exclusive access to a user s time and attention, but it is not easy to become immersed in Azeroth if one is also keeping an eye out for the boss or watching the kids. The trend towards easily interrupted, less time-consuming games may be related to a need to expand the market share to new users who have less opportunity to become immersed in WoW. In fact, the increasing ubiquity of gaming computers and consoles and the widening range of users may demand that games become more sensitive to the user s more immediate context. 5. SUMMARY The concept of immersion used to mean encapsulating the physical body in technology and representations. In this model of immersion, the user s body is treated as an object, hooked up and forced to adapt to a technology that is socially alienating and profoundly solipsistic, and that rarely provides opportunities for engaging social and bodily interactions. Loss of self-awareness, social awareness and game awareness are required to keep the user in a state of flow and within a seamless magic circle of representation. By contrast, neo-immersive games start with the body, building upon the embodied knowledges and sets of experiences that users already possess, and that connect them to social networks and contexts. Combined, an awareness of self, of others, and of the game mark what we call the experience of neo-immersion, which acknowledges the body and its various existing contexts as an integral part of game design. This inside-out approach adapts technology to the needs and lifestyles of users, rather than demanding their full attention and immobilization. For future research, potential routes to measure engagement include: 1) using video equipment, motion sensors, and heart rate monitors to measure physical engagement during game play; 2) analyzing transcribed conversations from segments of game play, using content analysis to code and measure the quantity and quality of social engagement; and 3) conducting focus groups and surveys of immersive versus neo-immersive game players, asking them to indicate their subjective measurements of social and physical engagement in game play. 6. article_rec.title: Facilitating language-oriented game development by the help of language workbenches

abstract.par: In recent years, a strong tendency towards language-oriented engineering became visible within game development projects. This approach is typically based on data-driven game engines and scripting languages resp. editing tools alike and already provided a great deal of overall productivity improvements. However, in its current form, potential benefits are not able to fully unfold yet. This is due to a mostly manual tool development process, which provokes substantial costs and lacks flexibility -- especially during prototyping phases of development. Language workbenches seem to be a viable solution to this problem as they promise the ability of (visual) language (re-)generation by introducing a meta-level of development. This paper picks up that idea and evaluates its application in the area of game development. In this particular case, we discuss first findings of an ongoing case study, covering the development of level editors for several classic games, which have been built by the help of a language workbench.
