fulltext.ft_body: Facilitating Language-Oriented Game Development by the Help of Language Workbenches Sonja Maier, Daniel Volk Institute for Software Technology Universitaet der Bundeswehr Muenchen 85577 Neubiberg, Germany {sonja.maier, daniel.volk}@unibw.de ABSTRACT In recent years, a strong tendency towards language-oriented engineering became visible within game development projects. This approach is typically based on data-driven game engines and scripting languages resp. editing tools alike and already provided a great deal of overall productivity improvements. However, in its current form, potential benefits are not able to fully unfold yet. This is due to a mostly manual tool development process, which provokes substantial costs and lacks flexibility especially during prototyping phases of development. Language workbenches seem to be a viable solution to this problem as they promise the ability of (visual) language (re-)generation by introducing a meta-level of development. This paper picks up that idea and evaluates its application in the area of game development. In this particular case, we discuss first findings of an ongoing case study, covering the development of level editors for several classic games, which have been built by the help of a language workbench. Categories and Subject Descriptors D.2.2 [Design Tools and Techniques]: evolutionary prototyping, D.2.11 [Software Architectures]: domain-specific architectures, languages D.2.13 [Reusable Software]: domain engineering, K.8.0 [General]: games Keywords Game Development, Game Prototyping, Language Workbenches, Software Factories, Model-Driven Development, (Visual) Domain-Specific Languages 1. INTRODUCTION Current AAA game titles are typically developed within a multi­year timeframe by big interdisciplinary teams, raising budget levels to that of several million US$ [1]. This trend towards such project complexity also caused a shift in prevailing development styles, replacing former ad hoc ones by more professional methodology. Regarding this, currently used methodology on both software engineering and project management levels ranges from more conventional top-down approaches, embodying mostly Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. pre-planned and tiered iterations [14], to more bottom-up ones, using agile forms of development [8]. Besides these procedure­based productivity measures, also a trend towards high-level development tools is clearly visible. Instead of former machine­oriented hacking , data-driven game engines [3] and language­oriented development tools are now widely used in game development. The mentioned tools are typically either realized in the form of scripting interfaces or visual editors [10] both implementing the idea of domain-specific languages. But while offering an obvious boost in development productivity by making technology more specific and easier to use, they also come along with some disadvantages yet. On the one hand, the additional tool layer does not come for nothing. A considerable amount of time and money needs to be invested for providing the tools, which is also often visible in a corresponding tool-building sub-phase before full production within a typical game development process [12]. On the other hand, the applicability of the tools is inherently limited to their smaller scope, of course. This means that such tools might either be restricting in terms of game design, which is often the case with static game development environments [10], or need to be adapted to changing requirements (e.g., for game prototyping), which has to be paid by further investments. In this regard, language workbenches seem to be a viable improvement since they promise to speed-up and cheapen tool building by trading manual creation for meta-level specification, from which the tools are then generated automatically. The paper at hand evaluates this approach using a case study, which includes the prototype-oriented creation of a series of classic games. It is structured as follows: first, the enclosing approach of software factories is discussed, which will provide a solid context for further examination. Then, the chosen language workbench is introduced and the case study s parameters are defined. This is followed by some examples from the ongoing case study and a concluding discussion of first findings. 2. SOFTWARE FACTORIES While language workbenches per se show productivity-enhancing characteristics by automating tedious and error-prone tasks within language generation, we rather understand them as a kind of key element within a more holistic approach and therefore discuss them in the context of such. One candidate approach, which language workbenches nicely fit into, is that of software factories (although there are arguments to see both on the same level of abstraction [4]). Indeed, software factories are well known in the area of game development in a somewhat weaker form [14]; and there is also some evidence that the approach can be applied to a greater extent [5] in the area of games. The idea of the software factory is basically a clever combination of three interacting key concepts, introduced in the following (loosely adapted from [6]): Software Product Lines (concept of specificity) The idea of product in principle arises from the systematization of ad hoc reuse. In this manner, the ever­recurring meta-pattern of pattern-extraction, pattern­codification and language-creation is extended to the definition of families of unique but similar products that can be developed in a collective manner. These product families (e.g., a series of game sequels) can be seen as a scope (level of specificity) for the granularity of used platform components and the abstraction of development models. Component-based Development (concept of granularity) The aspect of component-based development is primarily related to the structure of the technical platform for development. It can be characterized by an increasing level of granularity for software components, which comes along with a trend towards a decreased applicability of the module, but also enhanced productivity. There is a current trend towards a higher level of exchangeability of modules by using meta­level specification mechanisms that allow a better standardization. The corresponding part in game development is a black box game engine, which consists of a set of exchangeable modules. Model-driven Development (concept of abstraction) The core of model-driven development is the definition of formal languages for solving development problems. The idea started out to be the comprehension of a model as documentation (OOD/OOD), evolved to an understanding of models as artifacts (MDD) and culminated in the definition of domain-specific languages (DSLs) and their visualizations (VDSLs). It can be characterized by an increasing level of abstraction for formal languages, which comes along with a trend towards a decreased applicability of the model, but also enhanced productivity. There is a current trend of easing the creation and handling of VDSLs by the help of language workbenches, which allow language specification on a meta­level. The corresponding parts in game development are scripting interfaces and visual editing tools. After discussing the three key aspects of software factories, it is now possible to introduce the whole approach, which is shown in Figure 1 (in a simplified form). Its structure basically follows the idea of product lines, introducing as well the role of product line developer, who meta-develops whole product families, as also the role of product developer, who develops product instances. The process starts with the definition of a factory schema, which in fact is a graph of views (Figure 1 shows an example) that characterizes the development process of a product family. To understand this concept, software development needs to be realized as a set of relating and interacting concerns (different views within one row) that are transformed from the conceptual (C) to the logical (L) to the implementation (I) level, whereby the latter represents the executable software product. From the factory schema, as well organizational (e.g., development roles), as also structural aspects (e.g., rudimental build processes) can be extracted. Following his own factory schema, the product line developer now uses his part of the language workbench (as we see it as a recursive approach, we called it meta software factory) to create a factory template, which specifies all views and transformations of the schema on a meta-level. The factory template is now used either as indirect (used by workbench compilers to produce generated factory parts) or direct (used to configure customizable factory parts) input for the creation of the software factory. Figure 1: The Software Factory Approach The factory itself is used by the product developer to specify single product instances. This is done by modeling the problem domain within the highest-level set of (V)DSLs that are available within the software factory. The actual instance is then assembled on top of the product family platform (a preconfigured set of components) by generating both the product-specific code from the product developers specifications and an adaption layer from factory template assets that close the arising model-component gap by defining progressive transformations. In the end, language workbenches appear to be the central component of the described approach, insofar they build the platform for the two-tier development process of product (line) development in which model-driven and component-based aspects are integrated. In fact, they are also the most potent remedy against software factories main disadvantage their high set-up costs, as they cheapen the use of (V)DSLs substantially [4]. While the typical benefits of language workbenches should have become clear by now, the area of game development even seems to max out their beneficial role. In addition to conventional software development, the creation of computer games is of inherently creative nature [1], which consequently emphasizes non-functional requirements [2] and lowers the stability of functional ones. This clearly exacerbates product line development, since necessary meta-models cannot be defined completely beforehand at least, when their development scopes are quite narrow (which increases the corresponding productivity impact). Instead, flexible re-specification of meta-models and re­generation of derived software factories is necessary, especially in early phases of development. If this aspect is stressed even more, also a parallel development of software factory and product itself seems to be imaginable. A comparable approach (although it is based on manual creation yet) is described in [11], whereby the used software factory is just created for a single game. This maximizes specificity and, in a way, even brings the idea of software factories to an extreme. 3. CASE STUDY SETUP Since we comprehend the described prototyping character of game development as its very key element, too, we focused our case study on this aspect. We developed, following the principle of one game at a time , which essentially narrowed the scope of the product line to a single product. But nevertheless, the distinction between meta- and instance-level remained. In addition, the factory schema was restricted in its width, by concentrating on one concern basically a VDSL level editor for the corresponding game, and in its depth by integrating a simple game loop within the editor. The adaption of an external game framework (in the role of a product family platform) was just not necessary for the simple games that have been realized until today. Eventually, this renders the current state of our case study similar to that of prototyping tools for the game concept phase [12], but tailored to the specific game in development since our editors essentially were the games. Figure 2: Case Study Setup DiaMeta [8], an editor generator framework, functioned as language workbench within the setting. Our student groups used this framework to implement the games. As can be seen in Figure 2, the language workbench is operated as follows: The product line developer sets up the software factory, which means that he creates a factory specification, from which the factory is automatically generated. The product developer then uses the factory to develop the game. In the context of setting up a software factory, the product line developer needs to specify several visual editors. In DiaMeta, the creation of such an editor mainly consists of two steps: First, the product line developer specifies an EMF model (Eclipse Modeling Framework) that represents the DSL definition. Afterwards, he provides an editor specification that contains the VDSL definition. From these two specifications, the level editor (basically a visual language editor) is generated. After setting up (generating) the software factory, the product developer uses the factory to model the game. In this particular case, he uses both the level editor to create one or more levels and an additional textual DSL (that is provided by DiaMeta) to describe game logic by the help of graph transformation. At any point, developers may include hand-written code to extend the factory and the game. One special feature of DiaMeta is that the developers may interact with an editor via structured editing or via free-hand editing [9]. To give a developer more guidance, one has the possibility to (partially) turn off free-hand editing and to limit the number of structured editing operations allowed. 4. CASE STUDY EXAMPLES Our case study started with implementing the board games Ludo [13] and Muehle, to give DiaMeta a try in supporting the game development process. Here, the focus did lie on a graph transformation based specification of different player strategies. Their successor was the game PacMan one of the standard examples in the graph transformation community [7], which will function as our running example in the following. Although, design itself was quite straightforward, our students made heavy use of evolutionary methodology, because they were able to do this with DiaMeta. The language workbench excellently supports this style of development: each time there is the wish for change, the specification editor can be adapted, and the editor is automatically re-generated. Figure 3: The PacMan EMF Specification As described in the last section, the product line developer creates a level editor. The rather simple EMF model for the PacMan level editor is shown in Figure 3. It depicts the different elements a PacMan game consists of, their attributes, and their interrelation between each other. For instance, it contains the element Field. A Field has an attribute food, which indicates, if there is food available on this field. On a Field, there may reside PacMan or a Ghost. This correlation is indicated by the association between the components. Moreover, if the level editor and the game would have been independent applications, the EMF model would have also included concrete syntax elements like the position of a field. Figure 4: The PacMan DiaMeta Specification A screenshot of the specification tool can be seen in Figure 4. In the specification, the visualization of components is defined (Components), e.g., a wall element is visualized as a blue rectangle. Besides, Relations between elements are specified, for instance PacMan is on field X . Also mappings between components and EMF model elements are declared, e.g., a mapping between dStatus and Status (visualization and definition of PacMan s points and lives). Last, some operations to interact with the system are defined, for instance a button to add a ghost. Figure 5: The PacMan Factory The product developer now specifies the game logic using the DSL provided and the levels using the level editor. To complete the game, the ghost strategies were implemented by hand. A simple game loop was included in the editor, and, as can be seen in Figure 5, a fully functional PacMan game was the result. Besides PacMan, the presented approach also was tested by reimplementing the games BoulderDash and Pingus (Figure 6). A peculiarity of those games was the fact that several levels needed to be modeled, which resulted in multiple editor instances. While this caused quite a redundancy in our current setting, it also showed a possible way to improve our case study (see our discussion in Section 5). Figure 6: The Pingus Factory 5. DISCUSSION AND FUTURE WORK While language workbenches inherently come along with reduced set-up costs for software factories (or similar approaches, relying on meta-model development), the benefit, most apparent within our case study, was just the plain reduction of development time. Starting from scratch, our student groups were actually able to implement first gameplay prototypes literally within hours. In addition to increased productivity, developing within the corresponding game factories was also quite simple. This became clear at the latest, when preschoolers used the editors with great success while our university s open day. While the former benefits mostly origin in a high level of specificity of the instance layer, the well established evolutionary development process was basically made possible by using a language workbench. Our development groups enabled a kind of what-you-see-is-what­you-get development style by regularly switching between meta- and instance-level a prerequisite for a content-driven process [11]. When considering the main drawbacks within our case study, the steep learning curve for mastering meta-modeling a peculiarity of such approaches remained, of course. Further, the game projects were somewhat hindered in later phases by just concentrating on the level editor. What gave focus in the beginning of development just became a restriction when the development teams got used to meta-modeling and would have been able to specify additional views as well. In the end, also implementing and fine-tuning necessary game functionality consumed a considerable amount of time (although, adding code to the (meta) game factory did not pose a problem per se). In summary, we see quite a potential in our approach of using language workbenches to facilitate language-oriented game development and believe that it is worth to be investigated in more detail. This is especially true, since a parallel course in the area of classic game engineering [15] clearly confirmed deficiencies in current manual transitions towards the implementation level. As this course also underlined the relevance of game prototyping, it seems logical to us, to raise our case study to its next level by integrating it into such a course concept to exploit synergetic effects. This will happen in the following way: on the one hand, upcoming game projects will be driven by multi­concern modeling (e.g., by adding a visual language for behavior definition of non-player characters); on the other hand, current proprietary game code will be substituted by a common product family platform. All in all, we are quite curious, how these enhancements may work out. 6. REFERENCES [1] Badcoe, I., 2000. The Computer Game Industry: Current State of Play. Virtual Reality, Volume 5, Number 4. fulltext.ft_body: The Case for Research in Game Engine Architecture Eike Falk Anderson Steffen Engel Leigh McLoughlin Faculty of Engineering and The National Centre for The National Centre for Computing Computer Animation Computer Animation Coventry University Bournemouth University Bournemouth University eikea@siggraph.org sengel@bmth.ac.uk lmcloughlin@bmth.ac.uk Peter Comninos The National Centre for Computer Animation Bournemouth University peterc@bournemouth.ac.uk ABSTRACT This paper is a call for research in the .eld of game engine architecture and design, a more comprehensive and thorough understanding of which we consider to be essential for its development. We present a number of key aspects that may help to de.ne the problem space and provide a catalogue of questions thatwebelieve identifyareasofinterestfor future investigation. Categories and Subject Descriptors C.4 [Performance of Systems]: design studies ; D.2.11 [Software Engineering]: Software Architectures domain­speci.c architectures; H.5.1[Information Interfaces and Presentation]: Multimedia Information Systems arti.­cial, augmented, and virtual realities GeneralTerms game engine architecture Keywords game engine, entertainment systems 1. INTRODUCTION Starting with Spacewar in 1961 [4], computer games have been around for just over four and a half decades. Until about two decades ago, most games were developed by a small team of programmers, if not by individuals, usually written from scratch with very few reusable components. In a young industry that is very much project-based, this does not come as a great surprise; however, as the industry has grown, so has the size of individual projects. This change has necessitated a number of advancements in production Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copyotherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. techniques, and Garlan and Shaw [6] recognised that one characterization of progress in programming languages and tools has been regular increases in abstraction level or the conceptual size of software designers building blocks . A similar increase in abstraction level occurred within com­puter game development towards the end of the 1980s, when the .rst systemswithreusable components appeared.These components are what we would now call game engines. There appears tobe general agreement that game engines are not only useful, but due to the complexity of modern computer games, are actually required for game develop­ment. Given this, there exists a surprisingly small body of literature on game engine design. The available research has mainly focussed on game engine subsystems, such as ren­dering, AI (arti.cial intelligence) or networking. However, issues regarding the overall architecture of engines, which connects these subsystems, have merely been brushed over. This lack of literature and research regarding game engine architectures isperplexing. Books on the subject, such as that by Eberly [3], tend to only brie.y describe the high­level architecturebefore plunging straight down to the low­est level and describing how the individual components of the engine are implemented. Often authors present their ownarchitectureasade facto solutionto theirspeci.cprob­lem set, without necessarily justifying the decision-making processes that led to their designs, and merely indicating the authors personal preferences. Such literature o.ers an excellent source of information for writing an engine, but provides little assistance for designing one when the require­ments are di.erent from the solution described. We believe that there are a number of points that should be investigated, with regard to the game engine develop­ment process. In this paper, we are not trying to answer the questions that need answers, but we would like to invite the academic community as well as the game industry to par­ticipate in the discovery of these answers. The aim of this position paper is therefore to present these questions in or­der to provide a startingpoint for debate, and to encourage discussion of game engine development and architecture. 2. RESEARCHQUESTIONS In this section we present a number of questions, focussed onarangeofpotentialresearchtopicswithin gameandgame engine development.The questions thatwepose canroughly be categorised into questions of terminology and questions of game engine architecture and design. This is in no way intended to provide an exhaustive list, or even to examine the points in all their detail. Instead it is our hope that we can spark discussions on these and similar topics, and to trigger a more rigorous examination of their e.ects. 2.1 Terminology: The lack of a game devel­opment language. The games industry is relatively young, and as such it is still lacking a common terminology. This is true within the games industry itself, and between the industry and the emerging games-related academia. However, in order to fa­cilitate therigorous studyof anysubject,frombotha purely academic and a practical point of view, the ability to com­municate e.ectively is of the utmost importance. The absence of a formal terminology results in communi­cation at cross purposes, as lamentedby Stephens [11],who points out the confusion between game engines and ren­dering engines , clearly demonstrating the need to establish a game development language. We believe that such a language should encompass a def­inition of game engines and those engines components as well as other aspects relating to game development, such as game genre, a now outdated classi.cation of which was presented by Sawyer [8]. Regarding the technical aspects of game engine architecture, Folmer s attempt to establish a reference architecture [5] can be viewed as a step in the right direction. However, these two topics represent only a small subset of the subject area and, in addition to further investigation of these areas, additional research is required to de.ne the scope of the game development language. 2.2 What is a Game Engine: Where is the boundary between game and game engine? As mentioned above, there is disagreement about exactly what a game engine is, with sometimes fundamental di.er­encesbetween de.nitions. Simpson [10]reports on the con­fusion between game engines and games themselves, as well as the erroneous description of game engines as the game s component for displaying graphics. Game engine de.nitions that are not limited to individ­ual engine components are oftenverybroad andvague, such as a framework comprised of a collection of di.erent tools, utilities, and interfaces that hide the low-level details of the various tasks that make up a video game [9]. The main issue appears to be the question of where the boundary lies between the game engine and the game itself. There are signs that a common consensus may be emerg­ing for the de.nition of a game engine, however. More con­crete descriptions have been o.ered, such as that by Lewis and Jacobson [7] that game engines are the collection of modules of simulation code that do not directly specify the game s behaviour (game logic) or game s environment (level data) . While this undoubtedly brings us closer to an un­derstanding of theboundarybetween game engine and game logic, this divide is still not clearly de.ned and many over­laps remain. As a precursor to an investigation of game engines and their components, research in this area will have to examine computer games to identify the software components which are common and unique among di.erent types of games. This should then lead to the discovery of a clear distinc­tion between game engine code and game code, helping to establish thisboundary. 2.2.1 Toolsets: Is the toolset part of the game en­gine? An issue which is becoming increasingly relevant is that of the toolset that must accompany a modern engine. Cur­rently, artists employed to generate game content use mostly o.-the-shelf 3D modelling and animation packages, such as Maya or 3D Studio Max. These content creation packages were not, for the most part, designed for the task of creating game assets [1], andmustbe augmentedbyexporters,world­editors and script-editors that are tailor-made for the game engine. Such tools .ll the gap between the asset generation software and the game engine, and often provide an inter­face between artist and programmer. Without these tools there would be no game. However, an important question that needs to be answered is if such tools should therefore be considered within the scope of the de.nition of a game engine? 2.3 Game Genre: How do different genres af­fect the design of a game engine? The design and de.nition of a game engine is, currently, intrinsically linked to that of the game that uses the en­gine. The broad subject of computer games can generally be subdivided into a number of game genres, such as real­time-strategy (RTS) games or .rst-person-shooters (FPS). Commercially available game engines tend to be more spe­cialised towards the demands faced by games of a partic­ular genre. This allows them to provide genre-speci.c op­timisations, but usually at the expense of .exibility. While suchdistinctions across genres often highlight the di.erences between approaches, by focusing on the commonality we should start to gain aperspective and a clearer de.nition of what a game engine is, and what components it should be comprised of. We believe that a formal study of engine design with re­spect to genre could lead to the de.nition of a game engine that is independent of genre. 2.3.1 Überengine: Is it possible to de.ne a game en­gine independently ofgenre? Currently, game engines are mostly written for speci.c game genres. Certain optimisations are required for each, and overheads are introduced when trying to come up with a more generic solution. The ability to use a single game engine for any genre of game instead of using a number of genre-speci.c engines, however, couldpotentially o.er large bene.ts for the development of games. Apart from .nancial savings due to the use of only a single system that would have to be maintained, such an ¨ uberengine would facilitate the transfer of programmers and artists across projects. There is as yet no taxonomy of game engines that could provide an insight into the commonalities between di.erent engines. While super.cially many engines appear to have similar functionality, the question that needs asking is if there is something that could be called a game engine that caters for games of any genre. In other words, if presented with two completely di.erent games from di.erent genres, would a developer recognise the engine in each, especially considering the wide range of games that include the so­called serious games which are often simulations of real­world scenarios? We are convinced thatit maybepossible to solve this problem, eventually. 2.4 Design Dependencies: How do low-level issues affect top-level design? Reference architectures, such as those by Doherty [2] or Folmer [5] provide descriptions of top-level design, but rarely investigate the e.ect of low-level issues on the system archi­tecture as such. It is our belief that the manner in which low-level issues in.uence architectural design is intrinsically linked to the fact that technology changes at a very fast rate. Such technological changes take place at the low-level, in terms of hardware or software interfaces and capabilities, and can directly a.ect the evolution of individual or multi­ple game engine components. For example, a few years ago rendering was achieved us­ing a .xed-function pipeline, whereas today we use pro­grammable shaders. Initially, one might assume that such changes would be limited to within a single game engine module or component. In the case of shaders, this would obviously be rendering related. However, it is also possi­ble that functionality can be relocated from one part of an engine to another, for example part of an engine s physics calculations could be performed by using shaders. Another example is the introduction of multiple proces­sors, providing resources which a modern game engine should take advantage of. The restrictions and requirements of these would result in fundamental changes to a game en­gine s architecture (at some level or other) to transform it into a multi-threaded engine architecture [12]. It is clear that technology changes a.ect high-level archi­tecture, but it has not yet been established to what extent. Furthermore, the question must be asked if there are any engine design methods that could be employed to minimise the impact of the future introduction of new developments in computer game technology. 2.5 Best Practice: Are there speci.c design methods or architectural models that are used, or should be used, for the creation of a game engine? Common sense suggests that top-down design, andbottom­up implementation would provide a solution suitable to the development of game engines. However, this is not necessar­ily how game engines come into being. Empirical observa­tion suggests that many engines grow and evolve over time. The danger with organically grown projects is that features can spiral out of control, a phenomenon known as feature creep , usuallybecause the original goalswerepoorly de.ned at thebeginningofaproject.This has the unfortunate e.ect that when the implementation .nally meets the original re­quirements, the goals may have changed. The architecture, however, may not be capable of supporting these new re­quirements, and workarounds, a.ectionately called hacks , must be added. As brie.y mentioned above, a large section of the available literature appears to overlook this issue al­together by concentrating solely on the implementation of individual engine components, approaching the subject in terms of micro architecture as opposed to macro architec­ture. The question that we ask is whether there is a best prac­tice for the development of game engines that can help elim­inate, or at least reduce, these problems? 3. SUMMARYOF RESEARCHQUESTIONS While it is usually simple to attack speci.c problems, a scholarly approach would be to pull back to see the bigger picture and to identify trends. This abstraction can then be used to identify gaps in the knowledge of the .eld and to explore ideas that others may have overlooked. Our task, as academics, should be to look at designs and .nd common­ality, to allow us to try to piece together a better design . The aim of this call for research is to raise academic inter­est in the .eld of game engine architecture and design. Our research agenda could therefore be de.ned as: The establishment of a uni.ed language of game de­velopment; The identi.cation of software components that are com­mon to all types of computer games; The establishment of clear boundariesbetween game engine (code) and game code; The de.nition of the role of content creation tools in the game development process and as part of game engines; The identi.cation of links between game genres and game engine architecture; The identi.cation of components that are common to all types of game engine, allowing the de.nition of a genre-independent reference architecture; The investigation of the e.ects of low-level issues on top-level game engine architecture; The identi.cation of a best practice for the develop­ment of game engines. In this paper we have identi.ed several key aspects that may help to de.ne the problem space of game engine archi­tecture and design. We have posed a number of questions that we believe may provide directions for future initiatives to address. Apossible next stepwouldbe to setup an ex­ploratory meeting of interested parties from industry and academia. This could be followed by the setting up of a committee or working group to coordinate research on this topic, apossible end resultbeing the de.nition of an open standard for use by all. 4. REFERENCES [1] J. Blow. Game development harder than you think. ACM Queue, 1(10):28 37, 2004. [2] M. Doherty. A software architecture for games. article_rec.title: Towards 3D model interoperability in games

abstract.par: This paper presents an automatic method for enabling the interoperability of 3D models within different types of games. Character customization is an increasingly popular ability in modern video games. For example, games built for the Nintendo Wii#8482; may take advantage of the built-in avatar customization (e.g. Mii avatars) yet few games to date have actually utilized this ability. Game designers are hesitant to allow players total creative freedom when customizing their avatars for fear of invalidating the intended aesthetic gameplay experience. In this paper, we present a step forward in character customization allowing the player creative freedom while not sacrificing the intended aesthetics. This paper focuses on developing an automatic method to blend multiple animated 3D meshes.

fulltext.ft_body: Towards 3D Model Interoperability in Games Jia Sing Chen and Andrew Hogue Faculty of Business and Information Technology University of Ontario Institute of Technology 2000 Simcoe St. N Oshawa, ON, Canada, L1H 7K4 jia.chen@mycampus.uoit.ca , andrew.hogue@uoit.ca ABSTRACT This paper presents an automatic method for enabling the interoperability of 3D models within di.erent types of games. Character customization is an increasingly popular ability in modern video games. For example, games built for the Nintendo WiiTM may take advantage of the built-in avatar customization (e.g. Mii avatars) yet few games to date have actually utilized this ability. Game designers are hesitant to allow players total creative freedom when customizing their avatars for fear of invalidating the intended aesthetic game­play experience. In this paper, we present a step forward in character customization allowing the player creative freedom while not sacri.cing the intended aesthetics. This paper fo­cuses on developing an automatic method to blend multiple animated 3D meshes. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.3.5 [Computer Graphics]: Computational Geometry and Object Modeling Geometric algorithms, languages, and sys­tems; I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional Graph­ics and Realism Animation Keywords 3D model, mesh blending, interoperability, distance .eld, graph embedding 1. INTRODUCTION Interoperability and the ability to pass data between video games is becoming a reality. With the introduction of the Xbox Live Arcade (XBLA) on the Xbox360 a mechanism has been put in place to allow the transfer of data be­tween XBLA titles and larger titles. For example, it was announced at the Game Developers Conference 2008 that Fable 2 would enable you to play mini pub-games that are available in the XBLA to increase your character s wealth in Fable 2. The data from the XBLA pub-game is trans­ferred to your online presence accessible by Fable 2 when Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. connected to the internet enabling the interoperability. Character customization is an increasingly popular ability in games. Nintendo allows you to customize your own Mii avatar and utilize them in speci.c games. Currently only a few titles utilize the Mii avatar for in-game utilization. Sim­ilarly on other platforms, Sony s PlayStation Home allows you to create your own avatar and numerous games have added this ability for the character you control. Electronic Arts SporeTMallows for an extreme amount of avatar cus­tomizability. The user is allowed to generate avatars using a vast set of tools and limbs giving the user a tremendous amount of control over the look and feel of the creature. Tex­tures and animation are applied procedurally and tailored to meet the user-de.ned avatar[7]. At the recent E3 2008 conference, Microsoft announced that it also will be incorporating an avatar creation utility in the Xbox LIVE interface. In their discussion of this they implied that the intention is not to simply add the ability to create items and move them around but rather they will be focusing on using the avatar utility to make better gameplay experiences. Coupling this announcement with the ability to pass data between games makes it clear that the ability to utilize user-customized avatar s in more games is com­ing but it is not known to what end. These announcements have numerous implications for upcoming titles. The type of data able to be transferred currently seems to be lim­ited to numerical data (i.e. virtual currency), however one could imagine the possibility of incorporating a more gen­eral framework for the transfer of di.erent types of data to be utilized in-game. Sony Entertainment s PlayStation Home (due out in 2008) for the PlayStation 3 will also en­able users to customize avatars although it is still not known to what extent. It will however be possible to utilize micro­transactions in the form of an auction to purchase user cre­ated content for your own avatars. These avatar creation utilities have the possibility of becoming a new source of revenue for console makers. A signi.cant portion of the user base is interested in purchasing items/clothing/accessories to add to their avatars as seen in the ever popular Second Life1 . This user base could be expanded tremendously if console makers allowed users to use these purchased items in every game on their systems. Interoperability of avatar meshes has yet to be accom­plished. Just imagine if you could play as Nintendo s Super Mario in Sony s God of War. What would that look like? 1http://secondlife.com 2Super Mario is the property of Nintendo R @ 3God of War 2 is the property of Sony Computer Entertain­ Figure 1: Imagine what it would be like to play as Nintendo s Mario (a) in Sony Computer Entertain­ment s God of War series (b). Few games allow for any sort of interoperability between them for good reasons. Copyright and, more importantly, security is of concern when allowing for data to be trans­ferred to your game console or PC and a discussion on this is beyond the scope of this paper. Each game world has its own well-de.ned and unique artistic style. Incorporating mesh data not created by the game s artists and designers would compromise the intended look and feel of the expe­rience. As in the example above, Nintendo s Mario has a primary color palette and has a cheerful, cartoon style while God of War s Kratos is quite the opposite, i.e. mean, mus­cular and monotone, which suits the game world and style of gameplay of their respective games. By directly incorpo­rating the Mario avatar into the world of God of War, the character would look extremely out of place breaking the emotive intention of the game designers. Other issues plague interoperability of characters between games such as texture, animation, size/scale, attributes and accessories make this a very complex problem to solve in­dependently. This paper addresses the possibility of main­taining the intended artistic style of the game while auto­matically incorporating customized avatars between games. To this end, we focus on the blending meshes and leave the character shading and texturing for possible future work. 2. MODEL REPRESENTATION There are many ways to represent a 3D model. Triangu­lar/polygonal meshes, point-based representations, NURBS models, voxel grids, and hierarchical representations such as Octrees, are commonly used representations[3] for 3D models. The most commonly used representation for video games is the triangular mesh due to its simplicity and that graphics hardware has optimized pathways for rendering sets of triangles. Triangular meshes have several limita­tions for their use in model blending most notably are self­intersections which produce visually unappealing results. These limitations have been addressed in [11] with the creation of a new data structure called TransforMesh. Perhaps the most .exible representation to use is to utilize an implicit func­ ment tion[2] or scalar .eld representation such as a distance .eld or a level-set[6]. The idea is rather than representing individ­ual surface elements of the model, the surface is represented as a function. One example of a function may provide a way to determine the distance and direction to the surface from any point in 3D space. This approach is not constrained to a particular mesh data structure and can easily deal with self-intersections and topology changes. For example, ap­plying dynamics or constructive solid geometry operations to a distance .eld or level set is more easily accomplished than applying such operations to triangular meshes. During the operation or evolution of the dynamical function, a new mesh may be extracted at each iteration[8]. Sculpting op­erations can be performed directly on the distance .eld[10] enabling .exibility in the representation. In this work, we utilize the adaptively sampled distance .eld as our internal model representation to merge the two meshes into a single mesh suitable for real-time animation. 3. METHOD An overview of our method is illustrated in Figure 2. First we load in the two models we wish to incorporate and blend together (Figure 2(a)) in the example provided we used two di.erent freely available 3D meshes. In the application do­main discussed above, imagine that one of the meshes is user-created and the destination mesh is from a particular video game. We also load the skeletal rig if it exists. If no skeletal rig exists, we employ the autorigging approach from [1] to apply a generic skeletal rig to the mesh and compute the appropriate weights for each vertex. At this point we have two meshes with two distinct (and very di.erent) skele­tal rigs. They can be animated individually but combining the meshes is problematic as their scales are much di.erent. As can be seen in Figure 2(a), the Sonic the Hedgehog R @source mesh is shorter and skinnier than the kangaroo desti­nation mesh. We opted to deform the source mesh and bones into the same scale as the destination mesh. Currently we do this manually, however we propose using a graph embedding approach to .nd an embedding of the source skeleton in the second skeleton using the method from [1]. Finding the em­bedding of one skeleton in the other model provides us with a direct mapping of bones from the source to destination skeleton. Once the mapping is accomplished, we compute a transformation to stretch the bones to be the same length as the mapped bones in the destination skeleton and re-mesh our model to apply the deformation (see Figure 2(c)). Now that the meshes are in the same scale, we can merge them together. The simplest way to accomplish this task is to simply copy all of the triangles and vertices from one mesh into the other mesh. This creates problems where the meshes overlap as can be seen in Figure 2(d). This .gure shows the sharp edges where the triangles overlap creating a mesh that cannot be animated aesthetically. We opt to per­form a volumetric merge operation to ensure that the output mesh is aesthetically pleasing and able to be smoothly ani­mated. The volumetric meshing approach computes an adaptive distance .eld (ADF) using an Octree as described in [4] for both the source and destination meshes individually. The marching cubes algorithm [9] is used to compute the set of triangles for the distance .eld. Marching cubes samples a regular voxel grid and computes the distance to the surface (using both of the computed distance .elds) de.ned as the minimum of the two distance samples. The results can be seen in Figure 2(f) showing a low resolution (64 subdivisions) merging of the two meshes. As can be seen in Figure 2(g), the resulting merged mesh does not su.er from the same breaks in surface as it did with the simple combination of the triangle sets. Since this new merged mesh corresponds to a known skeletal rig, the animations already de.ned by the game artists and animators will also properly animate this new mesh. With this approach there are a few caveats. The resulting mesh detail depends upon the resolution of the voxel grid used in the marching cubes algorithm and also upon the maximum depth of the octree used for the distance .eld computation. In these examples, they were set to low values of 64 subdivisions each to illustrate the algorithm, however in practice the resolution should be increased dramatically to maintain overall mesh quality. For example in Figure 2(e), the voxel grid used was set at 512 subdivisions and much more detail such as Sonic s eye s can be seen more clearly in the resulting mesh (note that in this example the two meshes were not aligned showing the need for determining the appropriate mapping between skeletal rigs). A better approach would be to utilize the surface nets approach to mesh the ADF directly as in [5]. One advantage to this approach is the inherent level-of­detail encoded in the model representation. By utilizing suitable meshing techniques higher or lower resolution meshes may be extracted to conserve memory cpu intensity. The method can also be used to merge non-humanoid models as long as the models can be aligned in some fashion (See Fig­ure 2(h) and Figure 2(i) for an example). This is due to the usage of a non-mesh based model representation internally to perform the volumetric merging. 4. CONCLUSIONS The method developed in this paper is capable of merging two meshes. We maintain the ability to utilize pre-built ani­mations for the destination model since we deform the source mesh into the same domain as the destination mesh. This can be applied directly to characters from di.erent games. For example, you can blend the meshes of your user created mesh and Nintendo s Super Mario model for use in the Super Mario platformer games. In the current implementation, we focused on merging the mesh and skeletal data. Future work includes properly de.ning the animation blending factors to incorporate both the source and destination model anima­tions (or by using procedural animation techniques as in [7]); developing a more adaptive meshing approach to incorporate more detail into the resulting meshes; and developing proper texturing and shader support to bring the source mesh into the aesthetic realm of the destination mesh, i.e. to ensure that the Mario model has the look and feel of Kratos. 5. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We thank TurboSquid.com for use of the Sonic the Hedge­hog, Kangaroo and Chair models. 6. REFERENCES [1] I. Baran and J. Popovi´c. Automatic rigging and animation of 3d characters. article_rec.title: Experience in the design and development of a game based on head-tracking input

abstract.par:
Tracking technologies, such as eye and head-tracking, provide novel techniques for interacting with video games. For instance, players can shoot with their eyes in a first person shooter using gaze-based input. Head-tracking systems allow players to look around a virtual cockpit by simply moving their head.

However, tracking systems are typically based on expensive specialized equipment. The prohibitive costs of such systems have motivated the creation of low-cost head-tracking solutions using simple web cameras and infrared light detection. In this paper, we describe our experience developing a simple shooting game which incorporates such low-cost head-tracking technology.

fulltext.ft_body: Experience in the Design and Development of a Game Based on Head-Tracking Input Jeffrey Yim, Eric Qiu, T.C. Nicholas Graham School of Computing Queen s University Kingston, ON, Canada K7L 3N6 {yim, qiu, graham}@cs.queensu.ca ABSTRACT Tracking technologies, such as eye and head-tracking, provide novel techniques for interacting with video games. For instance, players can shoot with their eyes in a first person shooter using gaze-based input. Head-tracking systems allow players to look around a virtual cockpit by simply moving their head. However, tracking systems are typically based on expensive specialized equipment. The prohibitive costs of such systems have motivated the creation of low-cost head-tracking solutions using simple web cameras and infrared light detection. In this paper, we describe our experience developing a simple shooting game which incorporates such low-cost head-tracking technology. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.5.2 [Information Interfaces and Presentation]: User Interfaces evaluation/methodology, input devices and strategies, user-centered design. General Terms Design, Human Factors. Keywords Head tracking input, game design 1. INTRODUCTION There have in recent years been significant advances in novel techniques for interacting with video games. One interesting direction involves the creation of more immersive ways of providing input to games, where players natural movements translate into in-game actions. Perhaps the most well-known of these are gesture-based interactions using a Wii Remote [7], and movement-based interaction using a dance pad or Wii Balance Board [6]. A very different style of approach has been the use of passive input devices that capture player s focus of attention, and use this as a direct source of input to games. An example is eye-gaze control of video games, where for example, a player of a first Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. person shooter can aim his gun simply by looking at the desired target. In this approach, players do not control the game through a physical input device; they simply look. Gaze-based input requires expensive equipment (e.g., a $28,000 Tobii eye tracker), and therefore cheaper approaches have been developed, such as head-tracking. Unlike eye trackers, head tracking systems cannot directly determine eye-gaze. Instead, player attention is approximated by capturing head position and orientation (e.g. a $200 TrackIR head tracker). In this manner, players can freely look around their cockpit in a flight simulator game [10]. Head trackers, however, are not just low-fidelity substitutes for eye trackers. For instance, the act of dodging projectiles in a shooting game is naturally captured by lateral head movements. Recently, Lee [4] has developed a low-cost head-tracking technology demo based on the Wii Remote, and has made this software publically available. In this paper, we present the results of using Lee s code to develop a 3D game using head-tracking as a core interaction technique. We found the software to be robust and easy to adapt to our intended game purpose. We found its performance to be sufficient for real-time gaming, and its accuracy to be adequate for coarse-grained pointing actions. Informal feedback indicated that the game was fun and engaging, and that players found the head-tracking interface to be intuitive. 2. BACKGROUND Video game players can become so immersed in games that they unconsciously move their body in response to game events. For instance, players in a racing game may lean in to turns. Players may also tilt their head to look around corners in shooting games. Although players perform these actions, these motions have no effect on the game. Passive input devices have the ability to transform these body movements into useful input. Several technologies have been developed for passive input devices, such as optical, magnetic, and inertial motion tracking [10]. Due to the different characteristics of each technology, some applications may be more suited to one tracking system over the others. For example, optical tracking has low latency, but suffers from line of sight (LOS) issues. Users must always remain in view of a camera. Optical tracking is therefore suitable for head/eye tracking of stationary users. LOS problems do not affect magnetic tracking; however, it is slow, making it suitable for tracking human motion for non real-time applications. Finally, inertial tracking is fast and does not suffer LOS problems, but is inaccurate when capturing slow position changes. Commercial products have been developed for motion tracking in virtual environment applications such as flight simulators or 3D games, but they are typically expensive. For instance, Flock of Birds [1] uses magnetic tracking for head/hand/body tracking in flight simulators, and virtual environment games. However, it costs at least $2,500 with one receiver. VFX-1 [10] uses inertial tracking for head-tracking in 3D games such as first person shooters and flight simulators; this systems costs $995. A less expensive optical tracking technique involves capturing infrared (IR) light. We discuss some examples in the next section 2.1 Infrared Head and Eye-tracking Systems IR tracking is a form of optical tracking where IR light is captured using an IR filtered camera. Due to the filter, only IR light emitting objects are seen by the camera. For instance, head­tracking can be achieved by using a camera to observe IR light­emitting objects placed on a user s head. TrackIR [5] is a commercial head-tracking game peripheral based on this technique. Attached along the sides of an IR filtered camera are IR light emitting diodes (LEDs). The camera then captures IR light reflected by reflecting tape placed on a user s head. TrackIR can track six degrees of freedom in 3D space. TrackIR costs approximately $200. Using TrackIR, head motions can be used to simulate eye-gaze in video games. In a flight simulator game, players in a cockpit may want to look down at their controls. This is performed by physically tilting their head down while looking at the screen. However, such motions are awkward as TrackIR games may require players to move their head in one direction while looking in another direction. In addition to head-tracking, eye-tracking can also be achieved using IR light tracking with Tobii eye trackers [9]. Instead of reflecting IR light off reflective tape, the light is reflected off of the user s eyes. This provides the position of the user s eyes relative to the camera. A nine point calibration system can also be used to determine user s eye-gaze, or where they are looking on screen. Eye-gaze accuracy is rated at 0.5 degrees, meaning error in the detected gaze location may be up to 0.5 cm for users sitting at a normal distance from their monitor. A Tobii eye tracker costs $28,000. A feature of eye trackers such as the Tobii is that they operate completely passively. Players simply look at a screen and their eyes and gaze are passively captured by the camera. Unlike TrackIR, users do not need to wear any equipment. An issue with the above tracking systems is their prohibitive cost. At $28,000 the Tobii eye tracker is beyond the price range of most consumers. TrackIR costs significantly less; however, the $200 price is still high for a gaming peripheral. Additionally, both systems only function if users are facing the capture device. This is arguably reasonable for desktop computing. However, these systems are incapable of capturing 3D movement as they assume a particular player orientation. 2.2 WiiDesktopVR WiiDesktopVR is a low-cost (less than $100) head-tracking technology demo created by Johnny Chung Lee [4]. The demo uses a Wii Remote, Bluetooth receiver and IR LEDs. The Wii Remote is a motion sensitive controller equipped with an IR filtered camera. Using it as a camera, it is possible to track IR LEDs placed on a user s head. The Wii Remote transmits information via Bluetooth, which is interpreted using the Bluetooth receiver. The tech demo allows users to view targets floating in a virtual 3D space. The purpose of the demo is to illustrate the differences between viewing a 3D world with and without head-tracking enabled. Without head-tracking, the world remains stationary regardless of users head position. With head-tracking enabled, the view dynamically reacts to users head positions. In our experiences with the tech demo, we found the code understandable and well written. Using WiiDesktopVR as a foundation we built a simple shooting game. We discuss our experience developing the game in the following section. 3. DODGE IT! Dodge It! is a simple shooting game played from the first person perspective (see Figure 1). It is based on the WiiDesktopVR head­tracking tech demo. In Dodge It!, players must shoot down targets while dodging red projectiles fired by the targets. Levels are completed by shooting down all available targets. As the levels progress, more targets and faster projectiles appear. Players have a limited number of lives, which decrease when hit by projectiles. In addition to firing at the targets, players have the ability to slow down time and freeze projectiles in midair. To play, players aim a green reticule using a Wii Remote. Players shoot targets by pulling a trigger located underneath the remote and press a button to slow time. Players may also thrust the remote forward to freeze bullets in midair. Finally, head-tracking is used to allow players to dodge bullets by physically moving their body or head. 3.1 Game Design In traditional first person shooters, players move a mouse to aim a reticule centered on the screen. Players line up their shot by centering the screen over a target before firing. The mouse is effectively used to simulate player gaze. Ideally, players would simply look at a target and shoot. The problem is that using the eyes to control aiming and player orientation in a virtual world is difficult. Figure 2. Schematic diagram of game apparatus. With eye-based control, players move in the direction they look at [8]. While this is a very natural input technique removing the intermediate step of moving the mouse, it can become difficult for players to walk in one direction while looking at another. If players attention is temporarily distracted by an interesting event, they may inadvertently change orientation towards the event. Isokoski and Martin [3] also examined the issue of gaze-based controls in first person shooters. In their game, player position and orientation was controlled by the keyboard and mouse. Eye­tracking controlled the aiming reticule on screen. Players simply look at a target and press the right mouse button to shoot. Initial results showed that using an eye tracker did not improve performance compared to a keyboard and mouse configuration for a traditional first person shooter. It is possible that players were overloaded with too many control tasks (position, orientation, aiming) in the above research. On­rails shooters simplify controls by removing player control of movement and orientation. Movement and orientation are controlled by the game along a pre-determined path, similar to a roller coaster. Removing movement and orientation controls allows players to focus on aiming at targets on screen, like in a shooting gallery. Dodge It! takes inspiration from on-rails shooters by reducing player control to movement and aiming. As players move their head/body, the in-game camera moves in the same direction. By removing rotation around the three axes, players are only concerned about objects in front of them. An added benefit is that players remain in view of the camera. Unlike traditional first person shooters, where the reticule is locked in the center of the screen, players are free to aim anywhere in Dodge It! The reticule simulates player gaze. By separating player position from aiming, players can freely move in one direction while aiming in another. An obvious approach in on-rails games where players do not control their movement is to control aiming via head-tracking. We believe that due to the dual problems of accuracy of the head­tracking hardware and the difficulties of moving the head in one direction while wanting to look in another makes this impractical, just as Bérard s experiments have shown head-tracking to be a poor pointing technology for document editing tasks [2]. 3.2 Game Apparatus Dodge It! is played with a large projection screen and 5.1 surround sound system. Figure 2 shows a schematic diagram of the game apparatus. Solid/dashed arrows indicate wired/wireless connections. IR light tracking techniques are based on WiiDesktopVR. Head and cursor tracking is achieved using a pair of sensor bars (or IR LEDs) and Wii Remotes. Head-tracking is implemented by placing a sensor bar on the player s head (see Figure 3; Wii Remote H captures Sensor Bar H). A Wii Remote placed near the screen is then used to keep track of the position of the sensor bar/head. Reticule tracking is similar to head-tracking except in reverse (Wii Remote R captures Sensor Bar R). Players hold a Wii Remote in their hand while a second sensor bar is placed near the screen (see Figure 4). 4. DISCUSSION We held an informal play session for three participants to try out Dodge It! Participants enjoyed the game and were surprised at how well the motion tracking worked. One player stated: I liked that I had to jump around. It was really fun. They found head tracking intuitive for dodging tasks and enjoyed how body movements had an effect on the game, unlike traditional shooter games. Another player said Motion tracking worked really well. I was impressed by how easy it worked. It was fun too; I would definitely play it again. They did not perceive any latency between head movements and actions on screen and found the game, Surprisingly fun, surprisingly responsive. There was very little lag. There were also some criticisms of the game. Players commented that the game was a little too easy; projectiles should travel at a higher velocity and use predictive aiming. Finally one player found the head-tracking sensor bar to be unsteady, and worried that it might fall off other players heads. Ideally, players would use eye-gaze to simply look and fire at targets. However, short ranged eye tracking would not work in this game since players stand several feet in front of a large display. Formal experimentation will be needed to quantify this system s responsiveness, accuracy, and intuitiveness. However, the players positive feedback about these attributes indicates that incorporating head-tracking into shooting games can provide an enjoyable and immersive gaming experience. WiiDesktopVR is a technology demo. It was not intended to be a flexible system or library for use in other applications. As a result, we required some time to understand the code and recast it for our purposes. The code was, however, well-written and we did not need to modify the head/IR tracking code. To convert the tech demo into a shooting game, we added hit detection, projectiles, and particle systems code. 5. CONCLUSION Recent technologies such as the Wii Remote and Wii Balance Board have popularized gesture and movement-based interactions with interactive systems. These systems require direct manipulation of a device. Passive input devices such as eye and head-tracking systems are capable of capturing players attention as input for applications. While novel, these systems are typically expensive. Lee demonstrated how to create a low-cost head-tracking system with his WiiDesktopVR tech demo. This system was robust and its responsiveness was sufficient for typical video game applications. Using Lee s demo as a foundation we created Dodge It!, a simple shooting game that incorporates head-tracking technology. This game illustrates how certain pitfalls of eye-gaze based games can be avoided by separating player position/orientation from aiming. Informal tests with Dodge It! reveal an enjoyable and intuitive gaming experience. Players with minimal training easily adapted to the ability to dodge projectiles by simply moving their body. They found the head-tracking to be responsive and perceived little to no latency. Ideally, eye-gaze would replace aiming with a controller; however, with Dodge It! we have shown how to develop an enjoyable and immersive game within the limitations of a low­cost head-tracking system. Future work would involve experimentally quantifying this system s responsiveness, accuracy and intuitiveness. 6. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We would like to thank Rob Fletcher, Tad Stach, and Chris Wolfe for helping us with the game. 7. REFERENCES [1] Ascension Technology Corporation. Flock of Birds. www.ascension-tech.com. 2007. [2] Bérard, F. (1999) The Perceptual Window: Head Motion as a new Input Stream. In Proc. INTERACT 1999. Edinburgh. August 30 September 3 1999. article_rec.title: Exaggerated head motions for game viewpoint control

abstract.par:
In this paper, we present an evaluation of exaggerated headcoupled camera motions in a game-like 3D object movement. Three exaggeration levels were compared to determine if the exaggeration was more beneficial than a realistic 1:1 mapping.

The results suggest that there is some user preference for this type of exaggeration; however, no significant differences by the experimental conditions were found, other than a learning effect.
