fulltext.ft_body: The Procedural Planning System used in the Agent Architecture of Games Yingying She Concordia University 1515 St. Catherine St. West Montreal, Canada yy_she@cse.concordia.ca ABSTRACT We discuss a procedural planning approach that automat­ically and dynamically generates plans for game agents in real-time. This approach is applied to the design of an agent architecture in our current research project, Gameme, a game design application. This planning depends on o.­line goal design, the structure of the agent architecture, and real-time planning mechanisms. The Procedural Planning System (PPS) is capable of improving agents control for real-time goal processing in games. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.11 [Arti.cial Intelligence]: Distributed Arti.cial In­telligence multiagent systems; K.8.0 [Personal Comput­ing]: General games General Terms Agent architecture, Procedural planning system. Keywords Game, agent, planning, goal oriented design 1. BACKGROUND AND INTRODUCTION The goal of AI in games is not to compute optimal behav­ior for winning against the player but rather to endure so that the outcome is as believable and entertaining as possi­ble [4]. The dominant paradigms of agent architectures in­clude the Subsumption Architecture [2], the Multi-Layered Architecture [1] and the PRS. The PRS is a general-purpose reasoning system designed in a broad range of control sys­tem. Our approach of the agent architecture in Gameme uses the PRS as the major reference. The PRS is featured with Beliefs , Desires , Plans and Intentions . Appli­cations of the PRS provide signi.cant support for develop­ing the action-selection mechanism, a hierarchical library of plans, and a separate, specialized mechanism for reprioritiz­ing the agent s attention response to the environment [3]. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page.To copyotherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. Peter Grogono Concordia University 1515 St. Catherine St. West Montreal, Canada grogono@cse.concordia.ca The o.-line design in Gameme uses AI planners, such as GOBTs(Goal Oriented Behavior Trees) [7] and FSMs, to present behaviors and goals in hierarchical architectures. The real-time goal processing require the agent architec­ture to include attention-focusing, goal planning and learn­ing mechanisms in order to create intelligent, autonomous and believable agents in games. The agent architecture in Gameme was inspired by the Nilsson s Teleo-Reactive Archi­tecture [5], and consists of the perception tower, the pred­ication tower and the action tower. It runs in cycle, and combines functionality of sensor, goal processing, decision making, and sending. 2. THE PROCEDURAL PLANNING The concept of distinguishing between procedural and de­scriptive has been advocated for a long time, and it still has explanatory power. During steps of game design, Gameme has to transfer game designers rough and symbolical idea into C++ programs that can actually run the game in com­puters. It is a process from loose validation to strict valida­tion. So we consider that the process of generating a game is a process from descriptive stage to procedural stage. If we zoom in the scope to the agents control level, the descrip­tive (or logical) planning of agents activity, which describes states of agents in di.erent situations, has to become the procedural (or presentation) format, which speci.es how the planning should be presented in real-time. In the agent architecture of Gameme depicted in Figure 1, the predication tower is a PPS customized for agents con­trol in games. The PPS consists of four main components connected by an interpreter. The interpreter exchanges in­formation with these four components and drives the process of sensing, reacting, planning and learning. The .rst com­ponent is a database of knowledge. It is knowledge of game environment sensed by the perception tower and memories built from previous planning cycle. The second component is a set of desires, or goals. These goals are prede.ned o.­line and take forms of GOBTs or FSMs based on production rules. The third component is a list of plans, or goal execu­tion orders. They are in the form of a set of goals or game states in sequences. In detail, the execution order for each GOBT indicates the path of traverse the tree in order to accomplish the goal which is the root node [7]. Each plan is a list of subgoals or states toward achieving a particular end. The .nal main component is a set of priority queues of intentions, or priority factors. Priority factors in the same priority queue represent importances of goals for an agent. A priority queue for an agent indicates that only one goal is Figure 1: The arbitrator actually driving the agent s activity at a time, but multiple goals may be on the priority queue. The execution order and priority factors are prede.ned o.-line, and used in the real-time procedural planning. The PPS is designed to avoid problems such as slow plan­ning, and failure in dynamical planning. Planning is a basic technique for the agent to reason about how to achieve its objectives [8]. The planner s search is the last obstacle in reliably planning fast enough for real time [6]. Especially, the game rendering requires the PPS to construct a par­tial plan for each agent before rendering a new frame. The planning repeatedly operates a short processing cycle. Each agent can only focus on one goal at a time. So the partial plan is a part of a goal s execution order of an agent. If the predication tower decides to switch to another goal in the next cycle of planning, the plan is changed to a game state in another goal s execution order. If there is no need to change the current goal, the agent will continue to exe­cute next state in the same plan. This result is intentional goal oriented planning in which game agents activities are expanded in a manner analogous to the execution of subrou­tines in procedural programming systems. The interpreter in the PPS is the key component in the predication tower. It repeatedly executes the set of activi­ties depicted in Figure 2. At any particular running cycle of the PPS, certain goals are established and sent to the game rendering engine. There are seven planning activities in the PPS. (1) The knowledge is transfered from the perception tower to be processed. Also, knowledge includes goals and states which were memorized in the previous planning cycle. (2) The knowledge is used as conditions for searching match­ing results in rules. (3) If agents need to switch goals, several candidate-goals priority factors are checked, and new goals are chosen. (4) Based on new goals, new states of speci.c agents can be found in execution orders. (5) On the other hand, if there is no need to change current goals, agents next states are gotten from execution orders. (6) After planning, agents new states are sent to the action tower. (7) Finally, agents new states and associated goals are recorded for the next round of planning. 3. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK We have presented a Procedural Planning technique to be used in the game agent architecture of Gameme. The main contribution is the procedural knowledge approach used in the game agents planning in real-time. It allows action Figure 2: The interpreter cycle selection to be reactive within a complex runtime game envi­ronment, rather than relying on memory of prede.ned plans. In the future, we still have to design more experimental game scenarios to test the agent architecture in Gameme. Also, we would like to test Gameme with a number of di.erent game types. 4. abstract.par: In contrast to traditional teaching-and-learning environments whereby the teacher controls the learning (e.g., teacher-centered), video games present a learner-centered approach to learning whereby the student controls their learning experience through interactivity. Despite the many benefits of a learner-centered approach, the use of video game technology in business-related curriculums and accounting in particular, has been sparse. By and large accounting education has remained based on "paper and pen learning". This paper describes an ongoing project that will see the development and evaluation of a strategy-based, learner-centered, interactive accounting simulation environment for undergraduate accounting curriculums. The interactive simulation is meant to place accounting education in a "game" environment.

fulltext.ft_body: Interactive Accounting Simulation Environment for Accounting Education and Training Andrew Milner, Andrew Hogue, Bill Kapralos, and John Friedlan Faculty of Business and Information Technology University of Ontario Institute of Technology 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, Ontario, Canada. L1H 7K4. andrew.milner@mycampus.uoit.ca {andrew.hogue, bill.kapralos, john.friedlan} @uoit.ca ABSTRACT In contrast to traditional teaching-and-learning environ­ments whereby the teacher controls the learning (e.g., teacher-centered), video games present a learner-centered approach to learning whereby the student controls their learning experience through interactivity. Despite the many bene.ts of a learner-centered approach, the use of video game technology in business-related curriculums and ac­counting in particular, has been sparse. By and large ac­counting education has remained based on paper and pen learning . This paper describes an ongoing project that will see the development and evaluation of a strategy-based, learner-centered, interactive accounting simulation environ­ment for undergraduate accounting curriculums. The inter­active simulation is meant to place accounting education in a game environment. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional Graphics and Realism Virtual reality General Terms Human Factors Keywords Accounting, serious games, interactive learning environment, game-based learning. 1. INTRODUCTION Traditional teaching-and-learning environments are often quoted by millennial students (the generation raised in the sensory-.ooded environment of digital technology and mass media e.g., the internet generation ) as boring since they Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5 2008. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. do not address the unique learning needs of this generation. In order for knowledge and skills to become fully under­stood, integrated, and accessible for future situations, mil­lennial students require reinforcement, application, repeti­tion, and often practice in a variety of settings and contexts [4]. In contrast to traditional teaching-and-learning envi­ronments whereby the teacher controls the learning (e.g., teacher-centered), video games present a learner-centered approach to learning whereby the student controls their learn­ing experience through interactivity. Video games provide students the opportunity to explore the inter-relationships of complex behaviors, sign systems, and the formation of social groups [1]. Video game technology has been adopted and applied to applications whose primary purpose is not entertainment. These are referred to as serious games. Seri­ous games support the development of analytical and spatial, strategic, recollection, and psychomotor as well as visual se­lective attention skills [2]. Further bene.ts of serious games include improved self-monitoring, problem recognition and solving, improved short-and long-term memory, increased social skills, and increased self-e.cacy. Commercial games whose primary focus is business do exist. Examples of such games include Theme Park World whose focus is on making pro.t and attracting customers, Hollywood Mogul focuses on making deals, hiring stars, and creating a movie production. An example of a more .nan­cially oriented business simulation is Mr. Bigshot which is a simple stock-market simulation. That being said, the use of video game technology in business-related curriculums and accounting in particular, has been sparse. By and large ac­counting education has remained based on paper and pen learning . Students respond to written questions by writing responses. Cases, which are commonly used by accounting educators, tend to be done this way. Only through in-class discussions are students able to experience the interactive nature of a case study. Although technology has been used in accounting educations, it has not been used to develop critical thinking skills and judgment. For example, spread­sheets are widely used for facilitating data analysis. Educa­tional versions of business accounting software are used in many business programs. These are bene.cial for teaching bookkeeping and the mechanics of accounting but are very limited in value insofar as teaching judgment. Using ac­counting software at the introductory level is especially lim­ited in value because most students enrolled in introductory .nancial accounting don t go on to become professional ac­countants. An additional limitation to these software pack­ages is that they do not allow students to see the impact of alternative treatments for a particular transaction (this limitation is appropriate for the software because in actual use, companies do not want their employees to have the abil­ity to change the accounting records. However, for student learning purposes, there is bene.t for students to see the impact of di.erent choices on the .nancial statements and on the economic consequences for the stakeholders who use those .nancial statements. Textbook publishers have cre­ated on-line tools to support students but these tools tend to be mechanical in nature. For example, one publisher has a tool that provides students with repetitive quantitative problems. The same problem can be provided an in.nite number of times so that the student can learn how to do a calculation. This process teaches students how to solve a particular type of quantitative problem but again, does not address critical thinking, problem solving, and judgment skills. The proposed project will see the development and eval­uation of a strategy-based, learner-centered, interactive ac­counting simulation environment (IASE) for accounting cur­riculums. The IASE is meant to place accounting education in a game environment. Accounting is a discipline that re­quires both the people who prepare accounting information and the people who use it to apply high-level thinking skills such as judgment, analysis, evaluation, inference, applica­tion, interpretation, and decision making to be successful. It is anticipated that the IASE will allow such skills to be developed in a fun and enjoyable manner. 2. OVERVIEW Accounting case studies require that the students read and understand the facts involved in a particular scenario, de­velop ideas surrounding possible solutions to the accounting problems presented, and construct an argument to support their decisions. These types of scenarios are limited due to the nature of the paper medium it is presented upon. Inter­active digital media fundamentally provides a richer medium to present information. As opposed to traditional textbook cases, interactive simulation is far more e.ective to engage the students in the task at hand. The standard evaluation method for such case studies are to have the student prepare a short argumentative essay explaining the choice of action and an argument supported by the case study facts. This is essential to hone the students analytical problem solving skills as well as further develop their communication skills. Rather than replacing the standard evaluation methods, we focus on the content delivery mechanism. The simulation will provide a way to explore the accounting case studies in an e.ective and interactive manner. The simulation is being developed using Panda3D, a freely available 3D engine that allows for 3D rendering and game development [3]. The IASE will have the user represented as a 3D accoun­tant avatar (either their own customization, or as a forced choice from standard templates). The avatar is fully con­trolled by the user and is allowed to roam through a 3D cityscape. Each building in the city provides information related to the current scenario at hand. Simulation con­trolled characters walk the streets, work in businesses, and are all interactive. As such, the user s avatar can approach characters within the simulation and ask a set of prede.ned questions or simply listen to their story. Using this method, the facts of the case study are presented in a non-linear fash­ion from possibly di.ering perspectives; for instance, the .­nancial perspective of a CEO can be di.erent than a desk clerk. The user has the option of tagging important infor­mation by attaching it to their clipboard . When the user is .nished the simulation, the clipboard can be utilized to formulate their opinion and arguments for the scenario. The distribution of the case studies is performed through a server-based push update. When the simulation begins, it contacts a central server and submits a query for available scenarios. If any new scenarios are available (at the instruc­tor s discretion), the case study is automatically pushed to the student s simulation. Multiple scenarios could be pushed to the student and triggered by events in the environment such as entering particular buildings or interacting with a particular character. The case study itself is represented as a set of scripts generated using a standard text editor or a custom built .ow-chart-based tool. This tool enables the in­structor to de.ne his/her own scenarios easily and not have to resort to programming low-level code. The scripts de­.ne the facts of the case, which character will present them, any event triggered actions, and all dialogue associated with the non-player characters. The di.culty of the scenario will be fully controlled through the de.nition of these scripts. Possible adversarial or contradictory information could be presented through some of the characters to force the stu­dent to evaluate all of the possible data associated with the case. 3. SUMMARY AND FUTURE WORK This paper has described an ongoing project that seeks the development of an interactive accounting simulation en­vironment for accounting education and training. The sim­ulation will address a large gap between traditional account­ing teaching methods (which rely on pen and paper learn­ing ), and the needs of millennial students which dictates active learning through interaction. Future work includes completion of the simulation followed by focus group test­ing amongst students, educators, and accountant experts and .nally, the incorporation of the simulation within a un­dergraduate accounting course in order to determine the ef­fectiveness of the simulation. Acknowledgments The .nancial support of the University of Ontario Institute of Technology, in the form of a Teaching Innovation Fund award, is gratefully acknowledged. 4. REFERENCES [1] J. P. Gee. What Video Games Have to Teach Us About Learning and Literacy. Palgrave MacMillan, New York, NY. USA, 2003. [2] A. Mitchell and Savill-Smith. The use of computer and video games for learning: A review of the literature. www.LSDA.org.uk, 2004. [3] Panda3D. A 3D engine. Carnegie Mellon Entertainment Technology Center. www.panda3d.org. [4] B. It also helps build effective team relationships which is essential for optimal health care delivery. Interactive virtual simulation environments, such as serious games, can be used to augment traditional classroom-based interprofessional teaching methods as multiple team members may participate in the simulation simultaneously regardless of their physical location or time of day. Here we describe the Interprofessional Care Simulator for interprofessional education.

fulltext.ft_body: Interprofessional Care Simulator for Critical Care Education Brent Cowan1, Matthew Shelley1, Hamed Sabri1, Bill Kapralos1,3, Andrew Hogue1,3, Michelle Hogan2,3, Michael Jenkin4, Sandra Goldsworthy2,3, Louise Rose5, and Adam Dubrowski5 1Faculty of Business and Information Technology, 2Faculty of Health Sciences, 3Health Education Technology Research Unit University of Ontario Institute of Technology, 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, Canada. L1H 7K4. 4Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Centre for Vision Research, York University, 4700 Keele St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. M3J 1P3. 5Lawrence S. Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing, University of Toronto, 155 College St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. M5T 1P8. adam.dubrowski@utoronto.ca {bill.kapralos, andrew.hogue}@uoit.ca ABSTRACT Interprofessional education is a pedagogical approach which allows health care practitioners to develop a clear under­standing and appreciation of the roles, expertise, and unique contributions of their disciplines as well as those of the other participating health care providers. It also helps build e.ec­tive team relationships which is essential for optimal health care delivery. Interactive virtual simulation environments, such as serious games, can be used to augment traditional classroom-based interprofessional teaching methods as mul­tiple team members may participate in the simulation si­multaneously regardless of their physical location or time of day. Here we describe the Interprofessional Care Simulator for interprofessional education. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional Graphics and Realism Virtual reality General Terms Human Factors Keywords Interporfessional education, serious games, active learning. 1. INTRODUCTION inter-disciplinary initiatives to disease management imply that no one healthcare professional can tend to all of the health concerns a patient may experience [2]. In fact, the Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5 2008. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. majority of patients interact with more than one health pro­fessional and most patient care requires the collaboration of a team of health professionals working together either in the same space or scattered throughout several hospi­tals or departments. E.ective team relationship is essential for optimal care delivery. Providing such interprofessional training is a challenge given the varied backgrounds of the health care providers involved and the practical di.culties associated with coordinating a large geographically disperse group. Interprofessional education (IPE) is a pedagogical ap­proach which allows health care practitioners to develop a clear understanding and appreciation of the roles, exper­tise, and unique contributions of other disciplines as well as those of the other participating health care providers. By exposing health care providers to interdisciplinary collab­oration early in their career, it can alleviate biases before they begin. For licensed practitioners, IPE is a typical ap­proach used during skills maintenance training and further professional development. Despite the bene.ts of interpro­fessional education, it is not currently a major component of health care education and training. In addition, most healthcare providers and educators have very little formal experience with respect to interprofessional education and any interprofessional learning that does take place is typ­ically not part of mainstream clinical learning and thus is rarely included in the assessment process [5]. That be­ing said, our current health professional educational system fails to foster interprofessional skills and in fact, it has been argued that the traditional discipline-speci.c educational approach promotes attitudes that hinder interprofessional collaboration [1]. Furthermore, a lack of knowledge and re­spect for the capabilities of other professionals can lead to ine.ective and un-safe patient care [4]. Where available, current interprofessional education curriculums include tra­ditional classroom teaching, clinical placements, and prac­tice in simulation laboratories equipped with both high and low .delity medical manikins. However, such laboratories are expensive to build and maintain [3]. Furthermore, the use of simulation laboratories present signi.cant challenges Figure 1: Sample screenshots of a virtual hospital room with a patient, doctor, and nurse. in release from clinical responsibilities of team members, and are di.cult to coordinate amongst multiple team members. Because simulation laboratories are typically not a part of any particular hospital, but rather are centralized within academic settings, bringing the teams together for interpro­fessional training is often not feasible. In contrast to these three educational approaches, interactive virtual simulation environments, such as serious games, o.er a feasible alterna­tive as multiple team members may participate in the sim­ulation simultaneously regardless of their physical location or time of day. This paper introduces the Interprofessional Care Simu­lator (ICS), an interactive virtual simulation platform us­ing serious games technology to augment learning of skills, knowledge and attitudes requisite in interprofessional care (IPC). The interprofessional skills studied in this work are those needed by rapid response teams to optimize care de­livery in the management of critically ill patients. 2. OVERVIEW Within the ICS experts in critical care, education, and game development will construct a number of scenarios with speci.c learning objectives, feedback and predictors of at­tainment of the learning outcomes related to a critically ill patient. In each scenario, the critically ill patient requires the immediate attention of a critical care rapid response team which consists of a number of healthcare professionals including doctors, respiratory therapists, and nurses. Each response team member has a corresponding avatar within the simulation which is controlled by one trainee/student in a .rst-person perspective (see Figure 1). The simulation supports an online multi-player environ­ment allowing trainees to participate from remote locations. The patient presents several clinical concerns which increase in complexity and severity if not responded to appropri­ately. The goal of the trainees is to stabilize the patient. This is accomplished through the collaboration of response team members. Response team members are able to com­municate and interact amongst each other, the patient, and instruments/equipment within the virtual environment in order to accomplish their task. Virtual decision support systems will enhance information seeking behaviors of the team members. This is analogous to the current gold stan­dard in physical simulation using computerized mannequins and portable digital assistant devices. The patient role will be assumed by an instructor; an expert in critical care (in fu­ture versions, the expert .lling the role of the patient will be replaced by an arti.cial intelligence system). The instructor controls the patient avatar and responds to any actions of the critical care providers. For example, the patient may start to exhibit labored breathing. In this case, one of the nurses may respond by providing the patient with oxygen from an oxygen mask at which point the patient s breath­ing stabilizes and the oxygen saturation starts to increase to normal levels as indicated on the monitor. However, an inappropriate response on behalf of the health care provider could result in the patient s condition deteriorating further. The simulation is being developed using Panda3D, a freely available 3D engine that allows for 3D rendering and game development [6]. All models are being developed using Maya and/or 3D Studio Max. 3. FUTURE WORK Future work includes completion of the simulation fol­lowed by the testing of the content validity using survey and focus groups comprising of interprofessional critical care team members. The simulation will be modi.ed based on the outcome of user tests. Future work also includes replac­ing the instructor, expert .lling the role of the patient as currently implemented, by an arti.cial intelligence system. article_rec.title: Lessons from Brain Age on password memorability

abstract.par: User authentication involves establishing a user's right to access a system. Most user authentication is done with text passwords, which have advantages over other approaches, but more secure passwords are often difficult to remember. Nintendo's Brain Age games involve cognitive training which can improve memory. We examined Brain Age in search of insights towards helping users create and remember more secure passwords. Although Brain Age offers no techniques for memorising specific information, we discovered ideas for a new type of serious game that may help with password memorisation: Password Rehearsal Games.

fulltext.ft_body: Lessons from Brain Age on Password Memorability Alain Forget1,2, Sonia Chiasson1,2, Robert Biddle2 1School of Computer Science & 2Human Oriented Technology Lab Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada {aforget, chiasson}@scs.carleton.ca, robert_biddle@carleton.ca ABSTRACT User authentication involves establishing a user s right to access a system. Most user authentication is done with text passwords, which have advantages over other approaches, but more secure passwords are often di.cult to remember. Nintendo s Brain Age games involve cognitive training which can improve memory. We examined Brain Age in search of insights towards helping users create and remember more secure passwords. Although Brain Age o.ers no techniques for memorising speci.c information, we discovered ideas for a new type of serious game that may help with password memorisation: Password Rehearsal Games. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.6.5 [Management of computing and information systems]: Security and protection: Authentication; K.8.0 [Personal Computing]: General games General Terms Design, Human Factors, Security Keywords Memory, passwords, serious games, usable security 1. INTRODUCTION In computer security, the concept of user authentication involves establishing a user s right to access or modify sys­tem resources. Most authentication systems employ text passwords, and despite some weaknesses, they have advan­tages over alternatives: physical tokens can be lost or stolen, and biometrics can infringe on privacy. We are researching ways to improve users ability to authenticate securely and easily with passwords. We found claims that Nintendo s Brain Age games improve memory. In our examination of Brain Age, we noticed the games might be adapted as a new type of serious game: Password Rehearsal Games (PRGs). Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. Future Play 2008 Toronto, Ontario, Canada. November 3-5, 2008 Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 ...$5.00. PRGs could help users deeply rehearse their passwords while maintaining their engagement. Rehearsal is understood as a key technique to assist long-term memory [1], and thus might assist users at better remembering strong passwords. 2. BACKGROUND The key issues in password authentication are password strength and password memorability. Password strength re­lates to how di.cult it would be for an attacker to suc­cessfully guess the password. Unfortunately, users tend to choose easy-to-guess passwords containing common words and patterns [2]. Although online systems typically lock out attackers after a few incorrect guesses for a single account, attackers can target large numbers of accounts, giving them a good chance of guessing some of the accounts passwords. Increasing password strength is easy: a system can gener­ate long random passwords that have minimal risk of being guessed. However, users cannot remember such passwords. We are exploring methods of making small improvements to password strength [3] and improving memorability. The Brain Age series, Brain Age and Brain Age2, are Nin­tendo DS games based on brain and memory strengthening activities proposed by Kawashima [4]. His neurophysiol­ogy and brain imaging research [5] founded exercises to de­velop and maintain good cognitive functioning. Brain Age o.ers brain training and testing games involving memory, language, and mathematical exercises. In a framework guiding memory research, Craik and Lock­hart [1] describe two types of information rehearsal. Deep processing and rehearsal of information, such as interactive and thought-provoking stimuli, leads to greater memory re­call when compared to shallow rehersal, such as basic mental repetition. They also state that longer deep processing and rehearsal times increasingly improve memory performance. 3. PASSWORD REHEARSAL GAMES Our aim was to explore Brain Age .rst-hand, looking for design elements related to improving the memorability of strong passwords. We played the Brain Age games almost daily for approximately a month, making notes on design elements and discussing our .ndings. We found that the games involve taxing memory exer­cises aimed at improving general cognitive functioning, as opposed to remembering speci.c information, such as a pass­word. For example, if one wanted to remember a long com­plex password, the Brain Age games o.er no suggestions, techniques, or explicit practice for such memorisation. How­ever, some of the games may be adapted into Password Re­ Figure 1: Two Brain Age games: Connect Maze, where players connect characters in the proper or­der, and Symbol Match, where players write the symbol associated with the presented number. hearsal Games (PRGs) to assist users with password mem­orisation in several di.erent manners. PRGs present the user s same passwords in di.erent formats, allowing users to interact with their passwords in di.erent ways. This can help users perform a deep rehearsal of their passwords, in­creasing the potential for memorisation [1]. Some users may also more easily remember their passwords if they can vi­sualise them. PRGs can help such users discover visual mnemonics they can use to more easily recall their pass­words. We now present some examples of PRG adaptations of Brain Age and other memory games. Word Scramble: Brain Age s Word Scramble presents jumbled words that users must quickly unscramble. A sim­ilar PRG could have players quickly unscramble jumbled password characters by entering the correct password. Symbol Match: In our previous research [3], users often ignored symbols when selecting passwords because they are unfamiliar with typing them. Brain Age s Symbol Match game (Figure 1) associates the numbers 0 to 9 each with a symbol. During game play, the system shows a number and the user must quickly enter the correct symbol. Symbol Match could be adapted to train users to quickly .nd and enter special characters on the keyboard. Connect Maze: Connect Maze (Figure 1) players must quickly draw lines joining circles in sequence (A-1-B-2-C-3­. . . ) without touching other circles. Users could be asked to connect account names to the correct passwords. Low to High: In Low to High, users are given a 1-second glimpse of blocks containing numbers. Next, users are pre­sented with corresponding empty blocks and must touch the blocks in increasing order based on the previously-shown numbers. A user s password characters could be presented in jumbled order within blocks on the screen. When the char­acters disappear, users must identify the correct sequence of blocks corresponding to their password. Simon: While contemplating Brain Age games, it oc­curred to us that this familiar memory game could also be used for password rehearsal. In Simon, an early electronic game, four coloured buttons are presented, each associated with their own sound. The system begins by lighting up one button and playing its sound. The player must repeat the action by pressing the correct button. The system then replays the original combination and adds one more button to the sequence. The player repeats the new sequence. The game continues with ever-lengthening sequences until the player makes a mistake. A comparable PRG could intro­duce a password, one character at a time, having the user repeat the sequence so far. This approach might even help users memorise system-chosen random passwords. Memory: Similarly, in the old-fashioned game of Mem­ory, cards are placed face down and players may .ip two cards at a time to .nd pairs. If a match is not made, players must return the cards face down and try to remember the cards positions for later matches. A similar approach could be used to pair account names and passwords. 4. DISCUSSION These games are meant only as a supplement to the pass­word authentication process, not a replacement. After cre­ating a password in the regular manner using the normal in­terface, users could then quickly play one or more Password Rehearsal Games (PRGs) to help memorise their passwords. PRGs must reveal the passwords to help users learn them. However, since passwords are meant to be private, and play­ing PRGs are not required to log in, PRGs are intended to be played only on a well-secured (malware-free) computer in a private area (free of shoulder-sur.ng). Simple rehearsal of any information quickly becomes te­dious and boring. However, the same can be said about doing the series of arithmetic calculations, reading aloud, and other memory activities Brain Age players perform on a daily basis. This is because the Brain Age games are de­signed to be amusing, engaging, and challenging. Similarly, PRGs could assist users in remembering stronger passwords by rehearsing them in a fun and interactive way. 5. CONCLUSION We examined Brain Age for ways to help users remem­ber more secure text passwords. We found that Brain Age aims to improve players overall cognition and memory. Un­fortunately, Brain Age lacks any suggestions or techniques for recalling speci.c information (such as passwords). We explored some methods of adapting Brain Age and other memory games as Password Rehearsal Games designed to help users remember stronger passwords. 6. REFERENCES [1] F. Craik and R. Lockhart. fulltext.ft_body: World of Warcraft as a Ludic Cyborg Victoria McArthur York University, Toronto, Ontario vickymc@yorku.ca ABSTRACT This paper describes World of Warcraft as a ludic cyborg an entity that exists for play and depends on both artificial and organic components to survive. We argue that the popularity of the game arose due to the balance between the types of socialization it promotes and in-game literacies acquired by players on PvP servers. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0. [Personal computing]: General Games. General Terms Performance, Human Factors. Keywords Social Interaction, Social Computing, MMORPG, Ludic Cyborg. 1. INTRODUCTION Blizzard Entertainment s World of Warcraft (WoW) is currently the most popular game of the massively multiplayer online RPG (MMORPG) genre, with more than 10 million active players [11]. We attempt to explain the popularity of World of Warcraft by describing it as a ludic cyborg. In this paper the term ludic cyborg refers to an organism of artificial and natural systems existing for play, or ludus. The software and hardware supporting the game represent the artificial systems. The players themselves and their in-game actions represent the organic components. The most important artificial aspects we discuss include the mechanics of server types, the quest system, and the aggro radius. We also discuss player interactions and in-game literacies. Lastly, we present a discussion of the recent Alliance player boycott of the Alterac Valley battleground. We believe this to be the first academic account of the boycott, an important event that can help scholars understand what factors support the popularity of WoW. Since these observations were made on a specific player versus player (PvP) server, we do not aim to define the experience of all WoW players. Hence, while our argument may generalize to PvP servers, it may not to non-PvP servers. 2. RELATED WORK Scholars are already conducting qualitative research to explain the popularity of WoW [7, 4]. Ducheneaut et al. performed a quantitative study using WoW s scripting engine to collect character demographics on five servers. Their paper examines the spontaneous temporary groupings which often form when players encounter quests that are too overwhelming to be completed alone. They argue that WoW is effectively a Massively Single-Player Online Role Playing Game with the possibility for spontaneous multiplayer interactions [5]. Other work has examined the success of WoW in the context of various game mechanics such as player death [6]. Other work has examined the design of the game world as space [1]. We aim to add to this body of research by describing the success of WoW using the ludic cyborg analogy. 3. THE LUDIC CYBORG 3.1 Game Server Types There are four types of game servers in WoW: Normal, player versus player (PvP), role playing (RP), and role playing player versus player (RPPvP). We are particularly interested in PvP interactions, as we believe these are critical to the game s success. Players on PvP servers will initially find themselves in friendly zones. Above level 20, players will eventually have to venture into contested areas to progress in the game. Upon entering a contested territory, the player is automatically flagged for PvP combat, allowing any player on the opposing side to attack them. Players who do not desire this type of interaction can instead play on Normal server where the flag for PvP mode can be toggled on and off. RP and RPPvP servers offer the aforementioned types of interaction in addition to role playing. Players on these servers are encouraged to interact in character where the nature of these interactions are generally prescribed by high fantasy literature, within the context of the game s extensive background story. Previous work noted that the number of Normal servers outnumbered the PvP servers [5]. Nearly two years later, the number of PvP servers has increased drastically to match the number of Normal servers, suggesting increased player interest in this type of interaction [2]. 3.2 The Quest System Quests are one type of gameplay in WoW. Quests are accompanied with a background story informing the quest, formal objectives that must be met in order to successfully complete it, and the rewards for its completion. In this dialogue, the player can choose either to accept or decline the quest. If the player accepts, they can choose at any time to complete it or discard it [10]. There is little agency in quest completion since doing so involves enacting whatever role the game designers devised [9]. The only challenges quests present are navigation and strategy [10]. The limited number of distinct quest types and lack of agency in quest completion can easily lead to quest literacy. Once this literacy is gained, quest narrative becomes transparent, revealing the mechanical nature of questing. The introduction of human­piloted opponents helps to maintain the level of engagement in WoW as it compensates for the predictability associated computer­controlled enemies. The possibility of running into powerful enemy player characters while attempting to complete a quest adds a sense of real danger. While the quest system helps to sustain character development through in-game rewards, it is the PvP element that helps maintains engagement. 3.3 The Aggro Radius Aggro, short for aggravation, refers to the act of acquiring a monster s attention, which is how most NPC fights begin. We argue that PvP interaction also compensates for the predictability associated with the aggro radius in NPCs. Understanding the "aggro radius" is another type of in-game literacy acquired by players of WoW, which arguably, may detract from gameplay. The behaviour of virtual enemies is determined by artificial intelligence, which includes their aggro radius. While the exact formula for determining the radius for NPCs is not known, informal game testing in the community has noted that the aggro radius is observably larger for higher level NPCs in-world, making higher level monsters generally more threatening [12]. When one considers Csikszentmihalyi s theory of Flow [3], the need for the organic becomes apparent. Flow requires a balance between the difficulty of the activity and the abilities of the participant. Once a high level of literacy is achieved, the player may become bored with gameplay. Flow is improved in WoW by the addition of human-piloted enemies. The actions of such enemies are not governed by algorithms and AI, but rather, can be truly nondeterministic thanks to human intelligence. The ability for players to switch seamlessly between PvP and PvE type interactions organic and mechanical is one of the many qualities we attribute to the game s success. 3.4 The Alterac Valley Boycott Another avenue for PvP interaction in WoW are the battlegrounds, which feature a style of play similar to that popularized by competitive first-person shooters such as id Software s Quake 3 Arena . Players can join battleground queues by speaking to specific NPCs. Once enough players from each side have joined a queue, players enter the battleground instance and fight to achieve specific objectives (e.g., Defend/attack the mill , etc.). Currently there are four battlegrounds in WoW: Eye of the Storm, Arathi Basin, Warsong Gulch, and Alterac Valley. The objective in each battleground varies. In Alterac Valley, players must defeat the enemy NPC general and attempt to wipe out the enemy reinforcements. Players who participate in battlegrounds are able to acquire honor points for their contributions to their cause. Blizzard often adjusts game mechanics through regular patches. A patch released in November 2007, introduced changes to the Alterac Valley battleground widely believed to drastically favour the Horde. This prompted a boycott by Alliance players. Because so few Alliance players joined the battleground, the average wait times for Horde players rose to as high as 56 minutes [8]. Players of both sides noted how quickly the Alliance boycott of Alterac Valley got the attention of the publisher. The release of another patch in January 2008 supposedly addressed Alliance concerns [13]. This boycott is the most compelling illustration of World of Warcraft as a ludic cyborg. Lack of Alliance participation in the Alterac Valley battleground directly affected Horde participation and prompted a change in the game s mechanics. 4. CONCLUSION This paper discussed World of Warcraft as a ludic cyborg; an organism of artificial and natural systems where balance must be maintained in order to facilitate ludus. We conclude that while the mechanics of WoW are important, it is the introduction of human­piloted enemies that helps to maintain the level of engagement in World of Warcraft once various literacy curves are overcome. 5. fulltext.ft_body: Construction of Cybertypes in Lineage II: An Analysis of Game Interfaces and Support Documentation Victoria McArthur Tyler M. Pace Aaron R. Houssian York University Indiana University Indiana University vickymc@yorku.ca tympace@indiana.edu ahoussia@indiana.edu ABSTRACT This paper discusses social exclusion by analyzing the avatar creation interface of the massively multiplayer online roleplaying game (MMORPG) Lineage II. We use a previously developed syntagmatic-paradigmatic structure analysis for analyzing MMORPG interfaces and extend that method to include textual analysis of support documentation. This study concludes that virtual world designers must be more critical in their choices for representing sex and race. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0. [Personal computing]: General Games. General Terms Design, Human Factors. Keywords Avatar, MMORPG, Virtual World, Cybertype 1. INTRODUCTION It is estimated that there are over 17 million active subscriptions of Massively Multiplayer Online Role-Playing Games (MMORPGs) as of 2008, with Lineage II subscriptions representing approximately 6.3% of the total MMORPG market share [9]. As MMORPGs continue to gain acceptance and adoption in mainstream culture, players and designers need to be aware of the types of cultural data and biases presented in these games, or embedded in the game interfaces. 2. RELATED WORK Computers, like never before, are used for the creation, dissemination and consumption of cultural data (e.g., film, text, etc). All media, including virtual words, are created through a process of refashioning, translating and repurposing previous media [2]. Cultural data from film and literature, especially the high-fantasy genre, form the backbone of the cultural data embedded in most current MMORPGs. Virtual worlds also influence the cultural layer of new media, its organization, its emerging genres and its contents via a process called transcoding [5]. In other words, as cultural data influence virtual worlds, so do virtual worlds influence culture. Cybertypes, developed by Nakamura, are one such example of the recursive relationship between culture and computers [6]. In virtual worlds cybertypes are transcoded representations of remediated racial cultural data. The formation of cybertypes through Lineage II s character creation system and support documentation is the focus of this study. 3. METHODOLOGY The methodology used in this study was originally developed by Pace [8] based on prior applications of semiotics to the analysis of human-computer interfaces done by Bardzell [1] and Manovich [5]. Specifically, the semiotic notions of syntagm and paradigm are utilized to break down character creation interfaces into quantifiable categories. In semiotics, syntagms are strictly ordered structures composed of paradigms. A paradigm, then, is any individual option inside of a syntagm. When applied to character creation in Lineage II, a clear syntagm is defined for avatar creation: Race -Class - Sex. Furthermore, an additional syntagm is noted for constructing an avatars visual appearance: Hairstyle - Hair Color - Face (with sex and race dependent appearance options). Paradigms within each of these sytnagms are counted and an analysis of the resulting data forms the foundation for some of the results presented in this paper. Additionally, this paper extends Pace s method by including a textual analysis of the Lineage II support documentation made available on the official Lineage II website. It is important to note that the analysis conducted for this study restricted itself to the game interface and website. The actions and abilities of avatars inside the game world and the treatment of various avatars in the game world are not discussed in this study. 4. LINEAGE II 4.1 Character Creation Interface Character creation in Lineage II begins with selection of a playable race from Human, Elf, Dark Elf, Orc, Dwarf and Kamael. Once a race is selected the player is brought to a start screen with all the default (Type A) representative avatars, one for each class (fighter or mystic) and sex. Options for customizing the avatar s appearance can be seen in Table 1. It is notable that avatar body type is not customizable. 4.2 Racial Dimorphism Hair colour/style combinations have been limited to certain race/class combinations. It is worth noting that Orcs are the only race to have braids and dreadlocks in their available hairstyles, suggesting a stronger link between the fictional race and real-life ethnicities associated with these hairstyles. Table 1. Total avatar permutations for each human sex and class choice. Negative value for S. Dimorphism reveals that Permutations favour female characters. Male Fighter Female Fighter Male Mystic Female Mystic Hairstyle 5 7 5 7 Hair Color 4 4 4 4 Face 3 3 3 3 Permutations 60 84 60 84 Perms by Class 144 144 S. Dimorphism -24 -24 The minimal number of facial feature options total lack of skin tone modification lead to social exclusion. Humans, Elves, and Dwarves are undeniably white, Dark Elves are a pale blue/grey, and the Kamael have a pale gothic complexion. Orcs have dark green skin. The inability to create non-white avatars is a concern in other virtual worlds as well [3, 4, 8]. 4.3 Sexual Dimorphism The quantity of face and hair choices is identical between sexes with the exception of hairstyle. In all cases, females had 2 more hairstyle choices available to them than males. Hairstyle is a strong stereotype associated with femininity and even though it offers more female avatar permutations, the fact that it is the only way in which female permutations outnumber male permutations reinforces gender stereotypes. Differences between sexes are present in the textual information presented in the Lineage II character creation interface only for the Kamael race; a race added to the game with the release of the 1st Throne: The Kamael expansion in December of 2007. The language describing the strategic benefits of a male Kamael avatar use words like explosive nature and raw power , whereas the female is described as utilizing traps and deception and can be a valuable team player with elegant moves. [7] It is interesting to note that the team-support role was highlighted for female Kamael soldiers (who are presumably warriors of equal ability), while male Kamael are noted for their strength in battle. Female Kamael are placed into a stereotypical role of a subservient matriarch who is best left to assist, but not lead a band of brothers. The resting stances presented for male and female representatives of each race in Lineage II are also worth noting. Males tend to stand facing forward with their arms folded across their chest or at their sides. Females tend to stand facing slightly on an angle or with more weight on one foot than the other, with one hand delicately on the sternum, one or both hands on their hips, or both hands at their sides with their chest protruding. Differences in stances serve to further distinguish the sexes by supplying males with solid, powerful and direct stances and females with fetishized, curvy stances. The default armour for males and females also perpetuate traditional views of femininity. Females tended to wear skirts and sport attire that is more revealing of their bodies, calling into question the level of protection provided by their attire. 4.3.1 Sexual Dimorphism in Support Documentation On the game's website, the association between men and physical power versus women and mystical/intellectual power continues. For play style, the female Kamael soldier is described as follows: Female Kamael Soldiers are the almost exactly the same as Male Kamael Soldiers as far as available skills, but they have a far quicker attack speed and weaker attack power than their male counterparts The Female Kamael Soldier has less stamina and attack power than the Male Kamael Soldier, but she has greater attack speed. [7] Even in a virtual world where physical equality in between sexes is truly possible the male and female Kamael are designed to be purposefully distinct in terms of their physical prowess. 5. DISCUSSION/CONCLUSIONS The analysis presented in this paper is meant to shed light on the dangers and difficulties of new media composition. Designers must be very careful about what cultural data they choose to remediate when constructing cultural interfaces like virtual worlds. Unintended and subtle preferences given in virtual, cultural interfaces to males (usually white) may result in the further propagation of negative and repressive ideologies (racism and sexism) in the real world. When creating virtual worlds where equality is possible, designers must be more deliberate, intentional and inclusive with their designs. 6. REFERENCES [1] Bardzell, J. article_rec.title: Game 2.0 and beyond
article_rec.subtitle: an interaction design approach to digital game evolution

abstract.par: In this research, the authors discuss the evolution of video games from the viewpoint of interaction design. It is argued that recent video games are qualitatively different from earlier video games in their use of multiple user layers and novel domains. These qualitatively different newer games are referred to as Game 2.0, with older games being referred to as Game1.0. Appropriate design of interactions is presented as a key issue in Game 2.0 development. The relationship between game interfaces and computer interfaces is also considered.

These qualitatively different newer games are referred to as Game 2.0, with older games being referred to as Game1.0. Appropriate design of interactions is presented as a key issue in Game 2.0 development. The relationship between game interfaces and computer interfaces is also considered. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.5.2 [User Interfaces]: User-centered design. Input devices and strategies. General Terms Design, Human Factors. Keywords Interaction Design, Video Games, Game 2.0. 1. INTRODUCTION While traditional video games were targeted to a number of user segments, much of the revenue from video games has come from sales to core gamers who devote considerable amounts of time playing video games, often on high performance systems. These games have often involved various forms of combat, and quests, where players might seek to achieve a number of goals such as rescue the princess . However, recently developed games, such as Nintendo DS and Wii have been targeted to different market segments, and new types of game are being developed that depart significantly from traditional game genres. The radical changes that are occurring in gaming technologies and genres are leading to a qualitatively different generation of game machines and associated software, referred to here as Game 2.0 in contrast to earlier Game 1.0 systems. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. Mark Chignell University of Toronto 315 Bloor St W, Toronto, Ontario , CANADA +1-416-978-8951 chignel@mie.toronto.ca 2. EVOLUTION OF DIGITAL GAMES In this section, recent trends in game sales and software content are discussed. 2.1 Recent Game Sale Trends Japan is a leading maker and consumer of video game devices and software. In terms of recent (as of this writing) hardware sales in Japan, DS Lite ranked first with 9 million sets sold, while Wii ranked second with 7.5 million sets sold. The third best seller was PSP (Play Station Portable), with 6.5 million sets, followed by PS3 with 3.2 million sets. The dominance of the Nintendo DS and Wii systems was even greater in software, where Nintendo DS had almost half of the market (46.7%) and Wii holding a further quarter (26.6%) of the market. Thus the two leading systems controlled close to three quarters of the software market. 2.2 Contents of Game Software Game sales in Japan in January 2008 are used here to demonstrate the emergence of new gaming genres. The comments made in this section are based on the top 30 sales in the week from January 14 through January 20, 2008 in Japan [1]. A notable feature in the January 2008 sales data was that six games for Wii were in the top 10 and that 15 games for DS were in the top 30, demonstrating the dominance of those two systems. In addition, 18 of the top 30 games were portable, rather than targeted predominantly at standalone systems. In terms of types of games, 23 of the top 30 selling games in January 2008 fell into the following categories: action games (10), RPG games (3), adventure games (3), 2 action board games (2), simulation games (2, including action), shooting games (1), action and adventure games (1). The remaining seven games did not fit into traditional gaming genres. Two of the best selling games shown in this group of seven ( More Brain Training and Kanji Testing ) can be classified as edutainment, a category that seems to play a stronger role in the context of Game 2.0 than it did in traditional video games. Wii Beginning is a special type of software which encourages users to try various features of the Wii Remote Controller while Wii Fit focuses on fitness exercises. Two other games that are popular but also a departure from stereotypical video games of the past are DS Kakeibo (Housekeeping diary) and DS Bungaku Zenshu (Japanese Novels) which are targeted for everyday life and general reading, respectively. 2.3 Game 2.0 In addition to Gaming, revolutions are occurring, or seem likely to occur, in a number of domains: Web 2.0, Programming 2.0 [4], Human Interface 2.0 [3] and so on. In Table.1 Game 2.0 is compared with Game 1.0, focus on key characteristics that differ between the two generations of gaming. Note that the table highlights novel aspects of Game 2.0. For instance, while young men will no doubt remain an important segment within Game 2.0, it is the increased gaming by females and middle-aged people that differentiates Game 2.0 from Game 1.0 in terms of major user segments. Table 1 Game 1.0 and Game 2.0 Game 1.0 Game 2.0 Major Users Young men, core gamers Females, middle-aged people User Model Mass Personal Contents Immersion virtual space: Action game, RPG, Shooting, Simulation Real world oriented applications such as Language learning, Calculations, Novels, Cooking, Fitness Input Device A/B buttons and Cross key Character recognition, Voice recognition, Acceleration sensors Distance to screen 3feet (1m) 10feet (3m) or 1feet (0.3m) How to use TV set and game controller Big TV set and RC, or portable device Interruption No interruption Interruptible Initiative System Users Priority High performance, High precision User experiences Story Important Not Important 3. LESSONS LEARNED FROM GAME INTERFACES Games have evolved over a number of years in the face of strong competitive pressures and user demands. As a result, they are evolving much more rapidly than interfaces for other desktop software, such as business applications. Particular strengths of game interfaces are: (1) Quick to startup and to finish, (2) Easy to handle without reading documentation or taking courses, (3) Availability of mechanisms to help users learn, (4) Error tolerance. Users are rarely stopped and told they have made an error, (5) Efficient utilization of resources such as sound output. 4. DISCUSSION Nintendo DS and Wii are current instantiations of the evolving Game 2.0 interface. Many new games for DS relate to learning, and are much improved over earlier edutainment systems. However, further work is needed to strengthen the game element of these edutainment systems. Wii is advancing Game 2.0 interaction by providing working sensors that facilitate new genres, such as sports, fitness, and so on. While the discrepancy between Wii fit interfaces and the use of real training equipment is still large, there is considerable anecdotal evidence to suggest that many people find it a useful tool for assisting them to exercise. Norman once pointed out that users tend to blame themselves instead of blaming systems [6]. In his book The Design of Future Things [7], he said that users would learn better if they have greater self-awareness and responsibility. In Game 1.0, game users thought bad games were due to game software rather than themselves. But in Game 2.0, game users tend to blame themselves when they cannot master tasks. Game 2.0 interfaces need new ways to reward users in the face of the frustration and critical judgments of the self that accompany greater self­awareness and responsibility in game playing. 5. CONCLUSION What is Game 2.0? The following three features seem to be particularly important components of Game 2.0. (1) There is a shift in the demographics of gamers with more representation for women and the middle aged. (2) Game content has shifted from traditional immersion type games such as action games and/or adventure games to practical real world activities such as supporting learning or hobbies. (3) Game 2.0 interfaces are often portable and increasingly they are augmented reality interfaces with sensors. Aside from these features, perhaps the fundamental aspects of game interfaces are that they are emotional and motivating. Conventional user interfaces also need to be more emotional and motivating, and the emerging Game 2.0 paradigm challenges user interface researchers to find new designs and methods that can bring game-like excitement and rewards, in appropriate ways, to other tasks. 6. article_rec.title: Towards an AJAX-based game engine

abstract.par:
In recent years, browser games have considerably improved so that regarding the number of players they nowadays can compete with MMOGs. At the same time, they have abandoned their own principles by increasingly relying on proprietary technology.

In this paper, we propose the concept of a 2D single player game engine that is based on new Web 2.0 standards (especially AJAX) which promise to alleviate some of the problems that caused the mentioned technological shift. No additional platform besides a standard browser will be needed to run instantiated games, since the engine will be based on JavaScript. Game content will be loaded on-demand using an AJAX-compliant update mechanism.

fulltext.ft_body: Towards an AJAX-based Game Engine Christian Kletsch, Daniel Volk Institute for Software Technology Universitaet der Bundeswehr Muenchen 85577 Neubiberg, Germany {christian.kletsch, daniel.volk}@unibw.de ABSTRACT In recent years, browser games have considerably improved so that regarding the number of players they nowadays can compete with MMOGs. At the same time, they have abandoned their own principles by increasingly relying on proprietary technology. In this paper, we propose the concept of a 2D single player game engine that is based on new Web 2.0 standards (especially AJAX) which promise to alleviate some of the problems that caused the mentioned technological shift. No additional platform besides a standard browser will be needed to run instantiated games, since the engine will be based on JavaScript. Game content will be loaded on-demand using an AJAX-compliant update mechanism. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [General]: Games. Keywords Game Engine, AJAX, Web 2.0 1. MOTIVATION In a short span of time, browser games escaped their former antiquated image of simple card games, published on early, primitive websites. A completely new breed of browser games like Dofus or RuneScape have attracted millions of players and created a whole new market of its own, even competing with that of MMOGs (Massively Multiplayer Online Games). With this trend towards the mass market, also the requested quality level was raised to a formerly unknown level. This has forced the developers of such games to exchange standard web technology for a proprietary one, since current web standards didn t seem to suffice any more. Nowadays, most corresponding game-clients are either based on closed-source browser-plug-ins (mostly Flash) or built as completely independent and proprietary stand alone applications, demanding separate installations. Since most game clients come bundled with a complete copy of the corresponding game world, downloads also have become quite large. This new sort of browser games thus lost their former advantage of an instant-play feeling due to a technological arms race turning them into a kind of web-distributed standard games. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. Contrary to this trend, a new version of the Web called Web 2.0 emerged from the originally rather static document-delivery system. It introduced feature-rich web-pages that offer the experience of desktop applications. With the help of its core technology AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML), the former document-driven Web 1.0 is currently turning into a user­oriented and application-centric web. Within the next few years the browser seems to become the most important application, being the runtime environment for so called weblications that will replace a wide range of current desktop applications. Following this new trend of the Web, the idea of our approach is to develop a web-based 2D game engine that will be based on AJAX technology and thus will try to counter current trends towards proprietary browser game solutions by using Web standards again. 2. AJAX AND GAME ENGINES The Web 2.0 is closely related to the idea of the Rich Client, which characterizes a web site that handles a certain amount of user interaction by itself, instead of forwarding all requests to the corresponding server. Web pages are no longer static documents they are built dynamically within the browser, updating only necessary parts of their content [1]. Figure 1: AJAX / Game Engine This new mode of operation is illustrated on the left hand side of Figure 1. As can be seen, user input (within the user interface) is handled by a JavaScript-based AJAX engine that runs within the browser. This engine decides whether to propagate the request towards the server by the help of asynchronous XMLHttpRequests or to manipulate the Document Object Model (DOM) directly both being well-supported standards by now. This decreases reaction times substantially, thus enabling a rather responsive interface and shifting user experience from surfing a website to using a weblication . A responsive interface is also an important prerequisite for any kind of game (see the schematic overview of a game engine [2][3] on the right hand side of Figure 1). Here, the refreshing happens multiple times per second with typically just small changes per iteration within the primary game loop, which itself is based on the corresponding game timer that initializes the iterations. Besides updating the output (typically graphics and audio), the input in form of user-triggered events is handled and all computation (e.g., collision detection or executing game ai/ game scripts), is done resulting in changes of the dynamic game state. In this sense, a game engine is essentially a nicely interfaced simulation based on a content database providing the static game data. 3. ARCHITECTURE Since our architectural concept targets at a 2D single player game engine that is based on new Web 2.0 standards (especially AJAX), it basically is a conceptual merge of the two components from Figure 1 into the architecture shown in Figure 2. As a consequence, the shown game engine is realized as a JavaScript engine that runs within the browser. Figure 2: Early concept of the AJAX-based Game Engine (G Graphics, I Input, A Audio) The engine is planned to embody the concept of game states as its primary architectural pattern. This means that an instantiating game is understood as a state machine and therefore consists of definable states (e.g., maps or levels, but also different menus) and predefined transitions (e.g., a mouse click), which are able to bring about a switch of the main loop s running context. Graphical user interface (GUI) elements (such as menus or buttons) will be implemented using conventional AJAX frameworks, which already offer a reasonable range of standard interface elements. These just need to be consolidated in terms of a common style and can be provided as an interface layer that works on top of the core simulation routine of the main loop. The Output module will support 2D sprites (static and animated ones), that are visualized using the standard Canvas2D element. The graphical objects owned by the active state are contained in the render-batch-queue and accordingly are displayed by the main loop during refresh. In future, also SoundFX and background music will be supported. The Input module will offer two different modes of operation: polling of direct user interaction within the main game loop (e.g., handling the pressed forward -key) and event-based input for indirect user interaction (e.g., clicking a button within the game menu with your mouse). Our development will focus on a mouse­picking module that allows easy-to-use element selection within the game. Since loading necessary content on demand was one important aspect of the game engine, the development of the according Resource Manager will be a special focus of our development. This module will act as a layer of abstraction between the client­side game engine and a content database server. It will hide asynchronous data transmission using XMLHttpRequests objects from other game engine parts which only need to call a resource loading mechanism. Regarding the granularity of content (re)­load, two possible approaches appear to be useful: on a raw level, resources are bound to a specific game state and are therefore loaded when the game state is activated (e.g., the corresponding level is loaded); on a more fine level, it will be useful to load specific content on sight and in gradually enhancing quality levels. This would also imply to adapt the content model by implementing lazy-instantiated content containers, which deliver surrogate content until the real content is loaded by the Resource Manager. 4. SOME CONSIDERATIONS Of course, the use of an interpreted scripting language has its difficulties, since it is slower than binary execution. In addition to that, current rendering within browsers is not hardware­accelerated yet, which restricts the applicability of the engine even more. Finally, current browsers don't support real multithreading, thus reducing the level of possible computation executed by the main loop. While those restrictions appear to be quite massive at first, the huge benefit of using standard Web technology seems to outweigh them to a certain degree. Moreover, hardware­accelerated browser rendering (just think about the HTML 5 3D canvas element) and JavaScript JIT compilers (e.g., the Mozilla Tamarin project) are on the horizon already and will be available in a not too distant future. In this context, the approach we are currently developing might even act as a kind of feasibility study for a future multiplayer approach. 5. REFERENCES [1] Anderson, P., 2007. What is Web 2.0? Ideas, technologies and implications for education. Technical Report, JISC Technology and Standards, at http://www.jisc.ac.uk/ whatwedo/services/services_techwatch/techwatch/techwatch _ic_reports2005_published.aspx (last accessed 11.07.08) [2] Bishop, L., et al., 1998. Designing a PC Game Engine. IEEE Comput. Graph. and Appl., Volume 18, Number 1. IEEE Computer Society Press, Los Alamitos, CA, USA, 46-53 [3] Nacke, L., 2005. Facilitating the Education of Game Development. Diploma Theses, Otto-von-Guericke University, Magdeburg, Germany

article_rec.subtitle: turning game history students into pinball designers

abstract.par: The pinball machine is an endangered species. Often cited as a historical touchstone for video game levels, their pedagogical value is clear. Yet it is becoming difficult to find operational machines for students to play and analyze. However, by using Internet-based pinball design and history resources, and a shareware package called Future Pinball, the authors have been able to surpass the original pedagogic goals of a pinball analysis assignment. A new approach has been developed to convert a merely observational process into a constrained early design project; blending thematic and functional analysis, design and the benefits and challenges of constraints into a successful active learning experience. This paper will discuss the design and benefits of the experience and highlight examples of exemplary student work at both the graduate and undergraduate level.
