fulltext.ft_body: Kickback: Turning Game History Students into Pinball Designers Stephen Jacobs Game Design and Development Rochester Institute of Technology +1 585 475 7803 sxjics ** at ** rit.edu ABSTRACT The pinball machine is an endangered species. Often cited as a historical touchstone for video game levels, their pedagogical value is clear. Yet it is becoming difficult to find operational machines for students to play and analyze. However, by using Internet-based pinball design and history resources, and a shareware package called Future Pinball, the authors have been able to surpass the original pedagogic goals of a pinball analysis assignment. A new approach has been developed to convert a merely observational process into a constrained early design project; blending thematic and functional analysis, design and the benefits and challenges of constraints into a successful active learning experience. This paper will discuss the design and benefits of the experience and highlight examples of exemplary student work at both the graduate and undergraduate level. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.3.0 [Computer Education]: General; K.8.0a [Personal Computing]: General - Games General Terms Design, Theory. Keywords Game Design History, Pedagogy. 1. INTRODUCTION The Rochester Institute of Technology offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in Game Design and Development. Both programs offer coursework that explores history and analysis of games and electronic and digital media. In the original course designs there was an assignment in which students were asked to play and analyze pinball machines. Pinball machines were selected for an early analysis assignment not only for their historical value but also because their design and development provides a constrained analogue to videogames Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. Christopher A. Egert Game Design and Development Rochester Institute of Technology +1 585 475 4873 cae ** at ** it.rit.edu in general [1]. Pinball machines are also a topic with which this generation of game students has little experience across the board, so there s a level playing field for students in terms of their research experience for the assignment. Unfortunately, it is becoming harder and harder to find a wide variety of machines for students to gain hands-on experience with. The impact of this shortage on the assignment is that its value is reduced when 15-30 students have an overall pool of a mere 5-8 machines nearby to play and analyze. Fortunately a freeware package, Future Pinball [2], is available for design and construction of playable virtual machines and its use in the assignment moves students from players to designers. 2. INTERNET PINBALL RESOURCES There s a surprising depth to the topic of pinball [1]. The large and active pinball community on the Internet provides a wealth of detailed information for students on history, vocabulary, design, and construction. Resources such as the Pinball Arcade Preservation Society [3] describe the types of machines available and their place in the chronology of machine development. Chuck s Arcade [4], describes experiences related to the restoration and play of pinball machines. The Internet Pinball Machine Database, is an ambitious attempt to put everything known about every model on-line [5]. The glossary and the section on skills required to play the game (including mental skills) offer an incredible depth and are valuable resources in and of themselves [6]. [paradigm] A Look into the Pinball Design World [7], outlines the early design approaches and the fundamental elements of pinball machine construction. Pat Lawlor Design [8] explores the entirety of the design and construction process with exacting detail. Finally, students can research modern pinball machine development via an in-depth review of the Spiderman pinball game [9]. 3. FUTURE PINBALL Future Pinball is a full-featured 3D pinball development package that allows the user to design and play virtual pinball machines. The software is freeware and runs on Microsoft Windows XP and Vista. It can be found at http://www.futurepinball.com/ along with a 12-page tutorial originally published by PC World magazine and a forum. These resources, and the fact that the scripting language for the program is a variant of Microsoft Visual Basic, make the package very useable by students with some programming experience and provides for a minimal learning curve. 4. THE NEW PINBALL ASSIGNMENT An important aspect of the new assignment is that it combines analytical and historical research work and then reinforces them with a design and implementation phase. It also provides a constrained design problem, which the authors experience has shown to be extremely valuable for a game design student; who is often confronted with the ability to almost literally do anything. Students were asked to design a working pinball machine around one of three themes: Narrative (based on an existing book, for example) Non-Narrative (for example a sport or an environment like a carnival) or Video Game (replicating a game s s play style.) As part of the assignment specification, the completed machine had to use a minimum of three advanced features including, but not limited to Spinners, Ramps, Multiball, additional Flippers, Diverters, Split Levels, and Habitrails. The hardcopy report had to contain a playfield design sketch (that must be approved before the student starts building), an explanation of the thought process that went on during the theme selection and design, as well as the play instructions and citations for the graphics and sound if they were not original. 5. EXAMPLES OF STUDENT TABLES Graduate Student Brendan Parker s narrative inspired game explored the duality in the nature(s) and tendencies of Stevenson s Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. To punctuate these elements, Brendan chose an enforced two-player approach to express the tensions in the struggle for identity and purpose. The playfield is identical on both sides of the centered ball chute. The real gameplay challenge is the struggle to control one side of the playfield or the other, mirroring the struggle between the Jekyll and Hyde personalities for control. Graduate Student Joshua Gilpatrick chose to address the challenge of giving a single player a sense of participating in a team sport in his non-narrative, soccer-themed machine. The top and bottom of his playfield represents the two sides of the soccer field. The opening kick is represented by the ball dropping into play on top of a spinner in the center of the machine. This randomizes the direction of the ball after it hits the field. The opposing team s goalie is represented by a row of pop-ups and the player s goal is represented by a pop-up in front of the drain and a kickback on the left side of the playfield. Undergraduate Carl Kelso s videogame-inspired design referenced Portal. Specifically the table represented the Portal mechanic by using a pair of sinkholes capable of either capturing or ejecting a ball. When the lower sinkhole takes a ball, a second ball gets launched out of the upper sinkhole, and vice versa. 6. SUCCESS OF THE ASSIGNMENT Students experienced a few occasional technical frustrations like a few obscure bugs in the system and documentation that lacked clarity in spots. These, however, were few and far-between and to be expected to a certain extent when using a freeware (or if one is cynical, any) software product. The difficulties were overcome by class discussion and student peer support on-line and in person. Pedagogically, a few students submitted tables that confused a theme with a mechanic. For example, one student created a table titled Multiball Madness , which was entirely based around the multiball function (as named!) Students presented (and played) their completed projects in class, so these missteps became learning opportunities. Ensuing discussion served as a platform to explore gameplay, technology mechanics and the differences between the two. While it is too early in the use of this approach to have extensive quantitative data on its superiority over the analysis paper approach there are early qualitative indications that indicate that it is true. Two-thirds of both Graduate and Undergraduate tables that were turned in exceeded the requirements of the assignment. Only one or two analysis papers per quarter exceeded requirements over the past several years. Comments from student evaluations included Making a pinball machine was certainly a good example of game history and storyline development over the decades The Future Pinball and Level design comments were also pretty useful and important This was a good assignment because for some students it was their first open-ended programming assignment. I put a lot of work into the pinball assignment. I thought it was the most fun homework assignment I ve ever had Readers of this paper can download the student tables referenced at http://games.rit.edu/studentpinball. The authors would like to thank our game design and development students (both those cited above and the overall student pool in general) for their contributions. 7. REFERENCES [1] Turkle, S. 2003. Video Games and Computer Holding Power. In The New Media Reader, MIT Press, N. Wardrip-Fruin and N. Montfort, Eds., Cambridge, MA, 499-513. [2] Leathey, C. 2008. Future Pinball Home Page. article_rec.title: Canvas 3D JS library

abstract.par: Web browsers do not have a standard method of creating/delivering 3D content. The Canvas 3D add-on for Firefox 3, which will become part of the browser in a future release, allows the delivery of 3D content via the canvas element. However, 3D is a complex problem. This paper proposes a library built on top of the Canvas 3D that will help simplify the creation of 3D content within the browser.

fulltext.ft_body: Canvas 3D JS Library Catherine Leung Andor Salga Andrew Smith Seneca College Seneca College Seneca College 70 The Pond Road 70 The Pond Road 70 The Pond Road Toronto, Ontario Toronto Ontario Toronto Ontario 416-491-5050 (ext 3148) 416-491-5050 (ext 3148) 416-491-5050 (ext 3148) catherine.leung@senecac.on.ca asalga@learn.senecac.on.ca andrew@littlesvr.ca ABSTRACT Web browsers do not have a standard method of creating/delivering 3D content. The Canvas 3D add-on for Firefox 3, which will become part of the browser in a future release, allows the delivery of 3D content via the canvas element. However, 3D is a complex problem. This paper proposes a library built on top of the Canvas 3D that will help simplify the creation of 3D content within the browser. Categories and Subject Descriptors D.2.1.3 [Reusable Software]: Reusable Library General Terms Design, Experimentation Keywords JavaScript, Canvas, browser, 3D, library 1. INTRODUCTION The Canvas 3D JS Library (C3DL for short) is an open source JavaScript library that will facilitate the creation and manipulation of 3D scenes and objects within a web page. The library is built on top of the canvas 3D add-on for the Firefox 3 browser. This add-on allows the creation of OpenGL contexts within the canvas area of a page. C3DL makes it easier for those with very little 3D programming experience to use Canvas 3D. Web pages currently have very little 3D content. Aside from not having much native browser support for real 3D, the whole process of creating 3D content is typically more difficult than the creation of 2D content. The current method of providing 3D content typically involves using a plug-in such as Flash player. Papervision 3D [1,2] for example uses this method of 3D content delivery. 3D content is displayed within the player but is not actually part of the DOM Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2008, November 3-5, 2008, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Copyright 2008 ACM 978-1-60558-218-4 $5.00. (Document Object Model). Thus, while 3D content can be delivered in this manner, it is still separated from the web page. Canvas 3D [3,4] is an add-on written by Vladimir Vukicevic. This add-on allows the creation of an OpenGL context within an area of the web page defined by the canvas tag, allowing the creation of 3D scenes within the canvas area. Unlike a third party plug-in, the canvas is an element of the DOM meaning that, it can manipulate and be manipulated by other parts of the web page easily and its content is fully visible to web crawlers. The problem is that OpenGL programming is typically difficult. It involves a good deal of math and a solid understanding of 3D programming. For most people, programming in OpenGL would be far too large a hurdle to overcome. C3DL is a library that is designed to simplify the creation and manipulation of 3D objects and scenes within the canvas. Different people will use 3D on the web in different ways. A web designer may only want to use 3D to create a simple but eye catching 3D effect. Others may want to create an entire 3D world in the browser. With this very wide spectrum in mind, the canvas 3D library is designed to make 3D content creation as simple as possible while keeping it efficient enough to handle large amounts of data. 2. C3DL 2.1 Basic Design C3DL is written entirely in JavaScript to enable delivery as part of a web page's content. A person viewing a page created with our library would not need to find and download the library itself as it is part of a sites web page. A developer using the library can create and manipulate a 3D scene by using JavaScript and simple function calls to our library. As much as possible, our library hides the heavy math and OpenGL calls. 2.2 Steps to create a scene with C3DL To create a scene using C3DL, the developer will need to: Decide on the context (canvas 3D provides 2 contexts that closely follow the OpenGL ES 1.1 and OpenGL ES 2.0 spec) Create a Scene object Associate the Scene with the id of the canvas the Scene will be displayed in Add in a camera, objects and lights Start the scene 2.3 Model format Initially we had stored all our model data in separate arrays that indexed the vertices, faces and texture uv's. Recently we have switched to loading Collada files [6]. Currently we are able to load models stored in Collada files as triangles and Quads 2.4 Performance Canvas 3D makes use of the video card when it can. For functions that are unsupported on the video card, software emulation is done. Depending on the video card of your system, performance can be severely impacted. The following performance benchmark was done on a MacBook Pro with an NVIDIA 8600 video card. The model used for this benchmark was a teapot model with 1024 triangles. The texture was a 512X512 image. The benchmark program creates a number of teapots and rotates all of them randomly for 5 seconds. The benchmark used the moz-gles11 context, which closely follows the OpenGL ES 1.1 specification. Note that our library is constantly being updated and performance is often enhanced quickly. Thus, this benchmark may be out of date by the time this paper appears in print. Figure 1. Setup time for loading scene 3. DEMOS To demonstrate the use of our library we have written several demos that make use of its features. Below some screenshots of applications built with our library: All demos can be accessed from our web page: http://www.c3dl.org Figure 3. Screenshot s of our demos There are a mix of demos that we have on our site. The flickr demo does searches for pictures on flickers and textures cubes with them. Ricochet is our 3D version of Pong and Explorer shows how you can set up a first person environment. 4. CONCLUSION Our library is still in its infancy but work is coming along quickly. Its features are constantly being updated and refined. One of the biggest hurdles that this project faces is that there is a lack of support for the <canvas> tag in Internet Explorer. However, work is being done to retrofit this and other unsupported tags into IE (5). In time, it is hoped that this will not be an issue One of the key features of doing 3D with canvas as opposed to something like Papervision 3D is that the canvas is part of the web page. It isn't a separate entity that happens to sit on the web page but is an element of the page. This ability will allow different types of games to be delivered on the web page. We can include the web as part of the actual game play. C3DL will help simplify this process. 5.
